div.p: qe/rous—Thuc. divides the year into qe/ros, consisting of about eight months (Elaphebohon to Pyanepsion) and xeimw/n, consisting of about four (Maimacterion to Anthesterion).
a(/ma tw=| si/tw| a)kma/zonti—‘just when the corn was ripening’; about the middle of May, 428 B.C., before the harvest (karpou= cugkomidh/).
e)gkaqezo/menoi—the form serves as an aorist as well as a present.
w(/sper ei)w/qesan—sc. gi/gnesqai, in the two previous invasions. The plan had been started by Pericles.
o(/ph| parei/koi—impers., though strictly o( qeo/s is the subject implied.

to\n plei=ston o(/milon—cf. II. 31 o( a)/llos o(/milos yilw=n, ‘the main body.’ Outside Thuc. o(/milos is found only in Herod., in tragedy, and in late authors.—The wasting of the country was a tedious task that would devolve naturally on the light-armed troops.

ei)=rgon to\ mh/—for the constr., which is common with verbs and phrases signifying prevention (Aesch. PV. 252 e)celusa/mhn brotou\s | to\ mh\ . . molei=n, and often in Aesch.) cf. VI. 1 diei/rgetai to\ mh\ h)/peiros ei)=nai (where the MS. ou)=sa is shown by many imitations of the sentence by later authors to be a mistake).

tw=n o(/plwn = tou= stratope/dou, strictly the space in front of the quarters where the arms were stacked; here the word marks the fact that the light-armed could not with safety be withdrawn from the hoplites. 10. ta\ e)ggu\s th=s po/lews—i.e. houses, trees, vineyards: we
are not to suppose that the Athenians cropped their lands annually for the benefit of the Peloponnesian invaders.
ou(=—the gen. as in misqo\s triw=n mhnw=n. The enemy remained in Attica about thirty days: the longest invasion, that of 430 B.C., lasted forty days, the shortest, in 425 B.C., fifteen days.

*le/sbos a)pe/sth—the gravity of this event lay in the fact that Lesbos and Chios were the only two islands in the Aegean that retained the position of independent allies of Athens. These furnished manned ships, but not infantry or money. For the narrative see Introd. p. xiii.
*mhqu/mnhs—Methymna, the second town in Lesbos, was under a democracy, Mytilene under an oligarchy.
boulhqe/ntes agrees kata\ su/nesin with *le/sbos: this change, in the case of peoples, is especially common in Thuc.; and cf. c. 67, 3 h)liki/a . . w=n. So with stratia/, stra/teuma.
tw=n . . th/n serve for all three pairs of nouns.
xw=sin—the harbours were to be turned into lime/nes klh|stoi/ (II. 94, 4): walls were carried across the mouth on artificial moles, and the narrow opening left could be closed with a chain.

e)pe/menon—showing why they had put off the revolt. The constr. with e)pime/nein is here double: (1) th\n . . poi/hsin telesqh=nai, as in VII. 20 perie/mene to\n *xarikle/a . . paralabei=n: (2) o(/sa . . e)/dei a)fike/sqai, an accusative clause. (It is objected that Thuc. elsewhere uses e)pime/nein only as intrans., but he uses e.g. me/nw and u(po- in both ways; and why not e)pi-?)
toco/tas—as mercenaries.

metapempo/menoi h)=san—cf. I. 99 h)=san . . a)/rxontes, II. 80 h)=san . . cumproqumou/menoi. Of course, the periphrasis with pres partic. is much less common than with perf., but it is not different in principle. Passages like II. 67 ou(= h)=n stra/teuma poliorkou=n ‘where there was a blockading army’ are quite different, the partic. not belonging to the verb. In yet another case, like I. 38 toi=s plei/osin a/re/skonte/s e)smen, the partic. is a predicative adj.
i)di/a|—in contrast with what the government was doing koinh=|.
kata/—often of the motive or reason, e.g. II. 87 cumparagenome/nwn kata\ fili/an.

pro/cenoi—the fact that there were more representatives
of Athens than one at Mytilene might show that the office was hereditary in a family, but more probably the title of pro/cenos kai\ eu)erge/ths had been granted by Athens to members of different Mytilenean families. Aristotle in Pol. 1304 a says that Dexander h)=rce th=s sta/sews kai\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous parw/cune pro/cenos w)/n: he had a private quarrel with a member of the aristocratic party; from this small matter pollw=n e)ge/neto a)rxh\ kakw=n. In any case it would have been the duty of the Proxenus to inform Athens of movements in Mytilene unfavourable to her interests even before the war; but doubtless the quarrel was now an exasperating motive to him, and led directly to the outbreak of stasis, for it was a dispute about property and intermarriage between families of the opposed parties.
cunoiki/zousi—i.e. attempting to make the island into a single po/lis under one government, and in this case, an oligarchy.
cuggenw=n — Lesbos being of Boeotian (Aeolic) origin. To intervene on behalf of kinsmen was under all circumstances deemed justifiable among Greek states.
ei) mh/ tis—‘unless they mean to,’ the fut. indic. marking the urgency; cf. VIII. 91 ei) mh/ tis h)/dh fula/cetai.
no/sou—during 430 and 429 B.C.

a)/rti kaqistame/nou—‘just becoming established’ (i.e. settled, chronic). Cf. I. 1 a)rca/menos (cuggra/yai) eu)qu\s kaqistame/nou. If we render thus, it makes no difference whether Thuc. means the ten years' or the twenty-seven years' war. In either case, a)kma/zontos shows that ‘in its infancy’ is wrong. But Classen's ‘in the middle period’ seems impossible: for it is inconceivable that kaqistame/nou tou= pole/moi should mean either ‘just beginning,’ as he understands I 1, or ‘in the middle’ at will. In V. 25 eu)qu\s a)/llh taraxh\ kaqi/stato the verb means not merely ‘arose,’ but ‘tended to become permanent,’ applying to a period, not to a moment. a)kma/zontos—a)/rti does not extend to this. A period of a)kmh/ is of course meant. Athens was now beginning to feel the strain on her finances (see c. 19); and her position in Chalcidice was very precarious. (Vollgraff proposes to add h)/dh before a)kma/zontos, but this is not necessary.)

mei=zon me/ros ne/montes—‘attaching greater importance to their wish that it was not true’ (than to the allegations). For a)lhqh= cf. I. 8 plwimw/tera e)ge/neto ne)mein me/ros or moi=ran several times in tragedy: Aesch. PV. 294, Soph. Trachin. 1238, Eur. Supp. 241; cf. to\ i)/son ne/mein I. 71, e)/lasson ne)mein VI. 88, ple/on n. Eur. Hec. 868, c. 48, 1.
paraskeuh/n refers of course to the preparations of c. 2, 2 (cf. c. 2, 3).
dei/santes—ingressive.
e)capinai/ws—like e)capi/nhs, found only in Thuc. and Xen. among Attic prose writers (for e)cai/fnhs or ai)fnidi/ws).

peri\ *pelopo/nnhson plei=n—both in 431 and 430 B.C. when the Pel. invaded Attica (II. 23, 56), a fleet had been sent out to make descents on the coast of the Peloponnese, as a counter-move. For the operations of this year see c. 16, 1; for those of 426 B.C. see cc. 91, 94.
*malo/eis was a local name of Apollo in Lesbos; its origin is unknown.
pandhmei/—the whole people together, not by families or clans.
e)lpi/da ei)=nai like ei)ko/s e)sti, is commonly followed by pres. or aor. infin.
e)peixqe/ntas is conditional.

h)
 me
 cumbh=| . . ei) de\ mh/—a common idiom, found already in Homer; cf. e.g. Plato, Prot. 325B e)a
 me
 e(kw
 pei/qhtai: ei) de\ mh/.

ei)pei=n—this depends on the sense of ‘order’ implied in the passage; cf. Andoc. de Myst. 20 o( ga\r no/mos ou(/tws ei(=xen: ei) me\n ta)lhqh= mhnu/seie/ tis, ei)=nai th\n a)/deian, ei) de\ ta\ yeudh=, teqna/nai. Of course ei)pei=n = keleu=sai. (This passage is brief and peremptory in tone: its dramatic manner is quite characteristic, and there is no ground for suspecting the text.)
para\ sfa=s—put briefly for para\ sfa=s parageno/menai kai\ parou=sai: similarly parei=nai is often found with ei)s or e)pi/ with accus.; but there is no precise parallel to the present case.
e)s fulakh\n e)poih/santo—so VIII. 1 e)s a/sfa/leian poiei=sqai. Cf. Andoc. de Myst. 117 qugate/res ai(\ e)gi/gnonto e)/s te e)me/ kai\ *le/agron.

diaba/s.—the sentence, containing five participles, is an example of what Dionysius calls to\ pukno/n of Thucydides; Cicero speaks of him as pressus, Quintilian as densus. The participles that denote closely connected parts of the same action are joined by kai/.
e)pituxw/n = w(s e)pe/tuxe.

plw=| xrhsa/menos—‘after a good passage.’ plw=| = eu)ploi/a|, as in I. 137. (Some make plw=| xrhsa/menos merely = pleu/sas, but
Antiphon V. 24 plou=s h(mi=n e)gi/gneto kai\ a)nh/geto ploi=a a)/panta seems decisive.)
ou)/te . . te—a common idiom (cf. neque . . que or et), by which emphasis is thrown on the second clause.

ta/ te a)/lla . . e)fu/lasson—‘and besides (ta\ a)/lla, adverbial) having protected with rapidly constructed defences all round the half-finished (works) of the walls and docks they guarded them.’ This is the best way of taking this puzzling sentence. None of the changes in the text that have been proposed is an improvement.
peri/ is an adverb = pe/ric, as in Homer (Wilamowitz on Eur. HF. 1035).

oi( *)aqhnai=oi—the subject of the subord. verb is put at the head of the sentence to contrast the action of Athenians and Lesbians sharply; a good parallel occurs at VII. 32 oi( de\ . . pre/sbeis . . e)peidh\ . . e)/mellon a)/cein to\n strato/n, o( *niki/as . . pe/mpei. The imperf.,
e(w/rwn (sc. ta\ gigno/mena), is used because the action overlaps that of a)ph/ggeilan.
a)para/skeuoi qualifies polemei=n, and is therefore co-ordinate with e)cai/fnhs: cf. e.g. I. 39 prou/xonta kai\ e)k tou= a)sfalou=s, and c. 13, 2 qa=sson gege/nhtai kai\ a)para/skeuos.
e)/kploun tina—for the use of tis cf. II. 22 i(ppomaxi/a tis bra/xeia e)ge/neto.
naumaxi/an—both dat. and accus. seem to occur with w(s e)pi/ of intention; but the MSS. often vary, as here.

pro\ tou= lime/nos—i.e. that harbour which was used by the fleet (cc. 3, 6; 6, 1), in which their ships had lam. (Steup's suggestion that tou= e(te/rou l. should be read is unnecessary.) Presently they were driven back into this same harbour. The northern harbour is meant. See Introd. P. xiv.
o)li/gon is accus. of space (cf. 104, 2); of time II. 8 o)li/gon pro\ tou/twn.
to\ parauti/ka . . a)pope/myasqai—‘get the ships withdrawn for the time being,’ i.e. in order to gain time.
kai/ ‘accordingly.’
tw=n diaballo/ntwn—see c. 2, 3. The partic. becomes a subst, as in oi( e)pago/menoi II. 2, oi( prodido/ntes II. 5.

ta\s nau=s is not object of pei/seian, but only subject of a)pelqei=n, ta\s nau=s a)pelqei=n being an exact citation of the proposal they would make in the Ecclesia, which was to be for a permanent withdrawal. The constr. is strange, however, and poih/seian has been proposed.

e)n th=| *male/a| pro\s b. ph=s po/lews—the Malea that is known is the SE. point of Lesbos, 70 stadia from the city. A solution of the difficulty has been found, Introd. p. XV. (Those who suppose that the SE. point of the island is meant, take pro\s b. th=s po/lews with a)poste/llousi. But from the narrative that follows, it is clear the A. were lying to the north of the city (esp. c. 6, 1); and it is not likely they were so far distant as 70 stades. Some are driven to suspect that e)n th=| *male/a| may be corrupt or spurious.)
toi=s is neut., and
proxwrh/sein is epexegetic.

dia\ tou= pela/gous—crossing the Aegean directly instead of sailing down the coast of Asia Minor, between Chios and Erythrae, before crossing among the islands. The alternative routes are clearly explained in Odyssey III. 170 f. and the risks of that across the me/son pe/lagos are indicated. (Cf. Tozer, Islands of the Aegean, p. 170.)

au)toi=s prob. = the Lesbians, and is dat. commodi with e)/prasson, as in V. 76, where those acting for Sparta at Argos are called oi( toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois pra/ssontes. (Others take au)toi=s with h(/cei, or refer it to the Lacedaemonians.)
e)bebohqh/kesan—‘were there to aid.’ Thuc. is remarkably partial to the pluperf., as e.g. I. 128 e)nege(grapto, ‘the contents of the letter were.’

*)/imbrioi kai\ *lh/mnioi—closely associated with the Athenians throughout the war. The islands had been secured for Athenian ‘cleruchs’ by Miltiades; and along with Scyros they were regarded as very peculiarly the possessions of Athens.
pandhmei/—equivalent to panstratia=| in this connexion, as II. 31, 1 clearly shows.
strato/pedon—north of the city, where the fleet was lying.
ou)k e)/lasson e)/xontes describes a state of things, like krapou=ntes, vikw=ntes.
e)phuli/santo—‘did not encamp on the field,’ which was necessary to maintain a disputed victory (Bloomfield). What they did and what they felt are here balanced by ou)/te . . ou)/te.

e)k *peloponnh/sou kai\ met' a)/llhs—this appears to stand for ei) pr. ti (paraskeuh=s) e)k *p. kai\ a)/lloqen, ‘to try their fortune with remforcements from the Pel. and elsewhere, if any should come.’ Bloomfield and others have supposed that kai/ is intensive here, ‘again with fresh preparations’; but with the order of the text, the sense would necessarily be
that some reinforcement had already come from Peloponnese. As for met' a)/llhs, they might hope for ships from Megara, Leucas or Ambracia: Thebes had none.

au)toi=s . . a)fiknei=tai—the dat. with verbs of motion—which is strictly a dat. of mterest rather than of motion—is common in poetry, but does not occur in Attic prose outside Thuc.; cf. e.g. Aesch. PV. 35 d' a)ll' h)=lqen au)tw=| *zhno\s a)/grupnon be/los.
meta\ th\n ma/xhn u(/steron—i.e. they did not get there immediately after the arrival of the A. fleet (c. 4, 1), but only after the battle (§ 2).
oi( de/—co-ordinate with oi( me\n h(su/xazon.
ou)de\n i)sxuro\n a)po/—‘no sign of energy on the part of.’

periormisa/menoi to\ pro\s no/ton—‘changing their position and casting anchor south.’ As Malea pro\s bore/an remained still in their hands as a nau/staqmon, it is evident that a part only of the ships was sent to this new station.
to\ pro\s no/ton is adverbial as IV. 23 periw/rmoun plh\n ta\ pro\s to\ pe/lagos.
e(kate/rwqen th=s po/lews—explaining du/o. Logically Thuc. should have written strato/pedon, as there was but one on either side.
mh\ xrh=sqai—epexegetic.
nau/staqmon—the roadstead where the supply-ships lay.
ma=llon means rather than the new strato/pedon south of the town.

a)gora/ is Kruger's probable alteration for a)gora=s, on the analogy of such phrases as a)gora
 pare/xein, VII. 39 th
 a)gora
 tw=n pwloume/nwn . . e)pi\ th
 qa/lassan komi/sai. The idea of a site seems always present, and a)gora/ is not a synonym of ta\ w)/nia or ta\ pwlou/mena.

ta/ is probably subject, not adverbial accus., so that we have the pass. of to\n peri\ *m. po/lemon e)pole/moun: cf. VIII. 18 to\n po/lemon koinh=? polemou/ntwn (imper.). The act. of polemw= does not seem to occur with an adverbial accus.

peri\ *pelopo/nnhson—in the previous year the Pelo ponnesians had attempted an offensive war on a considerable scale in Acarnania, which, with the exception of Oeniadae, was in alliance with Athens. The idea was, to suppress the influence of Athens in the NW. (Naupactus, Zacynthus, Cephallenia, as well as Acarnania); and so to put an end to the harassing expeditions of Athenian fleets peri\ *pelopo/nnhson. But the scheme failed completely; and a squadron under Phormio that
had been stationed at Naupactus in 430 B.C. to close the Corinthian gulf to Peloponnesian trade, gained two brilliant victories. After the departure of the enemy's fleet, Phormio made an expedition into Acarnania, but was prevented by severe weather from attacking Oeniadae. Early in the spring of this year (428), Phormio returned to Athens; and it is evident that he was now dead or out of health. His statue was placed on the Acropolis and an inscription in his honour was set up at Delphi. (For peri\ some MSS. give e)s: and perhaps e)s ta\ peri\ *p. was the original form; cf. II. 7, 3. See, however, c. 3, 2.)
sfi/si as direct reflexive, referring to the nearer subject, is an Ionic use.
*lakwnikh=s depends on xwri/a.
a)nasth/sas—the verb occurs in a similar connexion in II. 68 and 96; in IV. 90 a/nasth/sas *)aqhnai/ous pandhmei/.

kata\ to\n *)axelw=|on—‘by way of the A.’; not the technical use of kata/ meaning ‘down’ a stream (cf. Aeschines II. 124 ei)splei=n kata\ to\n *ludi/an potamo/n); Oeniadae was an important town on a hill in marshy ground near the SW. coast of Acarnania W. of the mouth of the Achelous. Cobet conjectured a/na/ for kata/.
frourw=n—the contrast with au)to/qen suggests that these were not Leucadians.
a)popleu/santes—i.e. the ships withdrew to Acarnania, and from there the negotiation was carried on.

*dwrieu/s—a Rhodian athlete, who won prodigious fame and became the typical Olympic victor. He was son of the Diagoras for whom Pindar wrote the seventh Olympian. Besides three Olympian victories he won many at the Isthmian and Nemean games. (References to his career: VIII. 35, Xen. Hell. I. 5, Pausan. II. 7.)
kaqesto/s—MS. evidence and analogy favour the form in -o/s for the neut.; but etymology (-a/os) and the ancient grammarians are for -w/s.
tou\s ga/r—cf. I. 40 to\n no/mon mh\ kaqista/nai w)/ste tou\s e(te/rwn a)fistame/nous de/xesqai.
e)n h(donh=| e)/xousi—so e)n ai)ti/a|, e)n o)rgh=|, e)n o)rrwdi/a| etc., cf. c. 34, 3 and e)n h(donh=| ei)=nai I. 99.
xei/rous—think worse of them for being traitors.

ou)k a)/dikos . . e)stin, ei) tu/xoien—like I. 120 a)ndrw=n swfro/nwn e)sti/n, ei) mh\ a)dikoi=nto, h(suxa/zein. Here ou)k a)/. . . .
e)stin=di/kaio/n e)sti xei/rous h(gei=sqai, and in such cases (see Goodwin, MT. § 555) the opt. is not seldom found. The idiom should certainly not be regarded as abnormal. Cf. e.g. Plato, Gorg, 482 B e)/gwge oi)=mai krei=tton ei)=nai . . diafwnei=n xoro\n w(=| xorhgoi/hn. Bayfield on Antig. 666 collects passages from Soph. Presently
diakri/nointo is by assimilation to tu/xoien.
gnw/mh|—‘feeling,’ ‘sentiment’;

eu)noi/a| ‘loyalty’ to each other. These words, so frequent in Thuc. and orators, have various shades of meaning; and of gnw/mh it would be rash to say that we can always be sure of its precise significance— Classen has discussed gnw/mh at length in his Intr.—but here the parallel paraskeuh\ kai\ du/namis show that the two are closely similar in sense (eu)/noia is the intellectual aspect of gnw/mh); and c. 10 e)n tw=| diala/ssonti th=s gnw/mhs kai\ ai( diaforai\ tw=n e)/rgwn, where the meaning of gnw/mh is fixed by met' a)reth=s dokou/shs and o(moio/tropoi, bears this out. (eu)/noia of course implies ‘between equals’ here, not loyalty to a superior.) Cf. also c. 12, 1.

mhde/ tw|—here and again at c. 67, 2 there should undoubtedly be only a comma before mhde/. Thuc. never uses ou)de/, mhde/=‘and not,’ unless a neg. clause precedes; and it is quite plain from what precedes—ou)k a)/dikos au)/th h( a)ci/wsis, viz. xei/rous h(gei=sqai, ei) tu/xoien—that o(\ . . ou)k h)=n and mhde/ tw| xei/rous do/cwmen ei)=nai adhere closely together.
e)n toi=s deinoi=s—for Athens; often used of the troubles of war.

peri\ ga\r tou= dikai/ou kai\ a)reth=s—to be asking for a cummaxi/a when you have just abandoned one is a position that needs some justification; so first they will show that they were not guilty of a)diki/a (cf. c. 12, 2) since they were in danger of being ‘enslaved,’ and that they were actuated by the highest of motives, by a)reth/, unselfishness, regard for others, in that they wanted to ‘free Greece.’ Hence their diplh= a)po/stasis (c. 13, 1) might well commend them to their hearers.—Only one article is used because to\ di/kaion and a)reth/ are the two motives combined in the diplh= a)po/stasis.
prw=ton—this ‘first’ point—the question of political morality—occupies in point of fact most of the speech.
be/baion—always of two terminations in Thuc. Stobaeus gives bebai/an here: be/baion a)\n has been suggested.

met' a)reth=s dokou/shs e)s a)llh/lous gi/gnointo—the subject, as Bloomfield saw (and so Steup), is i)diw=tai kai\ po/leis: many edd. from Poppo onwards understand fili/a kai\ koinwni/a, but e)s a)llh/lous is a serious objection to this. It does not seem, how
ever, that a case has been made out for explaining gi/gnesqai meta/ ‘to behave with’ (majority of edd.); in the parallels proposed, such as kata\ cullo/gous gi/gnesqai, the verb means ‘to come into a certain condition or situation’: and as gene/sqai meta/ tinos=‘to be in the company of’ (e.g. Dem. LIV. 34), so met' a)reth=s gi/gnesqai should mean ‘range themselves with,’ and so, ‘to adopt,’ ‘work with’ a/reth/: a)reth\ (as above) dokou=sa e)s a)llh/lous=‘the supposition or assumption of mutual unselfishness, that each in his dealings with the other is acting unselfishly.’ So we may render ‘unless both begin with the assumption that the other is behaving unselfishly.’

ta)=lla o(moio/tropoi ei)=en—‘and in all other respects (besides that just mentioned) be like minded.’ Goller thought fi/loi was to be supplied out of fili/a as subj. to gi/gnointo. Vollgraff thinks gi/gnointo spurious and alters dokou/shs to dokh/sews with Herwerden, so that met'=‘besides’ and kai/=‘also.’ gi/gnointo and ei)=en are both needed, and are distinct m meaning. So long as the union between Lesbos and Athens was to further the resistance to Persia, both parties to the compact held to the belief that the other was actuated by a/reth/: but when Athens began to pursue another purpose, Mytilene gave up this belief, and the inherent difference of intention became manifest.

e)n ga\r tw=| dialla/ssonti th=s gnw/mhs—‘in animorum discrepantia’; the neut. partic. as abstract subst. (cf. the corresponding diaforai/) is a favourite device of Thuc., though rare in other prose; Xen. Cyr. IV. 5, 39 to\ e)llei=pon. Cf. e.g. II. 59 to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s gnw/mhs, VII. 68 th=s gnw/mhs to\ qumou/menon, for o)rgh/ and qumo/s. Thuc. likes to show the quality at work. The constr., as Krüger says, is freely imitated by late authors.
kaqi/stantai—‘become manifest’; cf. on c. 3

cummaxi/a e)ge/neto—referring to the transference of the hegemony of the allies from Sparta to Athens in 476 B.C. (I. 95). In reality this transference was an a)po/stasis from the Spartan alliance (Ath. Pol. c. 23); and the anxiety of Sparta to be quit of the war against Persia (a)pallacei/ontes tou= *mhdikou= pole/mou I. 95) was not shown until after the transference took place. Samos, Chios and Lesbos were at the head of the movement in favour of Athens (Plut. Arist. c. 23). (This passage well illustrates the freedom with which Greek orators habitually manipulate history when they refer to the past.)

a)polipo/ntwn e)k—this use of a/polei/pein seems to result
from such phrases as a)polei/pein th\n cummaxi/an (c 9), so that the full sense is a)polipo/ntwn (h(ma=s kai\ a)pelqo/ntwn).
*)aqhnai/ois and
toi=s *(/ellhsi depend on cu/mmaxoi egeno/meqa: toi=s *(/ellhsi is the exaggeration of rhetoric; for in reality they entered the Delian confederacy.
me/xri—‘so long as,’ a very rare use, not noted in L. & S.; Xen. Hell. I. 1, 6.

e)pagome/nous—this word, very common in Thuc., regularly means ‘to invite,’ ‘call in.’ But here, in contrast with a)nie/ntas, it is slightly different, ‘procure for themselves,’ as in e)pagwgh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn (Herbst).
a)deei=s—‘free from anxiety.’
dia\ poluyhfi/an—with a)du/natoi o)/ntes. Each constituent state had a vote in the synod of the League, but the allies were unable to combine against Athens through their disagreements.
e)doulw/qhsan—i.e. became subject allies. Cf. I. 98 prw/th au(/th po/lis cummaxi\s (Naxos) para\ to\ kaqesthko\s e)doulw/qh.

paradei/gmasi toi=s progignome/nois x.—‘drawing our proofs (that they were no longer pistoi/) from what was previously happening,’ i.e. ‘taking warning from the line of action that they had adopted.’ para/deigma is an example by which a conclusion may be supported. toi=s progignome/nois=‘the line of conduct that they were pursuing previously, and had not ceased to pursue.’ (The aor. or perf. partic. is conjectured here as in I. 23 tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h(gou=mai mega/gous gignome/nous . . a)nagka/sai e)s to\ polemei=n, which alludes to the conduct of Athens during the same period—between the formation of the Confederacv to the beginning of the war—from a different point of view. In both places the pres. partic., describing something still in progress, seems better.)

ou) ga\r ei)ko\s h)=n . . . mh\ dra=sai tou=to—to understand this sentence, it is necessary to realize that dra=sai refers, not to the future, but to the past, as in c. 40, 5 e)nqumhqe/ntes a)\ ei/ko\s h)=n au)tou\s poih=sai krath/santas u(mw=n. The sense is ‘it was not likely that they . . would not have treated those who were left in this way, if only they had found any opportunity.’ We should have been ‘enslaved’ had circumstances been favourable to Athens: cf. I. 98 (e)doulw/qhsan) kai\ tw=n a)/llwn w(s e(ka/sth| cune/bh. (Dobree's dunhqei=en makes the ref. to the future.)
bebaio/teroi—the personal constr. often found with a)/cios, di/kaios, i(kano/s.

kai\ pro\s to\ ple/on . . a)ntisoume/nou—(I should prefer to insert a)\n before a)ntisoume/nou, see Introd. p. xlii). The text means ‘since in contrast, moreover, with the majority who were already yielding, we alone still tried to keep on an equal footing with them.’ These words do not add much to what has been already said in u(poxeiri/ous . . o(milou=ntes, but, as Classen put it, refer to the conduct of the Lesbians as viewed by Athens.

to\ h(me/teron, not h(mei=s, is used for the sake of the verbal contrast with to\ ple/on. mo/nou, if the text is sound, is (as Steup points out), not a proper antithesis to to\ ple/on, and it is an awkward anticipation of the next clause, a)/llws . . e)rhmo/teroi.

to\ de\ a)nti/palon de/os—‘it is reciprocity of apprehension alone,’ as distinct from one-sided de/os. There is no objection to de/os, and no inconsistency with the opening words of c. 12, if the emphasis be put on a)nti/palon, as on prou/xwn in the next sentence, and if mo/non be taken as qualifying a)nti/palon rather than pisto/n.
ga/r—‘for in that case.’
o(/son—quatenus, ‘so far as.’

e)s th\n a)rxh/n ‘with a view to their empire.’ (I see no reason whatever for rejecting these words, as Kruger and Steup do. They give the true object of the Athenian policy, and the mention of a)rxh/ is appropriate enough in the presence of those who so strongly disliked it; cf. I. 75, with II. 8.)
gnw/mhs ma=llon e)fo/dw| h)\ i)sxu/os—‘by means of policy and not of force.’
ta\ pra/gmata . . katalhpta/—‘they might make themselves masters of the situation.’

a(/ma me/n.—this is the lo/gos eu)preph/s that they used as evidence that they were upright. The allies whom we attacked, they eould say, must have been in the wrong; otherwise those who have a vote in the confederacy equal to ours would never have been found at our side. The

mh/ is due to the protest implied in m. e\xrw=nto. If a)/kontas is right, it must be put briefly for a)/kontas a)\n o)/ntas, ‘but would have been unwilling, unless’ etc. But this, even if possible, is extremely awkward, whereas e(ko/ntas, read in a good scholium on this passage, gives the natural constr. and sense.
e)n tw=| au)tw=|=a(/ma: so IV. 73.
ta\ kra/tista—for tou\s krati/stous.

[ta\] teleutai=a—it is clear that ta\ kra/tista is object of
lipo/ntes, and teleutai_a is predicative; so that as there is no parallel for the article, it should be omitted.
tou= a)/llou—neut. collective, and gen. abs.

au)tw=n—in contrast with pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ sth=nai (aid from others): pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ sth=nai = h(ma=s tou\s duname/nous h(gh/sasqai au)tw=n (schol.). For the simple i(/stasqai ‘rally’ with pro/s cf. IV. 56 pro\s th\n e)kei/nwn gnw/mhn e(/stasan.
e)xeirw/santo—sc. tou\s cumma/xous.

to/ te nautiko/n—“a third reason is here given for the policy of the Athenians, of leaving the M. still independent,— namely, the apprehension of danger from driving them to unite their navy with that of the Peloponnesians” (Bloomfield).

kaq' e(
 geno/menon—standing alone this phrase would certainly mean ‘concentrating,’ ‘becoming united,’ as is proved by such passages as Xen. Hell. V. 2, 16 pw=s ei/ko\s u(ma=s th=s me
 *boiwti/as e)pimelhqh=nai o(/pws mh\ kaq' e(
 ei)/h, polu\ de\ mei/zonos a(qroizome/nhs duna/mews a(melh=sai; This would give no point here, since the whole fleet is of course meant by to\ nautiko/n. The accepted meaning ‘uniting with others’ is only to be got through the addition, h)\ . . prosqe/menon, which must be regarded as an explanation. (Steup suggests that prosqe/menon should be removed, so that kaq' e(
 g. can be taken with the datives. I do not think it a likely note—in fact there is a scholium, e)s tau)to\ cunelqo/n, here—but I do think there is a difficulty, and possibly the first h/ should be removed.)

ta\ de\ kai/—‘to some degree also’; a fourth and minor reason why the M. retained their independence. The schol. divides qerapei/a into flattery of the Athenian people and gifts to the leaders of the demos; no doubt these are included.

ou) . . a)\n e)dokou=men dunhqh=nai=ou)k a)\n e)dunh/qhmen, w(s e)do/kei. dokou=men, read by Kruger (e)/ti dokou=men Steup) is simpler, but the imperf., referring to the time of the revolt, does not exclude the pres., and cf. c. 13 e)nomi/zomen a)posth/sesqai.
toi=s—‘what had happened.’

ti/s—‘what form of trustworthy friendship or freedom was this turning out to be?’ i.e. how could we put any confidence in a friendship or a freedom like that? (Dion. Hal. Antiq. VI. 78 ti/s ou)=n h( toiau/th fili/a kai\ pi/stis, e)n h(=| para\ gnw/mhn a/llh/lous qerapeu/ein a)nagkasqhso/meqa; seems to have found h(, not h)\, after au(/th in his MS., and our MSS. have h(.)
para\ gnw/mhn—‘without sincerity,’ ou)k a)po\ gnw/mhs a)ll' a)po\ glw/sshs mo/non.

u(pedexo/meqa—this word can be used of every kind of reception or welcome afforded to a ce/nos, short of rejection: e.g. in Lycurgus § 133 ou)demi/a po/lis au)to\n ei)/ase par' au(th=| metoikei=n is repeated in the form tou=ton de\ ti/s a)\n u/pode/caito po/lis;

o(/ te . . pi/stin bebaioi=, h(mi=n tou=to . . e)xuro\n parei=xe— passages sometimes cited as parallel to this (as II. 40 d toi=s a)/llois a/maqi/a me\n qra/sos, logismo\s de\ o)/knon fe/rei and IV. 125 o)/per filei= me/gista strato/peda a)safw=s e)kplh/gnusqai) bear little resemblance to it. If pi/stin, which Stahl bracketed, is sound, we should assume, with Kruger, a conflation of relative with epexegetic clause—o(\ eu)/noia bebaioi= with eu)/. pi/stin bebaioi=. A schol. already takes this view; and unless the text is corrupt, no other explanation can be entertained. (The other scholium is a mere paraphrase, but its conclusion—dia\ tou=to a)/pistos h)=n h( fili/a a)mfote/rwn—shows that the writer discerned that in the whole passage, from ti/s ou)=n to parabh/sesqai e)/mellon, the underlying idea, not clearly expressed, is that of a pi/stis a)/pistos. Both pisth/ above and pi/stin here have been removed by critics more intent, perhaps, on the language than on the thought. cu/mmaxoi u(po\ de/ous pistoi/ are cu/mmaxoi a)/pistoi.)
para/sxoi—representing o(pote/rous a)\n para/sxh| in past sequence. 10
a)sfa/leia—‘sense of security.’
kai/—‘as a consequence’ of the qa/rsos.
dia\ . . me/llhsin refers to dokou=men a)dikei=n: this might be a reason for objecting that they should have waited till some wrong was inflicted on them.
ta\ deina/=‘methods of coercion’; for the whole cf. I. 25 kata\ th\n *faia/kwn proenoi/khsin th=s *kerku/ras.

ei) ga\r dunatoi/.—with the text before us, which (except for a)ntimellh=sai) follows the MSS., we must render, ‘had we been in a position both to intrigue like them and to delay like them (i.e. to put off our attack, but at the same time to have our plan of attack ready), what need was there for us to remain, nevertheless, at their mercy?’ The M. might of course defer the attack, but if they waited for the Athenians to attack they were lost. This is fairly satisfactory, the only difficulty being that e)k tou= i)/sou and e)k tou= o(moi/ou (‘just as we were,’ aeque atque fuimus) have no correspondence. It is in connexion with the next sentence that doubts arise. (1) e)pixeirei=n clearly corresponds to a)ntepibouleu=sai, and proamu/nasqai to a)ntimellh=sai (or a)ntepimellh=sai); (2) the statement ‘we need not have remained in their power’ is hardly equivalent to
‘we need not have revolted because we should have retained our independence’; (3) e)p' e)kei/nois ei)=nai looks suspicious before e/p' e)kei/nois o)/ntas. A great many changes have been proposed, and those of Heilmann and Kruger indicated in the crit. note and adopted by Classen give a much better correspondence and an improved sense. Yet I do not feel that the objections to the MS. reading are decisive. The general sense is: we cannot be blamed for taking the first move merely because they delayed to take action against us.
toiau/tas—the asyndeton when a demonstrative pron. sums up what precedes is common.
ai)ti/as is ‘grievances’ (Cornford), not synonymous with profa/seis.
safei=s toi=s a)kou/ousi gnw=nai as in ka/lliston i/dei=n toi=s fi/lois Xen. Oec. VIII. 6; but an unusual kind of example. The words are appropriate to a pleader.
ei)ko/tws—‘reasonably.’
boulome/nous—what is to be supplied?

a)posth/sesqai d. a)po/stasin—the figura etymologica, as in VI. 56 tou\s th
 pomph
 pe/myontas, VIII. 58 koinh=| po
 po/lemon polemou/ntwn. It is usually said that Thuc. plays upon the double meaning of a)fi/stasqai here. (1) ‘abstain from.’ (2) ‘revolt from.’ With Poppo and Classen I cannot think this is so. The passage clearly corresponds to c. 10, 3 cu/mmaxoi e)geno/meqa ou)k . . *)aqhnai/ois, a)lla\ . . toi=s *)/ellhsi, and the M. had ‘revolted from’ the Greeks who formed the Delian league just as much as they had ‘revolted from’ the Athenians. Nor is the view of the majority borne out by h( me/ntoi a)po/stasis ktl.

cu
 kakw=s poiei=n—referring to katadou/lwsis tw=n *(ellh/nwn c. 10. Cf. Xen. An. V. 5, 21 a)
 me/n tis eu)= poih=|, a)nt' eu)= poiei=n (a)nteupoiei=n MSS.), a)
 de\ kakw=s, a)le/casqai (Stallbaum on Plato, Gorg. 520 E).
propoih=sai=pro-diafqei=rai.
xrh/—sc. u(ma=s.
h(=| kai\ ma=llon i.e. in addition to the di/kaion and a)reth/ (c. 10, 1) or doing so.

boh/qeian a)poste/llein—the M. really suggest two plans, both of which were adopted (c. 15, 1; 16, 3; cf. 25, 1), viz. (1) that a fleet shall be sent to Lesbos, and (2) that there shall be another invasion of Attica, though there had already been one this year. But the second proposal is put forward only as according with the interest of Sparta (either the enemy will not resist you, or—if they do—they must withdraw from the Peloponnese (cf. § 3) as well as from Lesbos, § 4). The second
proposal only was at first carried out, but it did not have the desired effect (c. 16, 2). In the following year, accordingly, both schemes were to be carried out concurrently (c. 26), but even then the Pel. were slack about no. 1 (c. 27, 1). (I see no ground for thinking the text deficient here, as Steup supposes. The two courses are not proposed as alternatives, and, on the other hand, they are with good reason not announced as two parts of a scheme for helping Lesbos.)
kai\ e)n tw=| au)tw=|—this point is explained in what follows: so far it has not been touched upon. To this
kairo\s . . pro/teron refers.
e)fqa/ratai—the old plur. terminations in -atai, -ato, are rarely found in Attic prose, as Xen. An. IV. 8, 5: Thuc. varies.
ai( me/n—see c. 7.

periousi/an new=n e)/xein—a number large enough to protect the harbours and coast of Attica without recalling those that were out. This forecast was entirely falsified by the event; but it might very well be entertained because (1) in spite of the fall of Potidaea (in 429 B.C.), no Athenian fleet had been sent out to the Peloponnese in 429; (2) only thirty ships had been sent out this year in answer to the Spartan invasion of Attica, whereas in 431 and 430 the number had been 100; (3) late in 429 a Peloponnesian fleet had made an abortive attempt to seize the Piraeus: reflexion on the result of this mismanaged affair may have led them, with good reason, to underrate the naval resources of Athens.
e)pesba/lhte—‘make an additional invasion’: to\ deu/teron emphasizes the e)p-.
w(=| ga\r dokei= . . pare/cei—‘if anyone is thinking that L. is far away, the advantage will be given to him close at hand’; that will come home to him.

e)n th=| *)attikh=| e)/stai—‘will turn on Attica, but (on the country) through which . . ,’ i.e. e)n th=| cummaxikh=|; the issue depends on the action of the cu/mmaxoi The need is to transfer the resources (cf. w)feli/an . . w)felei=tai) of the cu/mmaxoi from the Athenian to the Spartan side. Cf. Tac. Hist. II. 28 sin victoriae columen in Italia verteretur.
oi( pri\n douleu/ontes—i.e. those who were made u)potelei=s before us.
bohqhsa/ntwn—a remarkable ex of the gen. abs. where the subject of the verb is the same; cf. c. 112, 6.
ei)/xete—‘have up till now’ is the meaning given by Poppo; but ‘had’ before the war is more natural, and more in accordance with the action of Sparta.
e)leuqerou=ntes—a good point: at the outbreak of the war the Lac. had claimed to be ‘the liberators of Greece.’
e)s u(ma=s—‘with regard to you . .’
i)/sa kai/—adverbial, as o(moi/ws kai/.
i)/dion . . paraballome/nous—instead of the external accus. usual with paraba/llomai, i.e. ta\ sw/mata, we have here the internal accus., ki/ndunon.

th
 e)s th
 *)attikh
 e)sbolh/n—‘as regards the suggested (c. 13, 4) iuvasion.’ e)sbolh/n is the ‘accusative of anticipation,’ for which cf. I. 33, 3 to
 de\ po/lemon . . ei)/ tis u(mw=n mh\ oi)/etai e)/sesqai. In both these instances the verb that follows (poihso/menoi, e)/sesqai) of course supplies a governing word to the accus. as in V. 36 to\ *pa/nakton e)de/onto *boiwtou\s o(/pws paradw/sousi, and in general. But sometimes the accus. has no strict regimen, but the constr. is changed in the dependent clause, as in the well-known case Aristoph. Av. 1269 deino/n ge to
 kh/ruka . . ei) mhde/pote nosth/sei pa/lin.
parou=si . . e)/frazon ‘gave them orders while they were on the spot,’ i.e. did not wait to send round after the delegates had left.
kata\ ta/xos and

toi=s du/o me/resin belong to i/e/nai: cf. II. 10 cunh=?san ta\ du/o me/rh . . e)s to\n *)isqmo/n. The dat. is sociative, as constantly with words like strato/s and nau=s. The subject of e)/frazon and a)fi/konto is ‘the Lacedaemonians’ only. 3/4ths=ta\ tri/a me/rh; but 3/8ths=tw=n o)ktw\ ta\ tri/a me/rh. w(s poihso/menoi belongs to a(fi/konto as well as to e)/frazon.
kai\ (‘and then’)
o(lkou\s (cf. e)f-olki/on, a boat towed, newlkei=n, to beach a vessel with a o(lko/s. The instrument for pushing heavy weights was called e(/lic, but it was not invented till Archimedes)

pareskeu/azon—the ships which had been used against Phormio in the Corinthian gulf (at Lechaeum) were to be hauled over the Isthmus along the track, called di/olkos, to the Saronic gulf. The ships must have been put on some kind of truck. The exact nature of the o(lkoi/ is unknown; possibly they were rollers fixed in the di/olkos. u(perfe/rein, diafe/rein, diakomi/zein and die/lkein are used of this.
oi( de\ a)/lloi cu/mmaxoi—the ‘exclusive’ use of a)/llos.
e)n karpou= cugkomidh=| like e)n paraskeuh=| ei)=nai: (e)n)
a)rrwsti/a| like e)n a)qumi/a| ei)=nai.

dia\ kata/gnwsin a)sqenei/as sfw=n=dia\ to\ katagnw=nai
sfw=n a)sqe/neian, i.e. sfw=n depends on kata/gnwsin. On what the ‘imputation’ was based can be seen from c. 13.
to\ e)pi\ *le/sbw| nautiko/n—the suggestion of the speaker in c. 13 was ap' amfote/rwn (Lesbos and Peloponnese) a)poxwrh/sontai: but what is mentioned in c. 7, 3 had meantime occurred.
au)toi/—these, as the restriction shows, consisted of the zeugi=tai and qh=tes. The two higher classes served on board only in times of great danger.
para\ to\n *)isqmo\n e)pi/deicin e)poiou=nto ‘made a demonstration along the coast of.’ With a)nagago/ntes instead of the ordinary a)nagago/menoi cf. Herod. VI. 12 a)na/gwn ta\s ne/as.
a)poba/seis—the plan of making descents on the enemy's coasts as a counter-move to the invasion of Attica had been started by Pericles.
a)/pora nomi/zontes—‘thinking (the situation) difficult,’ a characteristic use of the neut. plur. without subst., as in I. 8 plwimw/tera e)ge/neto.

kai\ ai( peri\ th\n *p. tria/konta nh=es ‘the thirty ships that were about (off the W. coast) the Pel. as well.’ If the text is sound, the thirty ships of c. 7 must surely be meant: it is true that c. 7, 3 shows that the majority of these ships, at any rate, were no longer ravaging the coasts; but the Lac. are misled by an inaccurate report. Chambry, however, suggests that the eighteen ships referred to in c. 7, 3 had subsequently rejoined the other twelve; if so, it is strange that Thuc. has omitted to mention this.—The edd. who delete tria/konta point out that from c. 13, 3 it is clear the Lac. knew already about the doings of this earlier fleet. But (1), the Lesbian speaker does not say that the fleet was actually ravaging the coasts; and (2) in any case, if c. 13, 3 is in point here, so is c. 13, 4, and there the expectation is that the fleet will be withdrawn. Why should not the Lac. have fresh information—inaccurate—that the expectation had been falsified? The second

kai/=‘also,’ i.e. as well as the new fleet which was making a)poba/seis (§ 2). Those who omit tria/konta understand the fleet of 100 ships mentioned just before. This is of course possible, but the passage admits of a simple explanation as it stands; and it is hardly likely that the 100 ships could so soon be reported as ravaging the coasts.
th\n perioiki/da—land belonging to the peri/oikoi in Messenia seems to be meant.
u(/steron—it was not sent at once, c. 25. o(/ ti pe/myousin—o(/stis because of the purpose.
e)ph/ggellon—a technical word for sending out a formal notice, which may amount to a command. Cf. periagge)llw.
nau/arxon—an office held for a year. The admiral in war was almost as important as the kings, who eommanded the land-forces. His power increased when the Spartan navy became greater.
ei)=don—sc. a)naxwrh/santas: cf. e.g. II. 11 dh|ou=n ma=llon h)\ th\n e(autw=n dra=n, sc. dh|oume/nhn.

I reluctantly agree with Steup that this ch. is spurious. Apart from peculiarities of language, it seems impossible to reconcile § 2 with the facts given in Bk. II. about the Athenian fleet a)rxome/nou tou= pole/mou. (1) The 100 ships here said to be guarding Attica, Euboea and Salamis are not mentioned in Bk. II. They cannot be the 100 nh=es e)cai/retoi of which we read in II. 24. Those ships were docked, and were certainly not e)nergoi/: (2) ai( peri\ *potei/daian ktl. makes the total 250 wrong, for we know that the number of ships at Potidaea alone was seventy, and, even if we conjecture that some of them had been withdrawn, there is yet another fleet of thirty sent peri\ th\n *lokri/da kai\ *eu)boi/as a(/ma fulakh/n (II. 26) to be counted in; (3) it is diffieult to see why in § 4 the 1,600 men with whom Phormio a)petei/xise to\ e)k th=s *pallh/nhs (I. 64) should be reckoned in counting the expenses of the siege of Potidaea, and the 4,300 whom Hagnon took there after Phormio's departure (II. 58) omitted in the computation; (4) the digression on the numbers of the first year of the war, when we look for a reasoned comparison between the numbers of 431 and 428 is very odd; (5) if 100 ships were guarding Attica, Euboea and Salamis, why should the fleet of thirty have been sent out to guard Euboea? As Busolt says, the author of this chapter has overlooked the fleet of thirty.
kata\ to\n xro/non tou=ton o(/n—i.e. kaq' o)/n, according to a common idiom; cf. Soph. OC. 748 e)s tosou=ton ai/ki/as pesei=n | e)/doc', o(/son pe/ptwken h(/de.

e)n toi=s plei=stai dh/—for the fem. cf. c. 82, 1 (sta/sis) e)n toi=s prw/th e)ge/neto. Pre-eminence is not necessarily implied in any of the examples of this idiom, and Herbst is perhaps right in saying that prominence only is meant. The latter must be the point here, because of paraplh/siai de\ kai\ e)/ti plei/ous.
dh/ heightening the superlative is not elsewhere added to this idiom.
au)toi=s—with e)ge/nonto.

e)nergoi\ †ka/llei makes no sense. e)nergo/s, though not
elsewhere applied to ships, is well suited to them, ‘on active service,’ ‘in commission’; and it may be that the note in Hesychius ai( mh\ a)rgai/ alludes to this passage. But ka/llei must be corrupt, for the rendering ‘effective by their fine condition’ is not possible. Herbst's conjecture s/ kai\ l/, i.e. 230, is plausible; but in order to make up so great a total, he assumes a fleet of sixty ships for guarding the eoast of Attica. Were this so, we should surely have heard of it at c. 16, 2 among the reasons that caused the Pel. to abandon the invasion; and even though we are left to collect the number of ships at sea in 428 B.C., this large item in the total must have been mentioned somewhere. Still, the interpolator may have reckoned the total at 230 by the same proeess, whatever it was, that led him to 250 for 431 B.C. below. The number, however, does not come in naturally after e)n toi=s plei=stai. A very good sense would be got by mia=| po/lei (Widmann).
th/n te ga\r *)attikh/n—referring to the first year of the war; but there is no mention of such a fleet in the account of that year.
peri\ *pelopo/nnhson—this fleet had been sent out by Pericles as a counter-stroke to the invasion of Attica.
xwri\s de/—‘besides,’ sc. h)=san, which is implied in the context.
tou=to—i.e. the sending out of these armaments. In a somewhat similarly vague way

meta\ *poteidai/as is used for meta\ th=s *poteidai/as poliorki/as, with which should be compared II. 13 e)s *potei/daian a)panhlw/qh, ‘money was spent on the siege of P.’ It is strange that the expenses of the army at Potidaea, as distinct from the expenses of the fleet there, should be brought in so vaguely.
di/draxmoi—half a drachma a day was the ordinary pay for a hoplite: here it is one drachma for the hoplite and one for his servant.

e)la/mbane—we should expect e(/kastos e)la/mbanon or e)la/mbanen. It is the omission of a singular subject to which the verb is attracted that is remarkable: edd. note that this omission is frequent in Herod.
w(=n ou)k e)la/ssous—when Potidaea revolted in 432 B.C., 3000 Athenian hoplites had been sent to besiege it. It seems that the permanent force was maintained at this number throughout the siege.

oi(\ proaph=lqon—these 1600 had been sent to blockade
Potidaea from the south (I. 64) soon after the revolt. They were withdrawn from Chalcidice before the place fell.
to\n au)to\n misqo/n—viz. one drachma per man, or double the ordinary wage (VI. 31).
tosau=tai dh/—referring still to the paraplhsi/ai kai\ e)/ti plei/ous (§ 1); so that the digression extends to the end of the chapter.
o(/n—see c. 17, 1.
*mh/qumnan—see c. 2, 1.
w(s prodidome/nhn—‘in the belief that it was going to be betrayed’; cf. Aristoph. Pax 408 prodi/doton th\n *(ella/da. MT. § 32.
e)pi/kouroi—for these mercenaries see c. 2, 2.
katasthsa/menoi . . bebaio/tera—cf. I. 118 th\n a)rxh\n e)gkrateste/ran katesth/santo.
plhge/ntes—in an old poetical meaning, found several times in Thuc.
tau=ta . . kratou=ntas . . i(kanou\s o)/ntas—the partic. phrase in apposition to tau=ta, as in Soph. Antig. 17
ou)de\n oi)=d' u(pe/rteron | ou)/t' eu)tuxou=sa ma=llon ou)/t' a)twme/nh, Philoc. 1355 pw=s tau=t' e/canasxh/sesqe, toi=sin *)/atrews | e/me\ cuno/nta paisi/n;
ei)/rgein—‘isolate.’

au)tere/tai—it was unusual in Thuc.'s day for fighting men to serve as rowers: in Homeric times it was usual; cf. Il. 2.719 e)re/tai d' e)n e(kasth| penth/konta
e)pemba/san, to/cwn eu)= ei)do/tes i)=fi ma/xesqai.

e)gkatw|kodo/mhtai—see crit. note. The verb means to build into a wall. Clearly the forts were built at the same time as the wall at the points strong by natnre. If the perf. is right, we must take it as historic, like the presents, and render ‘there are forts built in at various points,’ so that the perf. points to the condition of the wall and forts when completed. But as no parallel to such a use of the perf. is known, the plup. should probably be read (I do not think h(=? for oi(= necessary; but these forms are often confused in MSS.).
a)mfote/rwqen is explained by kai\ e)k gh=s kai\ e)k qala/tths.
kai\ au)toi/—bringing their own contribution into connexion with that levied from the allies.

to/te prw=ton—probably meaning that the extraordinary war-tax was aetually levied for the first time (cf. to/te prw=ton in I. 96) in 428 B.C., though the arrangements for it existed before. Some think that Thuc. means for the first time in this war. There is no evidence that the tax had ever been levied before. (About the details of the ei)sfora/ before the age of Demosth. little is known, but the burden fell mainly on the rich, being ‘a progressive income-tax on property.’ The amount was fixed by the Ecclesia. Gilbert, Inn. Gesch. 129 f. gives good reasons for supposing that Cleon took the initiative in promoting the vote before the Eeclesia. See also Neil on Aristoph. Eq. 771, 923.)
diako/sia ta/lanta—in apposition to e)sfora/n.
a)rgurolo/gous nau=s—to eollect an e)sfora/—not, in this ease, arrears of tribute. The sending out of such ships is expressly attributed to Cleon in Eq. 1070. (

*lusikle/a—this Lysicles does not belong to the family of Habronichus (I. 91), but is the probatopw/lhs of obscure origin whose connexion with Aspasia brought him into prominenee; Aristoph. Eq. 132, 765, Plutarch, Per. 24.)
pempto\n au)to/n—meaning that Lysicles had the ehief command. The large number of strathgoi/ sent is probably due to the difficulty and delicacy of the mission.
*anaiitw=n—cf. c. 32.
a)/llhs—‘as well.’

e)/ti ga/r—about the middle of September in the previous year the Pel. had turned the siege of Plataea into a blockade They had withdrawn the greater part of their army, leaving a garrison to guard half their lines, while the other half was guarded by the Boeotians.
tw=| te si/tw| e)pilei/ponti—equivalent to th=| sitodei/a|. e)pilipo/nti all MSS.: other aecounts are not deeisive in favour of the present.

timwri/as=bohqei/as, as often in Thuc. The Athenians had promised to help Plataea when the siege began, but their hands had since been full owing to the plague, the siege of Potidaea and the revolt of Lesbos. See further, Introd. p. xvi.
e)shghsame/nwn—cf. VI. 99 ou)x h(/kista *(ermokra/tous e)shghsame/nou.
a)ndro\s ma/ntews—together.
e)strath/gei—the opinion of a general supported by a ma/ntis would carry great weight.
a)pw/knhsan . . to\n ki/ndunon—cf. c. 30, 4.

e)s de\ . . . ma/lista—the phrase with prep. stands as subject of the verb. In Andoc. I. 37 ei)s triakosi/ous is presently repeated in the form ma/lista triakosi/ous. For e)s and ma/lista often used together cf. e.g. c. 90, 3 peri/ and ma/lista, Dem. XXI. 154, peri/ and i)/sws, Herod. III. 159 ma/lista e)s.
e)ne/meinan—as in e)mme/nein toi=s o(/rkois etc.
tro/pw| toiw|de is added kata\ su/nesin.
cunemetrh/santo—it is possible to supply to\ tei=xos or ta\s kli/makas, but § 4 strongly favours the latter.
e)calhlimme/non—‘whitewashed.’ The e)c- probably denotes completion: the whitewashing had not been finished at one part of the wall.
h)riqmou=nto . . a)riqmou=ntes—for the rapid passage from mid. to act. ef. II. 9 nautiko\n parei/xonto . . pezo\n parei=xon.

e)s o(\ e)bou/lonto tou= tei/xous—sc. kaqora=n, or perhaps rather o(ra=n: tou= tei/xous agrees with kaqorwme/nou, and e)s o(\ e/boulonto=‘as far as they wanted to see it,’ i.e. a sufficiently wide piece was visible. The objection to this is that e)s o(/ for o(son or e)s o(/son does not oecur elsewhere. In Herod. e/s o(/ means ‘until’ with aorist or hist. pres. or iterative imperf.; but in Thuc. V. 66 e)s o(\ e)me/mnhnto=so far as (of time), a use not found elsewhere; and it is possible by Gk. usage of a prep. and neuter adj. or pron., that the phrase should denote time or place: e.g. e)c o)li/gou of time II. 11, of place II. 91, and so with e)k pollou=. Two other views of this passage, not involving change of the text, must be noticed: (a) taking tou= tei/xous as agreeing with kaqorwme)nou ‘as the wall was completely visible to the desired point’ i e. to the foot of the wall, viewed from above; but we should expect this meaning to be expressed directly and clearly. (b) Taking tou= tei/xous as depending on e)s o(/, ‘as they easily looked down upon the part of the wall that they wished to see,’ i e. kaqorwme/nou (tou/tou) e)s o(\ tou= tei/xous e(bou/lonto (o(ra=n). This is very awkward and we should expect kaqorw=ntes. The alterations proposed are (a) o(/son for e)s o(/, Stahl, or (b) to insert an infin., as a)nabh=nai after e)bou/lonto (Stein).
th\n cumme/trhsin . . e)/labon—for the periphrasis with labei=n cf. e.g. Soph. Phil. 1078 fro/nhsin labei=n. Presumably the height arrived at by the majority was accepted as correet.
th=s pli/nqou—collective; so in II. 9, 4 li/qois kai\ kera/mw|, cf. e. 74, 1, II. 76 ka/lamos. The meaning is that, having counted the layers, they found the height of the wall by multiplication.
oi)kodomh/sei—Thue. is partial to nouns in -sis: o)lo/fursis, cumme/trhsis, kata/feucis etc.
pro/s—‘on the side towards,’ an idiomatic use common with localities, pro\s tou= lime/nos, tou= potamou= and so on.

to\ ou)=n metacu\ tou=to—‘this intervening space was oceupied with buildings assigned as quarters to the sentries.’ So Stahl, who views to\ metacu/ as subjeet, and oi)kh/mata as internal accus., as in to\ e)nanti/on o)/noma metwno/mastai I. 122. Steup agrees with this rendering, but he is inelined to retain oi( e(kkai/deka po/des and he regards oi)kh/mata as pred. nom. Another view, which is to be rejected, is that to\ metacu\ tou=to is adverbial accus., ‘in this space,’ and oi)kh/mata subject of w)|kodo/mhto: the constr. is then very strained, and the perf. partic. dianenemhme/na unnatural, implying that the quarters were distributed before they were built.

h)=n cunexh=—I agree with Steup in rendering ‘it was (all) continuous,’ without any definite subject, as in I. 8 plwimw/tera e)ge/neto, and cf. II. 3 a(ma/cas . . e)s tou\s o(dou\s kaqi/stasan, i(/n' a)nti\ tei/xous h)=|, for it was not only the guards' quarters, but the two parallel walls as well that ‘looked like one thick wall.’
dia\ de/ka de\ e)pa/lcewn—‘at an interval of ten,’ i.e. with the plur., ‘at intervals of ten,’ as in Isoer. IV. 46 ai( panhgu/reis dia\ pollou= xro/nou sullegei=sai.
i)soplatei=s—cf. i)somhkh/s, i)sopaxh/s, i)soplhqh/s.

kai\ to\ e)/cw—for kai\ e)s to\ e)/cw, cf. c. 44 peri( tou= me/llontos ma=llon . . h)\ tou= paro/ntos. The first kai/, ‘and,’ is deleted by Herbst, but the predicative oi( au)toi/ can eome in the second clause.

para\ pu/rgon—Thuc. might have written para\ tou\s pu/rgous, but the art. is omitted and the sing used collectively as in II. 13 par' e)/palcin, for which we might have para\ ta\s e)pa/lceis. (This is better than ‘past a tower,’ because of di' au)tw=n.)
pareskeu/asto—impers., as often.
thrh/santes—cf. threi=n a)/nemon I. 65, t. porqmo/n (‘passage’) VI. 2.
ta/fron—between the town and the tei=xos. See Introd. p. xix.
prose/meican—‘reached.’

a)na/ occurs only twice in Thuc., here and IV. 72: with the temporal use here cf. Herod. VIII. 123 a)na\ to\n po/lemon tou=ton. “In the local sense espeeially, but also in the temporal, a)na/ frequently occurs in Homer and Herod. The constr. is eommon in Xenophon, but seems to oceur in no other Attic prose writer” (C. F. Smith).
yo/fw| depends on a)ntipatagou=ntos only, katakousa/ntwn being absolute, like proi+do/ntwn. The gen. abs., in spite of the aceus. (fu/lakas), is eommon in Gk.
mh/ belongs to both partic. and verb.
ai)/sqhsin pare/xoi—cf. II. 4 ai)/sqhsis taxei=a e)pege/neto.

to
 a)ristero
 mo/non po/da—instead of both feet, as would normally have been the case. The plain statement of Thuc. therefore is that by leaving off the right sandal the men expected to get a firmer footing in the mud. (The schol. says u(pede/dento to
 me
 e(/na tw=n podw=n di' a)sfa/leian, to
 de\ e(/teron gumno
 ei)=xon dia\ koufo/thta, and many edd. follow this view; but this is eertainly not what Thuc. says, and it is not a question of what we might think to be the effeet of sandals or no sandals. Thuc. took it that the right foot was meant to get the firmer hold.)

prose/misgon pro\s ta\s e)pa/lceis—I should prefer a comma at prose/misgon, because pro\s ta\s e)pa/lceis does not go closely with the verb, but is added to make kata\ metapu/rgion clear. (As Steup says, the towers had no battlements, so that pro\s ta\s e)pa/lceis does not refer to the wall as a whole. But there is no need to alter the text with him.)

meta\ de\ au)to\n . . a)ne/bainon—this still refers to the yiloi\ dw/deka, and merely repeats the previous a)ne/bainon with the addition of the intention of this party: on reaching the top they were to turn to left and right. The awkward repetition is due to the breaking of the thread of the previous sentence by the words kai\ prw=tos a)ne/bh.
a)ntilambano/menos is absolute.
dou=pon—as the rarer word this may be right, but yo/fon is an early variant.
boh/—‘an alarm.’
e)pi\ to\ tei=xos—the garrison troops came out and made for their posts at the wall. See Introd. p. xviii.
o(/ ti h)=n—contrast v. 54 h|dei de\ ou)dei\s o(/poi strateu/ousin. Goodwin, MT. § 674 3

kai\ a(/ma . . prose/balon—this gives another reason why they did not know o)/ ti h)=n to\ deino/n: hence strictly we should have kai\ o(/ti oi( ktl.: cf I. 110 tou=ton de\ dia\ me/geqo/s te tou= e(/lous ou)k e)du/nanto e(lei=n, kai\ a(/ma maximw/tatoi/ ei)si tw=n *ai)gupti/wn oi( e(/leioi.

tw=n *plataiw=n—partitive gen., which Thuc., differing from other authors, often puts between an art. and partic., as I. 9 oi( ta\ safe/stata *peloponnhsi/wn dedegme/noi, ib. 48 tai=s a)/rista tw=n new=n pleou/sais, and below, c. 36, 5.

e)k tou)/mpalin h)/—cf. tou)nanti/on h)/, which generally shows a variant reading h)=|. In Xen. Anab. III. 5, 13 ei)s tou)/mpalin h)\ pro\s *babulw=na is probably incorrect, but the text shows the idiom.

e)qorubou=nto me\n ou)=n—‘thus, remaining at their post (on the wall), they were in a state of excitement. yet not one dared to move from his own station, but they were at a loss to make out what was happening.’ e(autw=n goes back to the subject of e)qorubou=nto. e(autw=n here is to be preferred to au)tw=n: but in c. 91, 2 tou\s *mhli/ous ou)k e)qe/lontas e)s to\ au)tw=n cummaxiko\n i)e/nai e)bou/lonto prosagage/sqai, the pers. pron. may be right, since ipsorum, not suum may be meant.

e)xw/roun e)/cw tou= tei/xous—i.e. they descended from the wall on the outer side, supposing that the alarm meant that some force was approaching from Athens. In the darkness and excitement these 300 had not communicated with the men in the towers who had raised the alarm. 44 fruktoi\ pole/mioi—lampa/des polemi/ous dhlou=sai schol.

o(/pws a)safh= . . h)=| kai\ mh\ bohqoi=en—the timehonoured example of interchange of subj and opt after a past tense. Cf. VI. 96 e)ce/krinan o(/pws ei)/hsan fu/lakes kai\ . . . paragi/gnwntai, where no difference of meaning can be detected. See M.T. § 321. Analogous is the interchange of moods in c. 113, 2.

oi( d' u(perbai/nontes—all who were attempting to escape, whatever they were doing, are regarded as one body; but presently they are divided into oi( me/n, those already on the wall, and oi( de/, those who were still below. The result is a very ugly sentence. 4. e(kate/rou—see c. 22, 3.

ta/s te dio/dous—Steup, following Poppo, renders ‘and,’ making the parenthesis extend from w)s to e)pibohqei=n, because,
if te is regarded as correlative to kai/, the sense of ta/s te dio/dous . . e)pibohqei=n is absurdly repeated in ka/twqen (i.e. a)po\ tw=n dio/dwn) ei)=rgon. It will be noticed that, if e)fu/lasson mhde/na di' au)tw=n e)pibohqei=n were absent, the sentence would be perfectly iegular in outline: oi( d' u(perbai/nontes ta/s te dio/dous e)nsta/ntes kai\ kli/makas prosqe/ntes, oi( me\n kai\ ka/twqen (i.e. a)po\ tw=n dio/dwn) kai\ a)/nwqen (i.e. a)p' a)/krwn tw=n pu/rgwn) ei)=rgon ktl. I think that this is a sign, not that the interrupting words are spurious— they are quite in Thuc.'s manner—but that Thuc. wrote them without working out the sentence to its end, as if after plei/ous he had intended to continue, not with oi( me/n, but in the form a)po\ tw=n pu/rgwn tou\s e)pibohqou=ntas a)/nwqen ei)=rgon ba/llontes: on reaching plei/ous, he shifted his plan and as the general subject was to be kept up, bifurcated the sentenee with oi( me\n . . oi( de/, instead of making a separate sentence of the oi) de/ clause. This view of the matter is confirmed by the ugly repetition of kli/makas prosqe/ntes and plei/ous in different senses.
di' au)tw=n—coming from the other pu/rgoi through the passages to the metapu/rgion over which the P. were escaping.
plei/ous—as in c. 22, 4 init.
oi( me/n includes those in the di/odoi and those on the top of the pu/rgoi.
ka/twqen kai\ a)/nwqen—with ei)=rgon.
oi( d'—those who were at the foot of the wall.
ai)ei/—as Kruger says, this belongs to the partic, and the verb alike.
th=s ta/frou—for this outer trench see c. 24, 2.
para\ to\ tei=xos—‘by the wall,’ on the outside.
kwluth\s gi/gnoito—a favourite periphrasis with Thuc., especially with nouns in -ths; examples occur in ec. 2, 40, 58, 59; with dida/skalos c. 42; with h(gemw/n c. 105.
pa/ntes—meaning oi( plei/ous of § 1.

oi( teleutai=oi—best taken by itself, between commas, i.e. ‘as they were the last,’ like oi( d' . . oi( plei/ous above. But Steup makes oi( teleutai=oi partitive apposition to oi( . . pu/rgwn and joins xalepw=s oi( teleutai=oi k. The men on the towers waited till the rest were safely across.
ta\ gumna/—the unprotected side.
biai/ws—like biaio/teron a)nagago/menoi II. 33, ‘hard pressed.’

oi(=os a)phliw/tou—sc. o)/ntos, as in Soph. OC. 83 w(s
e)mou= mo/nhs pe/las, se. ou)/shs. It is very rarely that the partic. is omitted in gen. abs where the noun does not itself suggest a partie. as in Soph. OT. 966 w(=n u(fhghtw=n, sc. o)/ntwn: but the omission is softened in this case by the analogy of the gen. of time, as in nukto/s.

h)\ bore/ou—perhaps a marginal note, intended to fill up the sense of ma=llon. (It has been suggested (1) that bore/ou should be ehanged to eu)/rou, or (2) that ma=llon should be transposed before h)/.) But possibly two propositions are eompressed into one; and the full sense is ‘as it is when the wind is east: it is, in fact, more watery then than when the wind is north.’ (So Chambry, Rév. de phil. '97.)
u(poneifome/nh—ef. Herod II. 13 u(/etai h( xw/rh, Xen. Hell. II. 4, 13 neifo/menoi a)ph=lqon: for u(. is properly ‘being thinly besnowed.’

e)ge/neto . . h( dia/feucis—cf. VII. 41 th\n kata/feucin e)poiou=nto ‘were seeking refuge.’ The idea of success is contained in dia-. (I eannot agree with Classen that e)ge/neto here means ‘proved suceessful’: that sense is confined in Attic to old phrases like e)ge/neto ta\ i(era/, cf. e). ta\ diabath/ria V. 55. In VI. 74 and VIII. 57 gi/gnesqai=merely ‘take place.’ kai\ h( dia/feucis=‘the means of suecessful escape too (as well as the difficult crossing)’ was mainly owed to (i.e. more than to any other cause: meaning that it was a narrow thing).
dia\ tou= xeimw=nos to\ m.—the order as in Herod.; cf. e.g. I. 32 meta\ th=s cummaxi/as th=s ai)th/sews.
to\ tou= *)androkra/tous h(rw=|on—shrine of a Plataean ‘hero,’ a well-known landmark on the road, evidently in Plataean territory and not far from the Asopus. Introd. p. xix.

h(/kist' <a)/n>—after such words as ma/lista the accidental omission of a)/n is so frequent in some MSS. where the error is obvious that it seems unlikely that nomi/zw se poih=sai can= ‘I think you may do it.’ Cf. Xen. Oec. 11, 14 h(ni/ka for h(ni/k' a)/n, 18, 1 po/tera for po/ter' a)/n, Mem. IV. 3, 8 ma/lista for ma/list' a)/n, in whieh instances the verb, being in opt., betrays the error. In our passage if h(/kista is read, we should render ‘thinking that the enemy had not formed a suspicion.’
sfa=s—subjeet of trape/sqai.
pro\s *kiqairw=na kai\ *druo\s kefala/s—i.e. making for the pass of the Oak's Heads from which they would descend to Attica. For the roads see Introd. p. xix.

th\n pro\s to\ o)/ros—they turned SE. and crossed
Cithaeron at a point E. of the road taken by the enemy. It is not meant that they actually touched— *(usia/s t' *)eruqra/s q' ai(\ *kiqairw=nos le/pas ne/rqen katw|kh/kasin. (Eur. Bacchae, 751.)
pleio/nwn—c. 20, 2.

kata\ xw/ran e)ge/nonto—‘went to their station.’ kata\ xw/ran usually with me/nein (certa sede manet); with e)a=n Demosth. XXVII. 60. For gene/sqai kata/ ef. kaq' e(\n g. ‘to concentrate’; th\n xa/lazan eu)xo/menoi mh\ kaq' e(autou\s g. Demosth. IX. 33.
e)spe/ndonto—sponda\s e)zh/toun poiei=sqai schol. With the internal accus. a)nai/resin cf. c. 109 a)naxwrhsin e)spei/santo a)/pasi.
pleu/sas e)s *pu/rran kai\ e)c au)th=s pezh=|—two stages in the scheme by which dialaqw\n e)se/rxetai: and so pezh=| ‘by land’ is co-ordinated with pleu/sas, and is equivalent to pezh=| e)lqw/n.

h| u(perbato\n h)=n—edd. do not agree whether this means (1) that the ‘torrent-bed’ interrupted the Athenian wall, or (2) that the wall, though unbroken, was lower at this point. u(perbato/n hardly admits of (1). A third suggestion (3) is that u(pobato/n should be read, meaning that Salaethus crawled under the wall through an outlet. As for (2), if we eompare c. 18, 4-6, it seems strange that the A. should have been so simple as to leave the wall low at the xara/dra: but Thuc. has omitted some detail that would have made things clear—as he is apt to do. See Introd. p. XV.
proe/drois—toi=s a)/rxousi schol. For the
nh=es see c. 16.
proapopemfqh=nai/ te—cf. I. 87 ei)=pon o(/ti . . dokoi=en . ., bou/lesqai de\ . .
tou/twn e(/neka . . e)pimelhso/menos—cf. I. 80 e)mpeiri/a| . . nomi/santa.
pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous—from passages like V. 44 pro\s tou\s *)a. ma=llon ei)=xon th\n gnw/mhn it is clear that w(/ste cumbai/nein does not govern these words, but is an epexegesis.

du/o kai/ can hardly be right, as the number is repeatedly given as 40, e.g. cc. 25 and 29, and the suggestion that the two Lesbian triremes (cc. 4 and 5) are here ineluded is not probable. Rather than suppose that a eommentator wrongly added in the two Peloponnesian ships mentioned in cc. 5, 4 and 25, 1, I prefer to think we have a confusion as the outcome of mistaking m' (40) for b' (2).
a)/rxonta . . prosta/cantes is a phrase in Thuc. for appointment to a special command, and even the order is exactly as in VII. 19: so a)/rxonta for e)/xonta is a certain correction.
nau/arxos means that he held the annual office of high admiral.
a)mfote/rwqen—through the dispatch of the ships and the invasion.

tai=s nausi\n . . katapleou/sais—the transl. ‘send out a fleet against the ships sailing to M.’ is impossible, because (1) the partic. cannot be attributive unless nausi/n is placed after *mutilh/nhn, and (2) e)pibohqei=n+dat.=‘hasten to help.’ Hence either we must alter the text—Steup brackets katapleou/sais —or, better, render ‘when they were sailing.’ So Stahl refers tai=s n. katapleou/sais to the Athenians and renders ‘sail with their ships to M. and come to help,’ as if we had kataple/ontes.

Cleomenes and Pleistoanax were sons of the famous Pausanias. In 445 B.C., when Euboea and Megara revolted from Athens, Pleistoanax had invaded Attica, but had retreated when Pericles returned from Euboea: he was exiled for this, and his young son Pausanias reigned in his stead.
newte/rou ‘too young.’ The

de/ after patro/s is not justified by the constr., since no description of Cleomenes has preceded; hence Krüger suggests that e)pi/tropos has fallen out after e)/ti. There may, however, be a slight anacoluthon.
[kai\]—ei)/ ti e). is clearly added as an explanation to ta\ . . tetmhme/na.
meta\ th\n deute/ran—i.e. that of 430 B.C., see last n. on c. 1. The present invasion is the fourth.
e)pime/nontes—equivalent to prosdokw=ntes, hence fut. infin.: the aor. inf. in c. 2 expresses result, not expectation; cf. Soph. Trach. 1176 mh\ e)pimei=nai tou)mo\n o)cu=nai sto/ma.
e)pech=lqon with te/mnontes, ‘pressed forward with,’ not ‘over-ran.’
o(pli/zei—to make hoplites of them, the defensive armour, shield and breastplate, had to be distributed.
kata\ cullo/gous g.—these meetings were, of course, informal.
oi( e)n toi=s p.—oi( ta\ th=s po/lews pra/ttontes.
a)pokwlu/ein—the MSS. give fut., but the infin. after du/namai and its equivalents is prolate.

*)aqhnai/ois me/n—the conditions are stated in the loose
form frequently found in treaties, etc.: (1) two points in favour of the A. are connected; (2) some supply e)cei=nai to a/poste/llein, but it is better to make the latter depend directly on w(/ste; (3) dh=sai, ete. also depend on w(/ste.
e)n o(/sw|=me/xri ou(=, cf. e. 52, 3. It is a similar constr. to that in Tityre, dum redeo. Classen saw a combination of (1) e)n o(/sw| a)\n a)pw=si and (2) e(/ws a)\n pa/lin e)/lqwsi.

o(/mws—in spite of the guarantee; cf. c. 49, 1 n. (Vollgraff brackets as a dittography from bwmou/s.) kaqi/zein e)pi\ bwmo/n, a/nasth/sas (=a)nasth=nai pei/sas), and katati/qesqai e)s are technical in this connexion. With a)nasth/sas w)/ste mh\ a)dikh=sai cf. a)nasth/santes e)f' w)=| mhde\n kako\n poih/sousin I. 126.
me/xri ou(= without a)/n, as in Herod. (me/xri ou(= is not nsed in verse). M.T. § 620.
prosekth/sato—the common object, as usual, accommodated to the partic., pe/myas.

e)ndie/triyan—Steup thinks that we should read e)ndiatri/yantes or remove, mainly because tou\s me\n . . e(a/lwken gives the result of the slowness in both parts of the voyage; more prob. Thuc. would have written e)komi/sqhsan below, but altered the form of the sentence at that point to add the result of komisqe/ntes in lanqa/nousi tou(s *)aqhnai/ous—for the ships could not have been detected by the Athenians e)k th=s po/lews so long as they were on the Peloponnesian eoast (there was no Athenian fleet out there now).
tou\s me\n e)k th=s po/lews *)a.—those remaining at home in contrast with those at Lesbos. (The attempt to fix upon any definite fleet seems to be a mistake. Ships in port may, of course, be meant.)

pri\n dh\ th=| *dh/lw| e)/sxon—though no actual neg. precedes, the whole effect is neg.; cf. c. 104, and M.T. § 635. With the dat. constr., whieh is poetical, for e)s or kata/, cf. c. 5 au)toi=s . . a)fiknei=tai, (which is nearer to the dat. of interest), and c. 33, 4. After leaving Delos they had no fear of A. ships.
*)ika/rw| kai\ *muko/nw|—the goal ultimately reached is mentioned first, as not uncommonly.

h(me/rai de\ . . e(alwkui/a|—lit. ‘M. now reekoned seven days’; cf. I. 13, 4, Herod. II. 145 *(hrakle/i+ o(/sa fasi\ e)=nai e)/tea e)s *)/amasin, Xen. Hell. II. 1, 27 h(me/ra h)=n pe/mpth e)piple/ousi toi=s *aqhnai/ois. The insertion of ma/lista even with small numbers is a mannerism of Thuc.
e)k tw=n paro/ntwn—‘under the circumstances.’
w(/sper e)/xomen—‘as we are,’ without change of plan, here implying ‘at once,’ but not always so: the meaning implied depends on the context.
a)ndrw=n depends on to\ a)fu/lakton, equivalent to tw=n; the gen. with neut. adj. or partic. as noun is a common constr. with Thuc.
kai\ pa/nu—‘most certainly,’ ‘undoubtedly,’ as in II. 11 kai\ pa)nu e)lpi/zein: here in contrast with ei/ko\s de/ . .

kai\ h(mw=n h( a)lkh\ t. ma/lista ou)=sa—the version ‘where our strength chiefly lies’ is open to the objections (1) that the fleet was not stronger thau the Athenian fleet at Lesbos; that could not for a moment be maintained after Phormio's exploits; and (2) that the strength of the Pel. fleet, being unknown to A., could be no reason why there should be polu\ to\ a)fu/lakton on the part of the enemy. Another rendering is ‘where defence happens to be in the main our rôle,’ but I cannot find that a)lkh/ is ever used for ‘the defensive’ in opposition to ‘attack’; it means, on the contrary, ‘defence or resistance’ in opposition to ‘flight or submission’—something positive, not negative. In spite of the objections, the first rendering is prob. right; the reasoning that Thuc. puts into the mouth of speakers is not always exact: the strength of the Pel. is not intended to be compared with that of the A., and should have been referred to iu an independent sentence, but the love of antithesis has led to the connexion of e)kei=noi/ te . . kai\ h(mw=n. tugxa)nei ou)=sa marks the circumstance as unusual, and the real comparison is between the military aud naval strength of Alcidas.
w(s—‘conscious that.’
Reading

to\ kaino\n tou= pole/mou lit. ‘the strangeness of war is just this sort of thing’; i.e. the carelessness of the victor with the corollary of a sudden and wholly unexpected attack. In fula/ssoito and e)norw=n only the carelessness of the victor is kept in view, but that the corollary is included in to\ toiou=ton is proved (1) by the vague inclusive pron. in place of tou=to, (2) by to\ kaino/n, which could not mean to\ a)fu/lakton merely, but must include to\ a)prosdo/khton. (Steup conjectures to\ koino/n, ‘where war shows itself notoriously impartial’: this makes the sentence easier to understand, but I do not think kaino/n impossible Many edd. see in to\ kaino/n a reference only to sudden attack—to\ prospesei=n a)/fnw. I do not understand how kai\ toi=s polemi/ois e)norw=n can be explained on this view. to\ keno/n, ‘the vanity,’ is as tolerable as to\ kaino/n in itself, but is more likely to be a mistake for to\ kaino/n than vice versa.)
o(/—governed by fula/ssoito and e)norw=n, or perhaps—in strictness—au)to/ is supplied from it to e)norw=n, for the position of te does not make this impossible.
oi( *le/sbioi—for these see cc. 4, 4, 5, 4.
e)lpi/da d' ei=nai—sc. a)posth=sai.
a)kousi/ws—i.e. ‘no one was unwilling to see them come,’ the adverb applying to ou)deni/, not to the subject of a)fi=xqai: cf. Soph. Antig. 70 e)mou= g' a)\n h(de/ws (sc. e)moi\) drw/|hs me/ta.

kai\ th\n pro/sodon . . u(fe/lwsi—parallel to a)posth/swsin, ‘(that) they might gradually draw away this which was the main source of A. revenue.’ Not ‘one of the chief sources’; and the position of tau/thn renders a second th/n unnecessary. The fo/ros from the Carian and Ionian cities is meant; they had been grouped together and treated as one since 436 B.C., and the lists in CIA. vol. i. show that this combined fo/ros was the largest item in the Athenian pro/sodoi. (h)\n before u(fe/lwsi can scarcely be right: the loss of the fo/ros would be the necessary outcome of the revolt of Ionia, and could hardly be stated as an independent condition of what follows, however that be understood.)

kai\ a)/ma . . . dapa/nh gi/gnhtai—‘and at the same time, in case the Athenians should blockade them (in the Ionian port), the Athenians might be put to expense.’ (A majority of MSS. gives h)\n e)formw=sin au)toi=s—or au)tou\s—dapa/nh sfi/si gi/gnhtai, i.e. ‘if the Peloponnesians should blockade the Athenians, they (the Pel.) might have a fund to draw on, viz. the fo/ros.’ The objections to this are, as I think, (a) h)\n e)formw=sin au)toi=s is too vague: surely the Lesbians and Ionians cannot be thinking here of a blockade of the Attic coast—c. 15, 1 —and an undertaking of such magnitude—see c. 16, 1— could not possibly be suggested in this casual way—and the alternative explanation, that the proposal is that Alcidas shall ‘maintain a squadron of observation in Ionian waters,’ with a victorious Athenian fleet of equal numbers at Mytilene—cf. especially c. 33, 1—is out of the question. (b) It is true that dapa/nh can mean ‘money for spending,’ where the context makes the drift clear, but it is hardly possible that dapa/nh tini\ gi/gnetai can mean anything but dapana=tai u(po/ tinos, according to the idiom; and there is force in Kruger's remark that the previous sentence here decidedly suggests the idea of ‘loss.’)

*pissou/qnhn—Ionia and Caria were included in his satrapy. As Persia claimed and did not receive tribute from
the Greek cities, it was by no means unlikely that the satrap might be induced to aid the enemies of Athens.
to\ plei=ston th=s gnw/mhs ei)=xe—‘strongly inclined to,’ ‘regarded it as decidedly best,’ like the Herodotean plei=stos gnw/mhn ei)mi/.
*mutilh/nhs u(sterh/kei—‘too late for’ means here ‘too late to help,’ as in Xen. Ages 2, 1 w(s u(sterh/seie th=s patri/dos.
pare/plei—down the coast of Ionia.
e)s th\n *)/efeson—though part of the Athenian empire, E. could not hinder the fleet from entering the harbour.
*sami/wn—the Samian exiled oligarchs living on the coast opposite Samos; cf. c. 19.

ou) kalw=s th\n *(ella/da e)leuqerou=n—that she was the Liberator of Greece was the claim of Sparta in the war, her a)ci/wsis th=s a)reth=s (I. 69). The most striking comment on this claim comes in Xen. Hel, III. 5, 13, in the speech of a Theban at Athens thirty years after this time: ou(\s u(mw=n a)pe/sthsan faneroi/ ei)sin e/chpathko/tes: a)nti\ ga\r e)leuqeri/as diplh=n au)toi=s doulei/an paresxh/kasin.
ei) die/fqeiren—(1) ei) in the sense of o(/ti or e)pei/, (2) for die/fqeiren, where we expect diafqei/rei, see M. T. § 691.
xei=ras a)ntairome/nous—so Herod, VII. 209, Xen. Cyr. V. 4, 26 e)a)n tis o(/pla a)ntai/rhtai/ soi.
o(rw=ntes ga/r—showing how it came that Alcidas had so many prisoners. The connexion is a little loose.
mh\ . . parabalei=n—the inf. appears to be fut,; the mh/ is produced by the preceding neg. and might have been omitted; the constr. is unusual. paraba/llw intrans., as with dia-, e)s-, etc.
w)/fqh—pluperf. in sense; he must have touched at Clarus while sailing from Embaton to Ephesus.
*salamini/as kai\ *para/lou—for the two state triremes see a dict. of antiquities.
th=s *)eruqrai/as—see c. 29.
kai\ w(/s—although, by the defenceless condition of Ionia, it was easy to stay.
a(/ma with reference to paraple/ontes.
au)ta/ggeloi de/—it is better, with Classen, to regard a)teixi/stou . . po/leis as a parenthesis, and this sentence as a direct continuation from kai\ pantaxo/qen.

ou)ke/ti e)n katalh/yei e)fai/neto—sc. o( *)alki/das, ‘was clearly no longer to be caught’; cf. VI. 60 w(s ou)k e)n pau/lh| e)fai/neto (to\ pra=gma). (I do not venture to disturb this traditional explanation; but I think it possible that Paches is the subject of e)fai/neto, and that e)n k. e). means ‘was clearly likely to catch him’; cf. c. 15 e)n karpou= cugkomidh=| h)=san.)
metew/rois—sc. tai=s *)alki/dou nausi/n.

ou)damou= e)gkatalhfqei=sai . . parasxei=n—‘they were not caught any where and (so) compelled to entrench themselves and to cause the Athenians the trouble of guarding and blockading them.’ For pare/xein with words denoting trouble cf. VII. 70 e)/kplhci/n te kai\ a)poste/rhsin th=s a)koh=s pare/xein, and pra/gmata p.
pa/lin—‘back,’ see e)panexw/rei, ‘turned back,’ above.

katw/|khnto—cf. I. 120 e)n po/rw| katw|khme/nous. Thuc. uses the mid. forms only in the perf. and pluperf.; so Herod. Notium was the port of Colophon. Aristotle tells us that Colophon and Notium were not well suited to form a single state: hence sta/sis. It was an exaggerated case, he says, of Athens and the Piraeus; and the Piraeus is more democratic than the city. Now Colophon had been under an oligarchy of the rich; and at the beginning of the Peloponnesian war, this oligarchy, it appears, wanted to get the city out of the hands of Athens, and invited in the ‘barbarians,’ favouring, apparently, reunion with Persia. The majority migrated to Notium, but a fresh sta/sis broke out, and one party got help from the satrap Pissuthnes and was joined by the oligarchs from Colophon. The expelled democrats now sought aid from Paches. (We do not know who Itamanes was.) kata\ sta/sin i)di/an—i)di/an cannot mean ‘intestine,’ and i)di/a|, ‘by one of the parties,’ is very probable; cf. c. 2 It is possible, however, that i)di/an means ‘confined to Colophon,’ not extending to Notium
ma/lista—‘about.’ The date is 430 B.C.
oi( me\n . . oi( de/—partitive apposition.
