e)pikou/rous *)arka/dwn—i.e. Arcadian misqofo/roi. They served as mercenaries already in the Persian wars, and are familiar as such in the expedition of the Ten Thousand. The mercenaries must have been in the service of Pissuthnes.

e)n diateixi/smati—a place divided by a wall from the rest of the town. diateixi/zein is ‘to separate by a wall.’ With the force from Pissuthnes came also the pro-Persian party from Colophon, which was now part of the citizen body cf Notium.
u(pecelqo/ntes tou/tous—for the accus. Kiuger quotes Eurip. frag. Alcmene o(/mws a)gw=na to/nde dei= m' u(pekdramei=n.
tw=n: the MS. to\n is a form of mistake that is frequent in similar passages in MSS. of Xenophon.

o( me/n after prokalesa/menos involves an anacoluthon, like that of Il. VI. 509 o( d' a)glai/hfi pepoiqw\s | r(i/mfa e) gou=na fe/rei; but it is not usual in Homer. Here we have a sing. nom. followed by two contrasted subjects. For the opposite form, a plur. nom. followed by only one subject, cf. Il. III. 211 a)/mfw d' e(zome/nw gerarw/teros h)=en *)odusseu/s.
prosdexome/nwn—the subst. to be supplied, as in I. 3 e)pagome/nwn au)tou/s, II. 52 e)napoqnh|sko/ntwn (sc. a)nqrw/pwn). Cf. c. 55, 1.
oi)kista/s—the ‘oecists’ or ‘founders’ settled the government and started the new colony, as was usual. Cf. VI. 5 oi)kisth\s geno/menos katw/|kise *kama/rinan.
As regards Pyrrha and Eresus see c. 18. For Salaethus see c. 25. For the Mytilenaeans in Tenedos, c. 28.
toi=s de\ loipoi=s—the dat. of accompaniment, frequent with words like strato/s and nau=s.
parexo/menon—‘propose,’ ‘put forward.’
gnw/mas e)poiou=nto—‘offered various opinions’ or ‘made proposals,’ in the Assembly, of course.

e)pikalou=ntes—anacoluthon, as though a personal constr. had preceded. Cf. II. 53 qew=n fo/bos ou)dei\s a)pei=rge, to\ me\n kri/nontes, VI. 24 e)/rws e/ne/pese . . eu)elpi/des o)/ntes, Eur. Hec. 971 ai)dw/s m' e)/xei . . tugxa/nousa.

th/n te a)/llhn . . kai\ proscunela/bonto—(1) they reproached them with revolting under specially grave circumstances, ou)k a)rxo/menoi; (2) their rage was largely due to the appearance of a Pel. fleet on the Ionian coast. As the sentence stands it is illogical, since th/n te a)/llhn should be followed by something like kai\ o(/ti ta\s nau=s e)phga)gonto. (As to Classen's insertion of kai/ after a)po/stasin—on whieh there has been some subtle argument—we may regard it as possible, but scarcely necessary.) For the change from partic. to finite verb cf. V. 61 boulo/menoi a)/llws te . . kai\ o(/mhroi h)=san. It is frequent in Herod.
proscunela/bonto—for this reading ef. IV. 47 cunela/bonto tou= toiou/tou ou)x h(/kista oi( strathgoi\ kata)dhloi o)/ntes. The emphasis is, of course, on the partic. (tolmh/sasai), as often.

ou)k e)la/xiston is adverbial. The other reading, proscuneba/leto,
‘contributed,’ to\ e). (sc. me/ros) th=s o(rmh=s being object,—cf. Ath. Pol. 19 suneba/lleto ou)k e/la/ttw moi=ran th=s o(rmh=s—is defended by IV. 25 ai)/tion de\ h)=n oi( *lakedaimo/nioi proeipo/ntes and VIII. 9 ai)/tion de\ e)ge)neto . . oi\ polloi\ ou)k ei)do/tes, but the present instance goes further.
ou) ga\r a)po\ braxei/as dianoi/as—‘it was no small design, they thought, that had led them to revolt,’ viz. the design of bringing about a revolt of Ionia with the aid of the Pel. fleet.
a)/ggelon—pred. to trih/rh.
meta/noia/ tis—tis is often added thus to words expressing feelings that rise half involuntarily, as with r(w/mh, o)/knos, kath/feia (‘dejection’), feidw/ (‘reluctance’).

w)mo\n . . ai)ti/ous—in the tragic style, and unusually rhythmical for Thuc. (pe/feuge to\ ei)=dos, says Hermogenes): the sentence breaks into two corresponding halves after po/lin, me/ga being elided and h)\ ou), of course, counting as one long. ma=llon h)\ ou)—h)/ implies a negative, and any sentence implying a neg. is apt to be strengthened by an expressed neg. (M.T. § 815): cf. II. 62 ou)d' ei)ko\s xalepw=s fe/rein ma=llon h)\ ou) . . o)ligwrh=sai.
pre/sbeis—c. 28.
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn—the order as in c. 22, 5.
pareskeu/asan — ‘got them to.’
oi( e)n te/lei are the ‘government,’ i.e., presumably, the Strategi, who, in time of war, could have a special meeting of the Ecclesia summoned.

au)=qis gnw/mas proqei=nai—‘allow a fresh debate’: to re-open a matter that had been settled in a recent meeting of the Ecclesia seems to have rendered the person responsible to impeachment; but the Ecclesia, as the sovereign power, could by a majority of course do anything, provided that the Prytanies and the president of the meeting consented to submit a proposal for discussion. (The evidence on the point is doubtful; but the account here given reconciles the various passages that bear on it.)
e)/ndhlon h)=n—the personal constr., esp. common with dh=los.

tinas—‘persons’: after tou\s e)n te/lei we should expect au)tou/s; but the speakers, rather than the officials, are referred to A special Assembly (su/gklhtos e)kklhsi/a) was summoned for the purpose. (G. Gilbert, B. zur innern Geschichte Athens, 142, assigns the debates on Mytilene to the end of the official year
428-7. It is probable that Cleon was in that year Strategus, having replaced Lysicles the probatopw/lhs, who had been killed in Caria in the winter. Busolt, however, places the debates in the first prytany of the following year, 427-6, wheu Cleon and those like him were replaced in the strategia by Nicias and Laches, men strongly opposed to Cleon. In either case, it is obvious that party-feeling must have run very high just at this time.
th\n prote/ran—sc. gnw/mhn, ‘proposal,’ from gnw=mai above:

nika=n is ‘to carry,’ as in nika=| e(/teron yh/fisma *filokra)ths, Aeschin, III. 63. (I do not think that the sense of gnw/mh shifts here from ‘views’ to ‘decree,’ and that consequently th=| prote/ra| ‘on the previous day’ should be read.)

biaio/tatos—this is the first time that Thuc. mentions Cleon, though he had been rising for some time. The views of him expressed by ancient authors, whether as politician or as orator, are almost uniformly unfavourable. As regards Thuc.'s opinion of him, and the following speech, see Introd. p. xxxvii.
dhmokrati/an—object of e)/gnwn, but in sense subj. of a)/rxein. a)du/naton, ‘incapable of,’ the neut. as in Homer's ou)k a)gaqo\n polukoirani/h.
e)n—of the cause.
a)dee\s kai\ a)nepibou/leuton give the same thing from two sides: you neither fear your neighbour nor cause him to fear you.

o(/ ti a)\n . . a(ma/rthte h)\ . . e)ndw=te—we know too little of the working of the Athenian empire to specify acts of clemency on the part of Athens. From what we do know we should say that Athens was severe enough; but we must remember that the standard of the times was very different from ours: any right that Athens did not take from her allies she regarded as a privilege granted to them.
oi)/ktw| is parallel to lo/gw| peisqe/ntes; supply au)toi=s to e)ndw=te.
e)pikindu/nws . . e)s u(ma=s—the emphasis is on this: hence the disloeation of the order. Tr. ‘you think that such weakness does not . . bring danger to you.’
ou)k e)s th\n . . xa/rin—‘without gaining the gratitude’; they take a concession as a sign of weakness.
turanni/da e)/xete th\n a)rxh/n—repeating words attributed to Pericles at II. 63.
kai\ pro\s . . a)rxome/nous—paralleI to turanni/da, the constr. with pro/s (after a)rxh/) like fili/a or po/lemos pro/s.

oi(/—very weakly supported by MS. evidence. There is a similar case at IV. 10, where the MSS. give to\ duse/mbaton h(me/teron nomi/zw: meno/ntwn me\n h(mw=n cu/mmaxon gi/gnetai, but Dionysius quotes the passage with o(\ meno/ntwn etc. Without the rel., we must assume an epexegesis of a)/kontas a)rxome/nous with asyndeton.

e)c w(=n . . perige/nhsqe—for e)c e)kei/nwn a)/, internal accus. to p., ‘as a consequence of the superiority you have established over them by strength (hinting at the successive reductions to the status of tributary subjects) and not by their willing obedience.’
eu)/noia as Arist. Eth. IX. 5, 3 says, di' a)reth\n kai\ e)piei/keia/n tina gi/netai, o(/tan tw| fanh=| kalo/s tis h)\ a)ndrei=os.

w(=n a)
 do/ch| pe/ri—for peri\ e)kei/nwn a(\ a(
 do/ch|, ‘as regards measures that we have passed.’ Thus the neut. nom. a(/ is here attracted as in VII. 67 bla/ptesqai a)f' w(=n h(mi=n pareskeu/astai. In (a(\) a)
 do/ch| the allusion is to yhfi/smata passed in the Ecclesia.

xei/rosi no/mois . . a)ku/rois—it has been thought that there is an allusion here to definite no/moi that forbade a psephism to be reconsidered, perhaps within some fixed period (cf. n. on c. 36, 5); but the reference seems more general. (The objection that Cleon would, if there were such an allnsion, definitely threaten a grafh\ parano/mwn has not much force, for (1) Thuc. does not deal in the technicalities of Attic legal procedure, which were not of sufficiently ‘universal’ interest for him, with his view of history; and (2) in VI. 14 sqq., where Nicias alludes to some rules about the re-discussion of a psephism, Alcibiades, in his rejoinder, makes no capital out of the rules at all—does not even allude to the point.) Arnold thought that the psephism under revision is itself meant under no/moi, and that the confusion is meant to be intentional on Cleon's part. It is best, I think, to consider the passage intentionally vague and rhetorical: revision of psephisms leads easily to revision of laws in a democracy. This general application is borne out by a)maqi/a te ktl., which would be an odd addition to a clause containing a precise reference.

krei/sswn e)sti/n—the personal constr.: ‘it is better for a state to have.’ (This explanation is strongly supported by w)felimw/teron (sc. po/lei) and a)/meinon oi)kou=si ta\s po/leis. Classen says ‘is stronger’; but the point is what is good for a state, not what a state can do.)

a)maqi/a meta\ swfrosu/nhs—‘ignorance when combined with self-restraint,’ no doubt a hit at the pepaideume/noi, and the sentiment so outrageous to an educated Athenian, that we
must assume that it was really uttered by Cleon in substance. For the evil results of a)maqi/a note the following passage (Euripides, frag.): gnw/mais ga a)ndro\s eu)= me
 oi)kou=ntai po/leis eu)= d' oi)=kos, ei)/s t' au)= po/lemon i)sxu/ei me/ga: sofo
 ga e(
 bou/leuma ta\s polla\s xe/ras nika=| su
 o)/xlw| d' a)maqi/a plei=ston kako/n. swfrosu/nh and a)kolasi/a are often contrasted in the language of popular philosophy: eu(rh/sete th
 me
 a)kolasi/an . . tw=n kakw=n ai)ti/an gignome/nhn, th
 de\ swfrosu/nhn tw=n a)gaqw=n, Isocr. de pace § 119. In oi(/ te faulo/teroi ktl. we meet a sentiment that is frequent in Euripides.
pro/s—‘as compared with.’
tw=n te no/mwn sofw/teroi—hence they despise the laws: a reference back to mhde\ gnwso/meqa etc.

tw=n te ai)ei\ . . perigi/gnesqai—the te . . te puts the contempt for laws and the opposition to all counsel on the same footing as joint parts of their conduct. perigi/gnesqai, ‘to get the better’ of it, by opposing it.

w(s e)n a)/llois mei/zosin . . gnw/mhn—‘as though they could not find any greater subject on which to display their talent’; the subject in debate is just the one, they think, on which they are qualified to give an opinion. (Cf. VII. 64 ou)k a)\n e)n a)/llw| ma=llon kairw=| a)podeica)menos.)

a)dunatw/teroi de\ . . lo/gon—in form exactly parallel to the preceding clause; but tou= kalw=s ei)po/ntos is certainly possessive gen. to lo/gon, together with which it refers to tw=n ai)ei\ legome/nwn e)s to\ koino/n above. To a)dunatw/teroi supply h)\ oi( cunetw/teroi.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou—‘fair,’ free from personal bias, cf. c. 42; more often ‘on equal terms.’ For a)gwnisth/s as a ‘rhetorical prize-fighter,’ Bloomfield cites several exx. 34

o)rqou=ntai—‘have a prosperous course’; cf. particularly II. 60 po/lin o)rqoume/nhn )( sfallome/nhn. Here o)rqou=ntai ta\ plei/w corresponds to polla\ sfa/llousi ta\s po/leis above. There is an exactly similar passage in Soph. Antig. 673-6. (The rendering ‘judge rightly’ is certainly wrong.)
w(/s—for ou(/tws, usually only with kai/, ou)de/, mhde/, in prose.

para\ do/can—‘contrary to our opinion,’ not, as in the other cases in Thuc., ‘unexpectedly.’ (The conjecture para\ to\
do/can, ‘contrary to what has been decided,’ is plausible; but I agree with Bloomfield that this is not really in point here: it is not borne out by tw=n ai)ei\ legome/nwn . . perigi/gnesqai and tou= kalw=s ei\po/ntos me/myasqai lo/gon.)
l. 1. e)gw\ me\n o( au)to/s ei)mi th=| gnw/mh|—similar words are attributed to Pericles, II. 61.
a)mblute/ra|—‘with anger more dulled,’ when there is delay.

a)mu/nesqai—for (to\) a)mu/nesqai as in Aesch. Ag. 191 par' a)/kontas h)=lqe swfronei=n, and elsewhere in Thuc. The addition of kei/menon (and perhaps o)/n) makes the omission ugly and unusual. Cf. the schol. ei/ to\ a)mu/nesqai tw=| paqei=n e)ggu\s teqei/h.

a)nti/palon o)
 . . a)nalamba/nei—‘is most adequate when it recovers satisfaction’: the main emphasis on the partic., as often. If o)/n is omitted, a)nti/palon agrees with timwri/an—cf. a)mblute/ra| th=| o)rgh=| above—and both form and sense are improved. (Hude reads tou= paqei=n, takes kei/menon as accus. abs., ‘when it is proposed to take vengeance,’ and makes o( paqw/n subj. of a)nalamba/nei, omitting o)/n with Haase. But what is the point of saying kei/menon a)mu/nesqai where the sense calls for a)muno/menos?) Some think a
alamba/nei should be lamba/nei or a)
 lamba/noi, as in di/khn, timwri/an, lamba/nein.

qauma/zw de/.—there might be reason in opposing the vote, if it were shown that either (1) the revolt is advantageous to Athens; or (2) though troublesome to us, it is indirectly a gain because it does harm to the allies and renders them less an object of fear to us.

to\ pa/nu dokou=n—‘the universal opinion of men’: he must try to prove a paradox. (According to another view, the allusion is to the psephism. But (1) to\ pa/nu dokou=n, ‘what is generally agreed upon,’ would hardly be a true description of the vote; and (2) to\ do/can would certainly be natural.)
ke/rdei—a suggestion of bribery: the charge was a common one against public men, and was often true. The contrast in
h)\ . . h)/ is between an opponent who wants to show his skill in oratory and one who is bribed to mislead.
e)kponh/: sas is co-ordinate with pisteu/sas, and e)pairo/menos gives the motive that prompts him e)kponei=n.

to\ eu)prepe\s tou= lo/gou—‘what is plausible in the words.’ The whole of this section is a hit at the bad side of the new rhetoric: it is piquant, because Cleon himself indulges in
rhetoric freely; this elaborate comparison to an a)gw/n of rival rhetoricians is itself full of it.

qeatai\ me\n . . e)/rgwn—‘spectators of words and hearers of deeds’ is an artificial way of saying: you are content to take the facts from what the orators say, and look on at the debates, thus inverting the natural order of things at an a)gw/n, in which one would watch the athletes' deeds and listen to the literary men's words: so badly do you, who are at once the directors and the people attending, manage the a)gw=nes. (The explanations usually given of this passage do not seem to me to give an intelligible meaning to the whole: (a) kakw=s a)gwnoqetei=n does not mean ‘to be wrong in instituting a contest,’ but ‘to do so in the wrong way’; cf. the second and third failings—a)pata=sqai a)/ristoi and zhtou=ntes a)/llo te ktl.: all indicative of a topsy-turvy mind and (b) only with the latter meaning—which is a natural one—does oi(/tines ktl. given an intelligible reason.)
w(s dunata\ gi/gnesqai—‘as practicable’: sc. o)/nta, cf. VI. 40 tou\s lo/gous w(s e)/rga duname/nous krinei=.
ta\ de\ p. h)/dh—sc. skopou=ntes.

ou) to\ . . a)kousqe/n ‘not taking what has been done as more trustworthy through having seen it, than what you have heard (about it).’ (It has been objected to o)/yei that we need a)kroa/sei or a)koh=| to contrast with it; but the whole clause corresponds to w(s dunata\ gi/gnesqai, and = w(s to\ a)kousqe\n pisto/teron o)\n h)\ to\ o)fqe/n; to\ a)kousqe/n itself contains the contrast to o)/yei: instead of saying to\ o)fqe/n, Thuc. says to\ drasqe/n in order to introduce again the contrast between e)/rga and lo/goi —drasqe/n and a)kousqe/n.)
e)pitimhsa/ntwn—the readiness of speakers to criticize adversely the action of public men, if opponents, is often insisted on; but it is odd that Cleon, who was ever ready to censure, should talk so.
meta\ kaino/thtos—equivalent to a dat, of cause, as I. 32 mh\ meta\ kaki/as, do/chs de\ ma=llon a(marti/a|: cf. c. 42, 1.

a)pata=sqai a)/ristoi— sc. o)/ntes, co-ordinate with kakw=s a)gwnoqetou=ntes, the second way in which you are ai)/tioi: eu)para)gwgos ei)=, qwpeuo/meno/s te xai/reis ka)capatw/menos, Aristoph. Eq. 1115.

meta\ dedokimasme/nou—sc. lo/gou, ‘when an approved argument is stated’; cune/pesqai means ‘go with the speaker.’ (Another way is to take cune/pesqai meta/ closely together, ‘to follow the lead of’: I prefer the former.)
dou=loi o)/ntes—the whole down to a)pobhso/mena is epexegetic of a)/ristoi (o)/ntes).
kai\ ma/lista me/n—co-ordinate with dou=loi o)/ntes. boulo/menoi would have made the sentence more symmetrical, but cf. already Iliad IX. 656 oi( de\ e(/kastos e(lw\n . . i)/san.

a)ntagwnizo/menoi toi=s toiau=ta le/gousi—i.e. toi=s toiou/tois r(h/torsi, who applaud that one of their number who happens to be speaking; ‘vying with speakers who use such arguments,’ viz. a)/topa. (It is objected to toiau=ta that it cannot be referred to ta\ a)/topa only, after what has preceded. But it is to be noted that u(pero/ptai de\ tw=n ei)wqo/twn is merely parenthetical: had there been a me/n after dou=loi, the objection would have been serious.)

th=| gnw/mh|—not to lag behind the rest ‘in insight.’ To understand ‘plan’ or ‘purpose’ of the speaker (gnw/mh| governed by a)kolouqh=sai) is not so good, because it is the external form, not the meaning, that rivets their attention.

o)ce/ws with le/gontos, because le/gonto/s ti cannot here mean ‘says something important or sensible.’ On the other hand, o)ce/ws, when taken with le/gontos, is rendered ‘shrewdly,’ ‘cleverly’; but (1) o)cu/, adj., would be natural, and (2) it seems that le/gein o)ce/ws means not ‘speak shrewdly’ but ‘speak rapidly’; it is only with words denoting mind that bradu/s, o)cu/s mean ‘slow,’ ‘quick’ of wit. I should prefer to render ‘when any one is speaking rapidly.’
proepaive/sai — sc. dokei=n, generally understood ‘to approve’ it before it is uttered, but perhaps ‘to be first with their approval.’

pro/qumoi ei)=nai—this may depend on a)ntaywnizo/menoi or, more probably, on dokei=n, but, in either ease, (ei)=nai) bradei=s does not give very good sense, and can hardly be excused on the ground that the main emphasis falls on pro/qumoi ei)=nai; for—to mention only one objection—proaisqe/sqai and pronoh=sai are plainly meant to be equal in importance. We require ei)wqo/tes to make sound sense. The best solution proposed is to consider kai/ before proaisqe/sqai and ei)=nai as spurious: the whole would then be closely connected with proepaine/sai.
zhtou=nte/s te—again going back to ai)/tioi d' u(mei=s, ‘seeking something different—one might almost say— from the world in which we live;’ dreamers.
a(plw=s te—a resumption of the substance of the whole sentence.
sofistw=n qeatai=s kaqhme/nois—‘men sitting as spectators at a display of sophists,’ as shown in the Protagoras, for example.
w(=n—neut. (
qeatai=s is pred.; but as the comparison is between qeatai/ and bouleuo/menoi, kaqhme/nois is possibly, as Lincke says, interpolated.)
mi/an po/lin—cf. c. 113, 6.
oi(/tines—the dat. antecedent omitted. Distinguish between oi(/tines mh/ and oi(/tines ou) below.

nh=son . . meta\ teixw=n—thus secure against enemies. The contrast to the previous sentence is stated in inverse order: subjection—compulsion; security—freedom. This is a common arrangement of clauses in Thuc.
e)n w|—of their condition.
kai\ au)toi/—independently of our help.

e)pane/sthsan ma=llon h)\ a)pe/sthsan—an armed rising contrasted with a secession; but the application of the contrast to the circumstances of Lesbos is not exact, since e)pana/stasis implies a dominant power, which Athens ex hypothesi was not.

me/n ge—‘secession anyhow,’ whatever be the truth about e)pana/stasis. For the suppression of the de/-clause after this combination cf. Aristoph. Ach. 154 tou=to me/n g' h)/dh safe/s. (Append. i., Neil, Aristoph. Equites).
bi/aio/n ti pasxo/ntwn—this is far-fetched; and the implied contrast about e)pana/stasis would too obviously not hold: hence the statement of it is suppressed.
kai/toi—‘surely.’
kaq' au(tou/s—‘by themselves,’ not meta\ tw=n polemiwta/twn sta/ntes.
ktw/menoi—probably conative.

para/deigma de\ au)toi=s—as para/deigma means example, both as a warning and as an encouragement, it might have been applied to both clauses with ou)/te; but the second has taken an independent form, cf. c. 96, 3.
tw=n pe/las—‘of others.’
ta\ deina/—often of the dangers of war.
to\ me/llon—‘the future’ )( parou=sa.

makro/tera . . boulh/sews—‘having come to hope for
what was beyond their strength, but less than their ambition.’ Clearly what they hoped for was the destruction of Athenian power—e)zh/thsan h(ma=s diafqei=rai. But how was this ‘less than they wanted’? what more could they want? Probably we have here a sample of Cleon's exaggeration and abuse, and no definite meaning is to be looked for. It is enough for his purpose that the Lesbians had wanted to revolt sooner than they did (c. 2). (Herbst's explanation, Zu Thuk. p. 82, that makro/tera means the power of Mytilene, and e)la/ssw that of Athens, seems far-fetched, and his rendering of th=s boulh/sews is scarcely intelligible.)
e)n w)=|—‘the moment that.’
ga/r—justifying the charge that they put might before right. They had suffered no wrong, and they chose a time when Athens was in difficulties.

ai(=s a)\n . . e)/lqh|—the clause forms the object to tre/pein. ma/lista kai\ di' e)laxi/stou, ‘most fully and most suddenly,’ refers to the moment just alluded to in e)n w(=| w)|h/qhsan; it was kairo\s w(s ou)/pw pro/teron, c. 13, 3. The revolt was not really the unpremeditated thing that Cleon represents it to have been. The

a)prosdo/khtos eu)praci/a refers to the difficulties in which Athens was. (The objection to di' e)laxi/stou that the change of fortune on the part of the Mytilenaeans was not sudden, but was gradually brought about by the events of the war, rests on a confusion of facts and the rhetorical presentment of them.)

ta\ de\ polla\ . . eu)tuxou=nta a)sfale/stera—‘in most things prosperity according to calculation is safer than prosperity that is a surprise.’ It is an extraordinary explanation that makes ta\ polla/, after the schol., adverbial accus., and kata\ l. eu)tuxou=nta equivalent to ta\ . . eu)tuxou=nta. The constr. intended is clearly a)sfale/stera/ (e)sti) ta\ polla\ eu)tuxou=nta=ei) eu)tuxei=: cf. II. 13 (e)/fh) ta\ polla\ kratei=sqai. And there is no doubt about the reading being right: eu)tuxi/a, a stable condition, is in contrast with eu)praci/a. a single event (cf. I. 33); a calm life unmarred by misfortune constituted eu)tuxi/a (cf. II. 44). Of course para\ do/can (eu)tuxou=nta) gives a different and paradoxical meaning to eu)tuxi/a. This doctrine of Cleon seems to be based upon the philosophy of life professed by his opponent Nicias. Cf. V. 16, of Nicias, diasw/sasqai th\n eu)tuxi/an.
w(s ei)pei=n r(a=|on—‘almost more easily.’

xrh=n de/—they would never have gone so far in
their indulgence in u(/bris had we long ago kept a tighter hand on them.

mhde\n diafero/ntws tw=n a)/llwn—the adverb (EM) is better than diafe/rontas, and has, at any rate, as much MS. support as xrh=n just before, and it has, in addition, the support of the text of the schol. and of Dio Cassins.
kai\ a)/llws — ‘in other cases as well,’ making the application general.
toi=s me\n o)li/gois . . to\n de\ dh=mon—the oligarchical government had caused the revolt.

oi(=s g' e)ch=n—as this sentence refers especially to the dh=mos, it would be better, perhaps, to put pa/ntes . . e)pe/qento in a parenthesis—unless, with Stahl, we understand pa/ntes (oi/ tou= dh/mou) and o(moi/ws (toi=s o)li/gois).
pa/lin e)n th=| po/lei ei)=nai—‘reinstated in their rights.’ For the sense of po/lis cf. IV. 106 po/lew/s te. sterisko/menoi.
bebaio/teron—sc. tou= meq' h(mw=n kindu/nou.

tw=n te cumma/xwn ske/yasqe . . ti/na oi)/esqe o(/ntina ou)—(1) the old explanation of this passage (given by Goller, for instance) was that ti/na oi)/esqe o(/ntina ou/ was equivalent to e(/kaston. c. 46, 2, where ti/na oi)/esqe h(/ntina ou) is independent, is strongly against this. Classen said that oi)/esqe merely repeats ske/yasqe owing to the length of the sentence; and this is accepted by subsequent edd. Classen's view involves also an anacoluthon, since ske/yasqe would be followed by ti/s o)/stis ou) with ind., not by ti/na o(/ntina ou). Against this view is to he urged (a) the complication of the constr. introduced by ske/yasqe, (b) the gen. tw=n te cumma/xwn, which, as Classen says, depends not only on toi=s . . a)posta=si, but also on ti/na oi)/esqe o(/ntina ou), so that Thuc. had a clear view of the constr. from the start. It is not unlikely that ske/yasqe is meant to be parenthetical. (2) ti/s o)/stis ou) is treated as a single word.
paqei/n—a second subject to h)=|.
a)pokekinduneu/setai—‘we shall find exposed to utmost peril.’

th=s e)/peita proso/dou, di' h(\n i)sxu/omen—the relative clause applies to th=s proso/dou only, the revenue generally, not to th=s e)/peita p., the future revenue; hence e)kei=qen or e)petei/ou has been conjectured for e)/peita, which the schol. already had in the text. Neither conjecture wholly removes the difficulty;
and so di' h(\n isxu/omen is thought by some to have been brought in here from the very similar passage in c. 46, 3. It would be better to read i)sxu/somen, ‘through which we may support our power.’
to\ loipo/n is pleonastic after e)/peita, and perhaps belongs to di' h(\n i)sxu/somen.
sterh/sesqe—‘will have to go without.’
proqei=nai—of the orators.

pisth/n—‘hope relying on (the speaker's) eloquence,’ is contrasted with ‘hope gained by bribery (of the speaker),’ cf. c. 38, 2; one speaker's eloquence, another's venality, may prompt him to take up the cause of Lesbos.

cuggnw/mhn a(martei=n a)nqrwpi/nws lh/yontai—‘that they will be excused for having erred humanly,’ i.e. through human frailty not deliberately: pw=s a)\n to/ g' a)/kon pra=gm' a)\n ei)ko/tws ye/gois; Soph. OC. 977. 4
a)/kontes—the ou) applies to this also, but is attracted to the verb.
cu/ggnwmon = cuggnw/mhs a)/cion, as also, perhaps, in IV. 98, but not elsewhere.

to/te—supply diemaxesa/mhn (the same idiom in I. 86 and VI. 60). But mh\ lu/ein ta\ p., which came into question only in the second meeting, causes some difficulty. We must assume either (1) that the sentence is developed as it proceeds, mh\ lu/ein ta\ p. not being supplied with to/te, or else, (2) that prw=ton (diemaxesa/mhn) means that Cleon had already in the previous meeting seen that there would be an agitation for revision. (I prefer the second solution. Brevity would excuse prodedogme/na as applied to a vote to be passed. The voting at the first meeting must have been close; and c. 36, 3 suggests anxiety about getting it carried out. Krüger had noticed that to/te prw=ton is unsatisfactory according to the usual explanation: I think there must be a point in prw=ton, as in Aristoph. Eq. 339 prw=ta diamaxou=mai.)
e)pieikei/a|—‘generosity,’ ‘consideration for others.’

tou\s o(moi/ous—variously rendered as ‘like minded,’ or ‘situated as we are,’ i.e. equals, not subjects. For the latter, it is claimed that e)c a)na/gkhs points to unwilling subjects; and sentiment so arrogant might well be attributed to Cleon.
e(/cousi . . a)gw=na—sarcastic, implying ‘if they must have their a)gw/n’; cf. c. 38, 4.

kai\ mh/ — there is implied prohibition, hence mh/ The
choice of the constr. is no doubt influenced by the previous kai\ mh/.
to\ paqei=n eu)=—the excellent return they will get is a bribe from the Mytilenaeans. It appears that a few years later Cleon himself was said to have made something out of the troubles of Mytilene.
kai\ to\ loipo/n—‘in the future as in the past.’

o(moi/ws . . u(poleipome/nous—the conjecture o(moi/ws seems to be clearly right. Even when o(moi/ous is rendered ‘consistent’ and taken as pred, with u(poleipome/nous, it remains very awkward that e)pithdei/ous and polemi/ous imply h(mi=n, whereas o(moi/ous must imply e(autou/s. The previous o(moi/ous used in a quite different sense in this series of closely connected sentences is against the adj. o(moi/ws te kai\ ou)de\n h(=sson is a Thucydidean way of saying ‘just as must as before.’

peiqo/menoi me/n—the steps of the argument, which is difficult to follow to a)ndragaqi/zesqai and has given rise to much discussion, are as follows: (1) if you punish M., you will act as Justice and Interest alike demand; (2) it may be said that Justice is on their side and against you (ei) ga/r); (3) even if it is, you must follow the dictates of Interest (ei) de\ dh/).
ou) xariei=sqe—because they will still hate you.

dikaiw/sesqe—‘you will punish yourselves’ (instead of them) by proclaiming to all that you have no right to exert authority. ei) ga/r—ga/r does not introduce the reason for the preceding statement, but = ‘it is true that,’ as in c. 43, 5 (Stahl in Rhein. Mus. 1901). ou) xrew/n is acc. abs. On the form of condition (cf. I. 38, VI. 92) Goodwin points out that it is “a perfectly natural combination, each part having its proper force.” If they were justified, you must have no right to your empire: ei) de\ dh\ . . kola/zesqai (mid ) proceeds on this assumption. If you persist in ruling (tou=to dra=n), even though you have no right to do so, then your interests require that you punish them, as you have others. The only alternative (h)/=‘otherwise’) is, you must give up empire; you must run no risks (e)k tou= a)kindu/nou=a)kindu/nws) and play an honourable part.

pau/esqai . . a)ndragaqi/cesqai — Cleon echoes words attributed to Pericles at II. 63. a)ndragaqi/zomai was, it would seem, in use among the aristocrats who favoured a peace policy; cf. for the noun with ‘a political or social reference’ c. 57, 1, 64, 4 (Neil, Append. to Aristoph. Eq.).

th=| te au)th=| zhmi/a|—viz. as that by which ta/ te di/kaia . . kai\ ta\ cu/mfora poih/sete—the one I recommend. (a) This is usually explained, after the schol., ‘the same that they would have inflicted on you had they succeeded.’ But (1) it is unlikely that zhmi/a would be used without explanation, of the destruetion Mytilene had sought to bring on Athens: and (2) th=| au/th=| can only be so explained by the assumption that the sentence, simple in form, is strangely confused in thought. We need such an addition as in II. 67 toi=s au)toi=s a)mu/nesqai oi)=sper kai\ . . u(ph=rcan. (b) Steup explains ‘the same as you agreed to yesterday,’ but this seems a strange way of saying ‘uphold your decision.’ Also the reference in th=| au)th=| should be found in the context immediately preceding; c. 62 th=| me/ntoi au)th=| i)de/a|. VII 39, 1. The reference in the version given above is. it is true. a little remote. but ei) de\ dh\ . . a)ndragaqi/zesqai is practically parenthetical.

oi( diafeu/gontes—cf. oi( diaba/llontes c. 4, oi( e)pago/menoi II. 2, oi( prodido/ntes II. 5. The temporal force is lost, and the partic. becomes a substantive. But the plot is referred to in aorist, as having preceded the escape.
mh\ cu\n profa/sei=a)/neu profa/sews i(kanh=s Antiphon V. 22. 37

e)pece/rxontai kai\ diollu/nai—‘follow up (the wrong they inflict) even to the length of destroying their enemy utterly.’ The MSS. have dio/lluntai, which can only yield a very artificial sense. Their own utter destruction is not what they seek. The inf. is of purpose.
u(forw/menoi ‘eyeing with misgiving.’ All edd. refer to the famous ‘odisse quem laeseris’ of Tac. for the sentiment.

o( ga\r . . paqw/n—this applies to Athens, which has been attacked a)/neu profa/sews. ‘He who has been injured needlessly is more dangerous when he has escaped (the plot to destroy him), than an enemy on equal terms,’ i.e. where equal offence has been given on both sides. Mytilene knew Athens would be implacable if she escaped.

geno/menoi . . th=| gnw/mh|—‘place yourselves in thought as near (the moment of) the injury as possible, and (think) how.’ g. th=| gnw/mh|=dianohqe/ntes (I. 143). (Possibly to/t' is lost after panto/s.) 44
a)ntapo/dote ‘repay.’ Cf. “Vengeance is mine, saith the Lord: I will repay.”

pro\s to\ paro\n au)ti/ka with malakisqe/ntes, ‘at their present plight,’ for to\ au)ti/ka paro/n: the position of the adv. is
not very rare in tragedy, e.g. Aesch. PV. 1013 tw=| fronou=nti mh\ kalw=s (Jebb on Soph. OT. 1294). Here au)ti/ka gains emphasis in contrast with pote/ by its position. For the pleonasm edd. compare I. 95 e)n tw=| tu/te paro/nti, I. 123 tw=n e)/peita mello/ntwn. (parauti/ka has been conjectured for paro\n au)ti/ka, and to/te for pote/.) 48

para/deigma safe\s katasth/sate . . zhmiwso/menon—for the partic., as with dhlou=n, dh=lon or fanero\n poiei=n, cf. Soph. El. 24 safh= shmei=a fai/neis e)sqlo\s ei)s h(ma=s gegw/s. to/de—o(/de referring to what precedes, as often in speeches.
*dio/dotos—not elsewhere heard of.
memfome/nous—equivalent to memfome/nous kai\ a)ciou=n- tas, the brachylogy being made easier by the preceding tou\s proqe/ntas th\n d., the persons censured.
du/o . . o)rgh/n—some make ta/xos te kai\ o)rgh/n subj. of ei)=nai, removing the comma, comparing cc. 40, 2, 57, 3, 75, 1. The parallels do not seem to prove the point.

to\ me/n=ta/xos. This passage is directly aimed at Cleon, who had deprecated xro/nou diatribh/n, thus showing his own follv, and had displayed the vehemence to which the ignorant and shallow-minded are pione.
gi/gnesqai ‘to be found.’
mh\ didaska/lous tw=n pragma/twn g.—‘are not to explain affairs,’ i.e. how they are to be conducted.
lo/goi personified, like peiqw/. diama/xomai as in c. 40.
i)di/a| ti au)tw=| diafe/rei—‘he has some private interest.’
fra/sai—‘give guidance.’

ti ai)sxro
 pei=sai—‘to carry a disgraceful proposal.’ Cf. c. 59, 2. ou)k . . h(gei=tai—ou) can appear after ei) . . me/n, provided the indic. is used, as in I. 121 ei) oi( me
 . . ou)k a)perou=sin, Xen. Anab. VII. 1, 29 ei) ba/rbaron me
 po/lin ou)demi/an h)qelh/samen katasxei=n.
eu)= de\ diabalw/n—Cleon got a name for skill in diabolh/, as several passages in Aristoph. Equites show.

xalepw/tatoi de\ . . e)pi/deici/n tina—‘most difficult to meet are those in particular (kai/) who by anticipation impute (to an opponent) a sort of rhetorical display to get money.’ xalepw/tatoi does not mean to exclude the eu)= diabalw/n, who also—as the kai/ shows—is xalepw/tatos as imputing to his opponent a desire to display his rhetorical skill; cf. c. 38, 2. But those who say that bribery is the motive are singled out.
The emphasis is on e)pi\ xrh/masi, which accordingly is in an unusual order: it belongs to e)pi/deicin. The point of tina is that an e)pi/deicis proper was not delivered in the Ecclesia.
a)cunetw/teros . . a)dikw/teros—‘judged more of a fool than a knave.’ The double compar. as regularly where two qualities in the same ohject are contrasted: i)w\ strathgoi\ ple/ones h)\ belti/ones.
meta\ a)cunesi/as—‘besides his (seeming) folly,’ a characteristic substitute for meta\ tou= a)cu/netos gi/gnesqai.
a)\n peisqei=en—viz. the state. The change to plur. is made easy by the intervention of tw=n politw=n.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou ‘on equal terms,’ is parallel to e)kfobou=nta.

sw/frona—a very moderate criticism of the dangerous tendency now manifesting itself in Athenian public life, since the death of Pericles, to give too much weight to the piqanw/tatoi (c. 36, 6). sw/frwn was esp. associated with those opposed to extreme democracy; cf. c. 62, 4. For tw=| plei=sta eu)= bouleu/onti, ‘he whose connsel is generally good,’ we should expect, at first sight, something like tw=| pista\ cumbouleu/onti (conjectnred by Weil), ‘he whose counsel is followed,’ in contrast with to\n mh\ tuxo/nta gnw/mhs, in the sense, ‘he whose advice is rejected’; cf pei/sas and mh\ tuxw/n in § 3, katorqw=n and e)pituxw/n below. But in stating the principle that ought to be followed, the moderate Diodotus criticizes what the people professed to wish, viz. to reward good (not merely persuasive) counsellors. But in rewards the persuasive was mistaken for the good. And to\n mh\ tuxo/nta gnw/mhs is no doubt intentionally ambiguous, for, in contrast with pei/sas, it does mean ‘he who fails to carry his opinion’; but, in contrast with tw=| eu)= bouleu/onti, ‘not fortunate in his advice’ means ‘wrong’ ‘Who fails in counsel’ will keep up the two meanings. Cf. Aesch. PV. 204 ta\ lw=|sta bouleu/wn piqei=n . . ou)k h)dunh/qhn. (The intentional ambiguity of this passage has escaped notice.)
a)lla\ mhd' e)lassou=n—‘but not to curtail . . either,’ as might happen in the case of his being charged with corruption.
ou)x o(/pws . . a)lla\ mhde/—non modo (non) . . sed ne . . quidem. For the sentiment cf. Demosth. III. 18 ou) le/gei tis ta\ be/ltista; a/nasta\s a)/llos eipa/tw, mh\ tou=ton ai)tia/sqw.
pro\s xa/rin—‘to please’ the people.
o)re/goito—sc. h(/kista a)/n. tw=| au)tw=| is explained by xarizo/menos ktl.

kai\ u(popteu/htai—‘if a mere suspicion that a man is speaking for gain, and is offering the best advice in spite of it.’ We cannot render ‘though he offers the best advice, he does so for gain,’ as is commonly done, for the me/n-clause must be our though (cf. Jebb on Soph. OC. 1536). But there is no need to supply dokh=| from u(popteu/htai to suit the de/-clause if we notice that me\n . . de/ is inserted merely for the sake of a verbal antithesis, and that the sense is simply ke/rdous e(/neka ta\ be/ltista le/gein.
fqonh/santes . . kerdw=n—‘feeling jealous of the uncertain impression of his gains,’ i.e. jealous of his supposed gains. That his advice is helpful is ex hypothesi certain.
th=s po/lews a)fairou/meqa—the same constr. c. 58, 1.
kaqe/sthke de/—‘it has come to this, that.’
a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os is opposed to a)pa/th| below.
ta\ deino/tata . . pei=sai—‘to get the most atrocious proposals adopted.’

mo/nhn te po/lin—‘so we are the only state which it is impossible to benefit openly, without recourse to deception.’ It is disputed whether mo/nhn po/lin means (1) ‘a state alone,’ as distinct from the individual citizens, or (2) ‘(ours) is the only state which,’ as pred. to h(ma=s supplied. The latter is surely right, for (1) Athens is contrasted with h( sw/frwn po/lis in c. 42, 5, and this contrast is kept up through c. 43, 1, and (2) there is no suggestion in the context that the state is more suspicious than the individual.
dia\ ta\s perinoi/as—‘excessive shrewdness,’ by which it thinks it detects self-interest in the honest speaker. The word only here.
a)nq-upopteu/etai—‘is in return suspected.’

xrh\ de\ . . skopou/ntwn—‘but in dealing with the most important interests and in such a case as this it ought to be assumed that we speakers take a somewhat wider forecast than you whose view is circumscribed,’ i.e. whose judgment is formed in a short debate
ti with peraite/rw, as in ma=llo/n ti. e)n tw=| toiw=|de: its possible meanings are ‘at such a time,’ and ‘in such a case.’
u(peu/qunon—a speaker was liable to the grafh\ parano/mwn.
pro\s a)neu/qunon . . a)kro/asin—‘as opposed to your attention to it, which is irresponsible.’
swfrone/steron a)\n e)kri/nete—‘you would be more circumspect (cf. c. 42, 5) in your decisions’ (II. 40, 2).

pro\s o)rgh
 h(/ntin' a)
 tu/xhte—‘in the anger of the moment.’ Grammatieally zhmiou=ntes is supplied to tu/xhte, and pro/s, according to a common idiom, is repeated to h(/ntina; but no doubt the speaker would not be conscious of such ellipse. h(/ntina without a)/n is according to epic idiom; but it is very probable that h(/ntin' a)
 is the true reading. (No other emendation is to be thought of: h)/n ti a)tuxh=te is impossible, if only because a)tuxei=n in this context means ‘to fail in a request’ Nor must sfale/ntes be supplied to tu/xhte: for this would mean that punishment is inflieted in the same mood as that in which the error was committed. But that is not the point.)
ei)=o(/ti.

h)/n te kai\ . . e)a=n—for ei)=en most edd. accept e)a=n= ‘(I shall not bid you) spare them.’ e)/xontas, se. a)pofh/nw, is a conjecture for e)/xontes, and unsatisfactory. The correction is uncertain, and it is doubtful if ou) keleu/sw can be supplied legitimately. It is likely that something is lost before ei)=en: e.g. Bergk suggested ou) dia\ tou=to kai\ a)/cioi a)\n cuggnw/mhs. (ei)=en as exelamatory which Classen, with some doubt, kept, is impossible. Its use is in assent to what precedes and in passing on to a new point it is not appropriate here.)

tou=to o(/ is rendered ‘as for this that.’ (1) There is no authority for this phrase used adverbially in this way: hence the conjecture tou/tou, governed by ta)nanti/a. Otherwise we must assume an anacoluthon. (2) But CG read tou=to w(=|, and quite possibly this is right. tou=to a)ntisxurizo/menos w(=| *kle/wn i)sxuri/zetai=‘while maintaining this in opposition to what C. maintains’ (cf. toi=s e)gklh/masi a)nterou=ntes I. 73). peri\ tou= . . e)/xontos is then epexegetic of tou=to, just as e)s to\ loipo\n . . e)/sesqai is of w)=| (=e)kei/nw| o(/). Both insist on the future, but one on to\ cumfe/ron, the other on to\ kalo/n.
proqei=si—depending on cumfe/ron (u(mi=n), eonditional.
pro/s—‘in view of.’
tw=n dikai/wn—‘arguments of justice,’ as in Demosth. de Cor. 6, 9. To
dei=n and
xrhsi/mws e(/cousin supply h(mi=n.
qana/tou . . pro/keintai—qana/tou gen. of definition. zhmi/a pro/keitai (see crit. note) is more likely in view of pasw=n tw=n zhmiw=n below. To pollw=n . . a(marthma/twn supply ‘as the penalty.’
tw=| e)pibouleu/mati—instrumental.
po/lis te a)fistame/nh—‘so in the case of a state.’
th=| dokh/sei—‘in its own opinion.’ An effective reply to Cleon's argument from the fact that M. had taken Athens at a disadvantage.
tou/tw|—revolt.
e)pei\ . . ge—not a common combination; Iliad IX. 425 e)pei\ ou)/ sfisin h(/de g' e(toi/mh, Pind. Ol. IX. 40 e)pei\ to/ ge loidorh=sai qeou\s e)xqra\ sofi/a. The ge merely emphasizes diecelhlu/qasi.
prostiqe/ntes—‘continually adding to them.’ For
ei)/ pws with a perf. preceding see M.T. § 489, esp. Aristoph. Av. 120.

parabainome/nwn—there are two tenable explanations of this: (1) impersonal gen. abs. as in I. 116 e)saggelqe/ntwn M. T. § 848, ‘transgressions being committed’; (2) sc. tw=n megi/stwn a)dikhma/twn, which would be internal accus. to parabai/nw in the act. form, as in a)dikw= a)di/khma. The matter is rendered impossible of certain solution by the perplexing kai\ tou=to para: bai/netai. We expect, of course, the sense ‘mild penalties being disregarded,’ and presently, ‘the death penalty is disregarded,’ but how this can be got out of the Gk. as it stands is not apparent, unless we take an etymological sense of parabai/nw, ‘pass by,’ which is found occasionally in the orators, and interpret tou=to below as put loosely for h( zhmi/a tou= qana/tou. Against this is not so much the fact that Thuc. does not elsewhere use parabai/nw thus, but much more that parabai/nw zhmi/an is stranger than any instance in the orators and that the proximity of a)dikhma/twn makes it unnatural.

kai\ tou=to o(/mws parabai/netai—the conjectures are (1) ka)n tou/tw| (Kruger) ‘and under these circumstances,’ with parabai/netai impers. But it should be e)n tou/tois (cf. Jebb on Soph. Ant. 39); e)n tou/tw|=‘meanwhile,’ or ‘in this point.’ (2) kai\ tau=ta, sc. ta\ a)dikh/mata (Hude; cf. 2 above). I should prefer kai\ tau)ta/ ‘and the same offences are committed.’
deino/teron . . de/os—‘a terror more terrible’; cf. VII 68 e)xqroi\ kai\ e)/xqistoi.
h)\ to/de ge—‘else this,’ with emphasis on the second alternative (Neil on Aristoph. Eq. 413). Notice to/de after tou/tou, not very rare; e.g. Soph. Ant. 296.
h( me\n peni/a—to peni/a is opposed the power—e)cousi/a —that results from wealth. A poor man is emboldened by necessity, as a rich man is made covetous by insolence and pride.

ai( d' a)/llai cuntuxi/ai . . kindu/nous—‘the other condi
tions of life,’ as they arise—temporary rather than permanent: these fill men with a sudden passion (o)rgh=|), ‘as each (cuntuxi/a) is overpowered by some irrepressible power’—such e.g. as an overwhelming desire for independence. o)rgh=| tw=n a)nqrw/pwn coriesponds to th
 to/lman pare/xousa and th
 pleoneci/an p. of the other clauses, while a)nh/kesto/n ti corresponds to a)na/gkh and u(/bris kai\ fro/nhma. Of the many alterations proposed, only to
 a)/nqrwpon for tw=n a)nqrw/pwn needs notice. It is not an improvement; for there is a point in tw=n a)., ‘passion in those men’ whom they befall, always there, like pleoneci/a and to/lma, and ready to be called out by a favourable cuntuxi/a. (Not ‘mankind,’ which would here be a/nqrw/pwn, as o)rgh=| is without article. It has been proposed to refer e/ka/sth tis to o)rgh=?, but this would leave cuntuxi/ai too vague, and there would be little point in e(ka/sth tis.)
e)pi\ panti/—‘in every case’ of those just alluded to; cf. e)p' ou)deni\ tw=n toiou/twi Demosth. XXI. 65.
o( me/n—first comes Desire, next Hope—and then the attempt. Note the personification here.

th\n . . e)piboulh\n e)kfronti/zwn—‘thinking out the plot.’ The schol. has e)gxei/rhsin on this word, so that the writer of it must have found e)pibolh/n, ‘attempt,’ which most MSS. give, the only objection to which is that the subst. is not found elsewhere in this sense before Polybius.

th\n eu)pori/an th=s tu/xhs—‘suggesting the ready help of Chanee.’ Hope deludes them into a fancy that at the critical moment Chance will favour them. Though a subjective gen. does not occur with eu)pori/a elsewhere, th=s tu/xhs is plainly subjective here; cf. VII. 61 to\ th=s tu/xhs ka)\n meq' h(mw=n e)lpi/santes sth=nai, V. 113. (tu/xh cannot=‘success’ here, cf. § 7, nor ‘their fortunes.’)

o)/nta a)fanh=—i.e. e)/rws and e)lpi/s, ‘because (not though) unseen.’ Were they fanerai/, men would see that they could not be counted upon. As it is, plei=sta bla/ptousi by luring them on. Cf. v. 103 e)pi\ ta\s a)fanei=s (e)lpi/das) kaqi/stantai, and the next sentence.
e)p' au)toi=s—besides e)/rws and e)lpi/s.
kai\ e)k tw=n u(podeeste/rwn—‘even with insufficient means.’
ou)x h(=sson—i.e. even more than men.
peri\ tw=n megi/stwn te—sc. kinduneu/ousi. For the te, which, though found only in C, is probably right, cf. IV. 80 e(toi/mwn o)/ntwn tre/fein te kai\ e)pi\ a)posta/sei sfa=s e)pikaloume/nwn.

meta\ pa/ntwn . . e)do/casen—‘each individual acting with the whole community . . rates himself considerably above the reality,’ i.e. exaggerates his own strength. The reading of the best MSS. is au)tw=n for au(to/n. For doca/zw with personal obj. cf. Xen. Cyr. V. 5, 46 a)lkimw/tatos doca/zetai ei)=nai. e)pi\ ple/on ti together.
a(plw=s—c. 38, 7.

pollh=s eu)hqei/as, o(/stis—‘(it is a mark) of much simplicity, if anyone supposes.’ Cf. Xen. Hell. II. 3, 51 nomi/zw prosta/tou e)/rgon ei)=nai oi(/ou dei=, o(\s a)\n . . mh\ e)pitre/ph|. It would be more usual to have pollh\ eu)h/qeia/ (e)stin) o(/stis, or eu)hqe/staton o(/stis.
e)xeggu/w|—affording a good e)ggu/h, security that other states will not follow the example of Mytilene.
bouleu/sasqai—‘come to a decision.’
ou)k—redundant.
o(/ti e)n braxuta/tw|—notice the regular order with o(/ti and w(s+superl.
kai\ a)posta=sa—‘when revolt has actually taken place.’

th\n dapa/nhn a)podou=nai kai\ to\ loipo\n u(potelei=n—here, naturally, the least is made of the terms dealt out by Athens to revolted allies who submitted. Independent allies, when reduced after revolting, had also to pull down their walls and to hand over their ships to Athens. In I. 98 Thuc. gives a summary of the treatment dealt out to them much less favourable to Athens. By u(potelei=n is meant fo/rou u(potelei=s ei)=nai.
ti/na oi)/esqe h(/ntina—see on c. 39, 7.
paratenei=sqai—‘be strained to the utmost extremity.’
to\ au)to\ du/natai—cf. I. 141 th\n au)th\n dou/lwsin du/natai.

th=s proso/dou . . a)p' au)th=s—the art. not repeated with a verbal substantive (pro/sodos—prosie/nai). The words necessary to complete the sense of the subst. generally follow it, as in I. 18 th\n kata/lusin e)k th=s *(ella/dos, but occasionally precede, as in II. 18 kata\ th\n a)/llhn porei/an h( sxolaio/ths.
tw=|de—viz. th=| proso/dw|.

a)kribei=s—‘exacting’; so in I. 99 Thuc. says a)kribw=s e)/prasson of Athens in relation to her allies.
e)s xrhma/twn lo/gon—e)s l. is ‘on the score of.’ The phrase occurs also in Lysias (XIX. 61), and ei)s xrh/mata is found.
a)po\ tw=n e)/rgwn th=s e)pimelei/as—‘by practical precautions.’ Some render ‘by taking care of our actions’; but the former seems more natural, and cf. VI. 40 e)/rgw| fulassome/nh.
e)leu/qeron by right;
bi/a| a)rxo/menon in fact. bi/a|= ‘in its despite’; cf. I. 43 mh\ cumma/xous de/xesqe bi/a| h(mw=n, 68. Diodotus alludes to the true position of Lesbos; cf. c. 10.
pro/s—‘to the side of.’
tou/tou—i.e. tou= a)fi/stasqai.
o(/ti e)p' e)la/xiston—viz. of the inhabitants.
tou=to—internal aecus., ‘in this.’
a)posth/sasi—sc. th\n po/lin.
th=s a)ntikaqistame/nhs—‘which is ranging itself against us.’
e)s po/lemon e)pe/rxesqe—either e)/rxesqe e)s po/lemon or e)pe/rxesqe alone would be usual. Here we must supply au)th=|, and take e)s of the end in view.
ei) with fut. indic., ‘if you are going to.’
a)dikh/sete . . ktei/nontes—‘you will be guilty of the crime of’; a legal use.
katasth/sete—‘bring about,’ unusual without a predicative adj.; cf. (Classen) IV. 92 pollh\n a)/deian katesth/samen.
prodeica/ntwn—‘as you will have published abroad.’
kai\ ei) h)di/khsan, mh\ prospoiei=sqai—‘even if they did wrong, to pass it over.’ mh\ prospoiei=sqai, dissimulare, which occurs in several authors, is on the principle of ou)/ fhmi.
o(/—‘the element.’ Thuc. is partial to the neut. sing. collective for a masc. plur.
kai\ tou=to—tou=to antieipates e(ko/ntas h(ma=s a)dikhqh=nai: cf. VI. 85 kai\ h(mi=n tou=to w)felei=, ou)k h)\n . . . a)ll' h)/n . .
dikai/ws—i.e. as strict justiee allows.
dei= refers to interest, as in § 4.

to\ *kle/wnos.—made in c. 40, 4: ‘Cleon's claim, namely the identity of justice and expediency in the punishment, is found to be impossible of being realized at once in such a punishment,’ viz. e)n tw=| diafqei=rai. The sentence is illogical, for either to\ au)to/ or a(/ma should have been omitted.
ta/de—viz. the proposals about to be made.
ple/on nei/mantes—see c. 3, 1 n.
ou)de\ e)gw/—see c. 40, 2.
prosa/gesqai—middle, as regularly in this sense; the indef. subject must be supplied.
a)pe/pemyen—see c. 37, 1.
kaq' h(suxi/an—‘calmly.’

toi=s polemi/ois—thinking of the Peloponnesians. That Athens should show wisdom (1) calmly judging the guilty, (2) acquitting the democratic party, would be more effective against her enemies than a hasty exercise of brute strength, of vis consili expers.
pro\s tou\s e)nanti/ous is to be taken with krei/sswn e)sti/.
e)piw/n—‘if he goes to work.’
a)ntipa/lwn—‘equally matched’ (here, in argument), a common meaning of a)nti/palos in Thuc.

h)=lqon me\n e)s a)gw=na o(/mws th=s do/chs—‘engaged in a conflict of opinion after all,’ i.e. in spite of the revulsion of feeling (c. 36). o(/mws, as Poppo pointed out (Proleg. i. p. 290) implies a clause which is omitted; and, in spite of the remoteness of reference, the interpretation seems warranted by such passages as c. 28, and VII. 1. Some render th=s do/chs ‘about the decree,’ but the gen. should express the feeling, as in nu=n a)gw\n eu)yuxi/as Eur. Med. 403, and bou/leuma or yh/fisma would be expected for ‘decree’ here.
prote/ras—the best MSS. have deute/ras, as the result, no doubt, of an unfortunate conjecture, based on ei) fqa/seian below.
oi)/nw| . . pefurame/na—‘barley-meal kneaded with wine . .,’ into cakes, ma=zai, of the kind called oi)nou=ttai. fura=n, not fu/rein, is the form of the word in this sense.
o(/son . . a)negnwke/nai—‘as for him to have read,’ like o(/son a)pozh=n in I. 2. o(/son practically=w)/ste.

u(ste/ra au)th=s—as this is predicative, the e)pi- in the verb is pleonastic, if, as elsewhere, the verb=‘is brought into port after.’ It is possible that e)pi- implies haste, as in e)pibohqei=n: we expect such an allusion here, and Steup suggests au)ti/k' for au)th=s.

para\ tosou=ton . . h)=lqe—this and similar phrases—para\ mikro\n e)lqei=n, par' ou)de\n e).—are followed either by gen. or, more often, infin.; e g. Herod. IX. 33 par' e(/n pa/laisma e)/drame nika=n. para\ tosou=ton=‘within, up to, so short a distance.’ ki/ndunos
means the danger of destruction, and the gen. is the same as with e)ggu/s.
a)pe/pemyen—to Athens; see cc. 28, 35, 48.
xili/wn—the number is astonishing, and nothing approaching it is suggested by anything in the preceding narrative. Hence it is thought that *<*>a=xili/wn is a corruption of *l'=tria/konta.

klh/rous . . poih/santes—i.e. the late owners became hereditary tenants and paid an annual sum to the Athenian ‘cleruchs.’ Thuc. (and Ephorus, as copied by Diodorus XII. 55) assume that all the land was thus divided, except that of Methymna: this would bring each klh=ros to about 96 acres (as Chuton says); but, of course, not the whole of the klh=ros would be under eultivation. Apparently all the land was owned by oligarchs. The new klh=roi would, of eourse, cut across the boundaries of former estates.

klhrou/xous—2700 poor citizens chosen by lot They doubtless served to form a garrison; but in 412 B.C. there cannot have been anything like this number of Athenians in Lesbos (VIII. 22); it is assumed that many of the cleruchs subsequently returned to Athens.
e(ka/stou with klh/rou. The mid. denotes a reciprocal arrangement.
a)rguri/on is prob. object of fe/rein, and
du/o mna=s with the gen. is in appos. to it.
ta\ e)n th=| h)pei/rw|—several places called *)aktai=ai po/leis—Antandros being one. These became tributary allies.
*niki/ou—first mention of him in Thuc.

h(\ kei=tai . . e)xrw=nto de\ au)th=|—it is not usual to have the rel. repeated in the second clause (VI. 4 to\ xwri/on ou(= nu=n h( po/lis e)sti\ kai\ o(\ prw=ton e)teixi/sqh), unless the one is pos., the other neg., as in II. 43 ou)k e)n w(=| kei=ntai ma=llon, a)ll' e)n w(=| h( do/ca katalei/petai. In the second clause the rel. is often replaced by the required case of au)to/s. A similar omission or substitution is frequent in Lat., esp. in Livy, as XXIII. 8 cum quo steterat nec eum patria maiestas sententia dcpulerat. So, too, in Engl., as Hooker ‘Whom though to know be life, and joy to make mention of His name,’ Macanly ‘To whom she seemed to listen, but did not hear them.’
th\n fulakh\n . . ei)=nai—Athens had at least one frou/rion at Salamis, and a few ships there maintained a not very efficient blockade of the port of Megara.

tou/s te *peloponnhsi/ous—parallel to toi=s te *megareu=sin
. . e)splei=n, and probably, like that clause, depending on toi=s *)aqhnai/ois fulakh\n ei)=nai=tou\s *)aqhnai/ous fula/ssesqai. This kata\ su/nesin constr. cannot be paralleled in prose, but it would be ordinary in tragedy: see Jebb on Soph. Antig. 216. Thus tou\s *p. is the anticipatory accus., for o(/pws oi) *peloponnh/sioi ktl.: the differing constr., first o(/pws, then infin., after a single verb, is not unusual. (Several emendations have been proposed, of which pro/s te *pel., depending on fulakh\n ei)=nai and tou/s te *pel. skopw=n are worth notice.)
mh\ poiw=ntai . . au)to/qen—viz. from Nisaea, the harbour of Megara. The allusion in au)to/qen is not quite the same as in the previous case.

to\ pri\n geno/menon—‘the previous incident’ occurred in the autumn of 429 B.C. The Pel. intended to surprise the Piraeus, but contented themselves with a descent on Salamis, which caused great alarm at Athens, and led at once to measures for the protection of the Athenian harbours (II. 93).

e(lw\n ou)=n . . prou/xonte—when, as in the case of Megara (I. 103), a city had long walls running down to its harbour, it was usual to prolong the walls aeross the mouth, and to leave only a small passage between two towers, forming what was called a klh|sto\s limh/n. a)po\ th=s *nisai/as prou/xonte are to be taken together. The order is unusual, but (1) a)po\ th=s N. gains prominence by its position (cf. Jebb on Soph. Antig. 325), (2) it is certainly not stranger than II. 7 pro\s tai=s au)tou= u(parxou/sais e)c *)itali/as kai\ *sikeli/as toi=s ta)kei/nwn e(lome/nois, where e)c . . *sikeli/as goes with e(lome/nois. (If taken with e(lw/n, a)po\ th=s N. is rendered either (a) ‘on the side toward N.,’ or (b) ‘on the side away from N.’ But (1) in either case du/o pu/rgw then raises a difficulty, because they are then both on the island, and above, it was one tower: (2) neither meaning has really been proved possible: in the passages quoted for (b) a)po/=‘at a distance from’ with a verb of rest. If not taken with prou/xonte, a)po\ th=s N. would naturally=‘starting from N.,’ with N. for a base; (3) with (a) it is impossible to explain kai\ to\ e)k th=s h)pei/rou, which must denote a different place from a)po\ th=s N.)

e)s to\ metacu\ th=s nh/sou—supply kai\ th=s h)pei/rou, as in Dem. de Cor. 26 to\n metacu\ xro/nen tw=n o(/rkwn, ‘the interval between (that time, and) the oaths,’ Aristoph. Av. 187 e)n me/sw| dh/pouqen a)h/r e)sti gh=s, and often. Sometimes the other limit is expressed. (It might mean ‘to the part of the island lving between,’ as Isocr. IV. 70 e)n tw=| metacu\ th=s xw/ras, but on the whole this seems less likely.)
a)petei/xize kai\ to\ e)k th=s h).—‘he proceeded to build a wall on the side facing the mainland as well,’ apparently at the island end of the bridge. The kai/ refers to prw=ton.

kai\ e)n th=| nh/sw| tei=xos—the kai/ refers to a)petei/xize to\ e)k th=s h)pei/rou. (We cannot be confident about the interpretation of these operations at Mmoa, because (1) the account— as is often the case with Thuc. when he writes of topographical details—is not clear, and (2) the coastline has changed, and there is no longer an island at all.)
poliorkei=sqai—‘endure the siege,’ a use of the inf. frequent with a)dikei=sqai, and found occasionally both in Greek and Latin.
ei\rhme/non ga\r h)=n—sc. bi/a| mh\ e(lei=n. But this is just what the Pel. had tried to do in 429 B.C.: their views had changed.

o(/sa pole/mw| xwri/a e)/xousin—the original intention of Sparta had been to destroy the Athenian empire: since the failure at Lesbos they expect much less. That failure had evidently strengthened the peace party at Sparta.
le/gonta—as in VII. 3; contrast II. 85 pe/mpousi cumbou/lous keleu/ontes.

ei) bou/lontai . . ou)de/na—in this perplexing sentence, it is best (1) to make paradou=nai and xrh/sasqai depend on bou/lontai: (2) to make tous te . . ou)de/na the apodosis to this protasis. Then (1) te . . de/ eorrespond (I. 11, 1, 25, 3, VI. 83, 1, VII. 81, 3, and in other authors not very seldom); (2) kola/zein=‘they are ready to punish,’ unless we accept the conjeeture kola/sein. For the outline of the syntax cf. VII. 3 prope/mpei . . le/gonta, ei) bou/lontai e)cie/nai . . e(toi=mos ei)=nai spe/ndesqai. (It is impossible to render ei) ‘whether,’ as though le/gonta were e)rwtw=nta.)
e)n o(/sw|—cf. c. 28, 1.
a)gaqo/n ti—the second ti is not impossible, but, in view of 53, 2, 68, 1, it is improbable.

prota/cantes sfw=n au)tw=n is generally rendered ‘having appointed as their advocates,’ but, in view of VI. 100 triakosi/ous sfw=n au/tw=n . . prou/tacan (cf. c. 112 below), Hude is probably right in taking the gen. as partitive.
*ai)eimnh/stou—a eelebrated man, who had commanded the Plataeans at Marathon and Plataea.

h(gou/menoi—this series of partieiples is perplexing, and their
relation depends on whether (1) the sentence is meant to be antithetic, so that pisteu/santes kai\ deca/menoi form a pair, and oi)o/menoi and h(gou/menoi stand in causal relation to these respectively; or (2) oi)o/menoi kai\ h(gou/menoi give the two grounds of pisteu/santes, and e)n (with the MSS.) a)/llois deca/menoi is subord. —either conditional or causal—to h(gou/menoi: or (3) the sentence is developed as it proceeds, so that (a) oi)o/menoi kai\ deca/menoi—with either e)n or a)\n a)/llois—give the cause of e)poihsa/meqa, and h(gou/menoi gives the cause of deca/menoi: or (4) with deca/menoi subord. to h(gou/menoi, pisteu/santes is similarly subord. of condition to oi)o/menoi. I decidedly prefer (3), because it gives a form of sentence to which Thuc. is certainly partial (Hache, de Partic. Thucyd. ii.); the main verb is followed by a partic.—here oi)o/menoi kai\ deca/menoi—that gives the cause; then this partic. itself develops another causal to itself; cf., for instance, c. 110 a)gge/lletai tou\s *)amprakiw/tas e)pibohqei=n, boulome/nous . . cummei=cai, ei)do/tas ou)de/n. The order of pisteu/santes tells against (1) and (4), and (2) is very artificial. The incoherence of § 1 is doubtless intentional, as in the case of the opening of Soph. Antig.

e)n dikastai=s ou)k a)
 a)/llois deca/menoi—the MSS. have e)n a/llois, and for the repetition of the prep. in apposition VI. 68 h)=lqon e)pi\ th
 mhtro/polin e)f' h(ma=s is quoted. But (1) in that passage and others like it, such as Lysias VI. 14 e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw|, e)n tw=| semnota/tw| dikasthri/w|, we have a second noun added to explain the first (cf. Jebb on Soph. Trach. 695): this is not so with e)n a)/llois here (so Kruger). (2) Taking constr. (3) as explained in the last note, a)
 deca/menoi, ‘would have consented to appear before no other judges,’ gives a better sense than deca/menoi.
w(/sper kai\ e)sme/n—‘as we are actually doing.’
a)mfote/rwn—to\ no/mimon and to\ i)/son.
h(marth/kamen—the subj. perf., of what may turn out afterwards to have been the case, might have been used.
lo/gon—i.e. makro/tera ei)pei=n, c. 52, 5.
to/ te e)perw/thma braxu\ o)/n—accus. abs. co-ordinated with the preceding gen. abs, both expressing cause.
ta\ me\n a)lhqh= is obj. of a)pokri/nasqai; the infin. clause is subj. to gi/gnetai. Hence

e)nanti/a sc. h/mi=n, is for e)nanti/on, which is awkward after ta\ a/lhqh=: some think e)nanti/on should be read. (The other view, that a)pokri/nasqai is epexegetic, a)lhqh\s a)pokri/nasqai, is most improbable, and w(=| is then grammatically impossible.)
ta\ de\ yeudh=—sc. a)pokri/nasqai.
e)/legxon e)/xei—‘can be confuted.’

ei)po/ntas ti kinduneu/ein—‘to say something and take our chance’=here ‘to say something if we must risk our lives’; the emphasis, as often in Gk. and Lat., on the partic., as in I. 20 boulo/menoi dra/sante/s ti kai\ (‘then’) kinduneu=sai, Soph. OC. 1038 xwrw=n a)pei/lei ‘threaten, but go,’ Trach. 592 ei)de/nai xrh\ drw=san ‘you must act, if you would know.’

o( mh\ r(hqei\s lo/gos=to\ to\n lo/gon mh\ r(hqh=nai, a frequent constr. in Greek and Silver Latin; cf. c. 66, 3, Demosth. Olynth. III. 34 oi)/koi me)nwn belti/wn=to\ me)nein au)to\n be/ltio/n e)sti. See also c. 66, 3. The neg. in the phrase is regularly mh/, whether the partic. is in attributive, or—as much oftener —in predicative position.
ai)ti/an—‘grievance,’ meaning probably ‘self-reproach,’ as in I. 140.
a)gnw=tes . . e)pesenegka/menoi—the subject contracts, being first both parties, but then the Plataeans only: this freedom is characteristic of Thuc.
pro\s ei)do/tas pa/nta lele/cetai—‘you know all that can be said.’
h(mw=n with prokatagno/ntes as well as a)reta/s, ‘having formed the prejudice against us, that our merits’; cf. c. 45, 1.
au)to/—viz. to\ h(/ssous ei)=nai ktl.

a)/llois xa/rin fe/rontes—‘gratifying others,’ viz. the Thebans. The subject of fe/rontes would more naturally be the Lacedaemonians: if the text is sound—fero/ntwn has been conjectured—we recall the principle qui facit per alium facit per se.
di/kaia—cf. c. 44, 4.
pro\s . . e)s—no difference of meaning.
*qhbai/wn=pro\s tou\s *qhbai/ous.
fi/lous nomi/zontas=ei) fi/lous nomi/zete (h(ma=s).
ta\ d' e)n th=| ei)rh/nh|—adverbial. The art. covers pro/s.

kai\ ga/r—(1) this could be taken together,=etenim, or (2) a correlative for kai/ could be sought in what follows, or (3) kai/ could be supposed to emphasize the concessive force of
h)peirw=tai o)/ntes: most probably (1) is right, though some deny this use for Thuc.
ma/xh|—temporal, without e)n; this dat. is used several times by Thuc. The Plataeans were always proud of the fact that the battle had been fought on their soil.
kai\ u(mi=n . . i)di/a|—as distinct from their services to the common cause.
o(/teper dh/—‘at the very time when,’ in 464 B.C.
tw=n . . a)posta/ntwn depends on fo/bos. For the position of the attrib. partic., not rare in Thuc. when other qualifying words are added, cf. II. 18 h( e)n *)isqmw=| e)pimo/nh genome)nh, c. 67, 3.

deome/nwn ga\r cummaxi/as—in 519 or 509 B.C. (see on c. 68, 5) Plataea, piezeu/menoi u(po\ *qhbai/wn (Herod. VI. 108), applied to king Cleomenes to be admitted to alliance with Sparta.—Note (1) absence of noun with deome/nwn, see c. 34, 3 n.: (2) gen. abs. though a)pew/sasqe follows, a common sacrifice of form to sense in Herod. and Thuc.; for this variety cf. II. 5 a)naxwrhsa/ntwn de\ pa/lin (sc. au)tw=n) e)k th=s gh=s a)podw/sein au)toi=s.
a)poikou/ntwn—for the case here cf. II. 8 e)s tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, a)/llws te kai\ proeipo/ntwn.
e)n . . tw=| pole/mw|—viz. ‘this war,’ as often in Thuc.
ou)k h)qelh/samen—ei)=o(/ti, hence ou).
u(mw=n keleusa/ntwn—this occurred in 429 B.C, when the Peloponnesians marched against Plataea. The demand was that Plataea should either join the Lacedaemonian alliance or remain neutral.
eu)= paqw/n—what services Plataea had received from Athens before she ‘won the alliance’ of 519 (or 509) B.C. is not known.
tis of course, means the Plataeans.

politei/as mete/laben—this passage and c. 63 clearly imply that Athenian citizenship in some form was granted to Plataeans settling at Athens since the original alliance; and Isocr. Piat. 51, Pan. 49, Lysias XXIII. 2, and [Dem.] c. Neaer. do not make this assumption impossible. But in II. Thuc. speaks only of a cummaxi/a between Plataea and Athens, and possibly Thuc. here anticipates. It is certain that citizenship was conferred on the Plataean refugees after the destruction of Plataea. For the w(=n omitted see c. 51, 1 n.

a(\ . . e)chgei=sqe—a)/ is internal accus., and e)chgei=sqe,
which is used of the orders issued by the head of a confederacy is imperf.

app.lem: polla\ me\n . . h)di/khsan, to\ de\ teleutai=on . .

div.p: cu/niste—the form of the sentence shows that *qhbai=oi is purposely placed in a prominent place; cf. what the Plataeans say at II. 71 meta\ *qhbai/wn tw=n h(mi=n e)xqi/stwn e)pi\ doulei/a| th=| h(mete/ra| h(/kete.
katalamba/nontas—conative.

i(eromhni/a|—the attack occurred teleutw=ntos tou= mhno/s (II. 2), but whether the holiday was connected with the new moon is unknown. The attempt was made at about ten o'clock (peri\ prw=ton u(/pnon) on the night, probably, of April 4, 431.

ei) ga/r—‘if you are going to base your estimate of Justice on your present interest (which is, to favour Thebes) and their hostility.’ The repetition of the art. before e)kei/nwn would be more usual; but it is not necessary. The position of te is defended by the contrast between u(mw=n and e)kei/nwn. lamba/nein is here ‘to feel about’ a thing. (Stahl and Classen agree in this explanation, which is no doubt correct) For lamba/nein, ‘to feel about’ in a certain manner, cf. di' oi)/ktou l. (Eur. Suppl. 194), and c. 59, 1.
h)mei=s—sc. h)=men, as the sense shows.
mei/zoni—viz. than you now are, from the Athenians.

e)n kairoi=s oi(=s—i.e. e)n oi(=s, according to a common idiom, e.g. Dem. XIX. 342 e)pi\ th=s au)th=s (e)f') h)=sper nu=n e)cousi/as . . menei=. To e)n kairoi=s, as to mei/zw, the partic. must be supplied; cf. c. 30, 1: contrast c. 47, 5.
ma=llon—i.e. than now when their services are forgotten.

ta\ cu/mfora . . au(toi=s—(‘arrange terms) which were to their own advantage in view of the invasion.’ pro\s th\n e)/. belongs to cu/mfora rather than to pra/ssontes: cf. II. 3 h| e(/kaston e)fai/neto pro\s ta\ paro/nta cu/mforon e)/sesqai.
a)sfalei/a|—‘securely,’ as in c. 82 a)sfalei/a| de\ to\ e)pibouleu/esqai, ‘to make plans in security,’ Soph. OT. 51 a)ll' a)sfalei/a| th/nd' a)no/rqwson po/lin.
w(=n—partitive.
e)pi\ toi=s au)toi=s—i.e. because we have again chosen to\ a)gaqo/n (cf. dikai/ws presently) rather than to\ a)sfale/s (cf. kerdale)ws).

tw=n cumma/xwn toi=s a)gaqoi=s—lit. ‘when, while feeling (e)/xousi with u(mi=n) lasting gratitude towards brave allies,
what is perhaps (pou) your interest at the moment is also secured.’ The chief emphasis is, of course, on the participial phrase, which states the permanent condition or test of the righteousness of pursuing one's own interest. (The conjecture e)/xousi for MSS. e)/xwsi, which cannot be satisfactorily explained, seems certain. For the dat. toi=s a)gaqoi=s depending on a dat. e)/xousi cf. [Xen.] de Rep. Ath. 1 6 toi=s o(moi/ois sfi/sin au)toi=s h)=n a)gaqa/ ‘for those like theniselves.’ It is impossible to find a subject for e)/xwsi, and Mr. Spratt's rendering of th\n xa/rin e)/xwsi ‘command a recognition’ is incorrect. That this passage, however, is completely restored by reading e)/xousi, it would be rash to assume.)

proske/yasqe—as pro-skopei=n always implies a look into the future, there is much to be said for the conjecture pros-ske/yasqe ‘consider besides’ here, for advice to consider the future has already been given in the preceding chapter. But as the Spartan reputation for a)ndragaqi/a was based on the venerated institutions of Lycurgus, they might be supposed to be specially sensitive about the future of that. 2

a)ndragaqi/as—a merit for which Dorians especially valued themselves: here and at c. 64, 1 “the point is the special Dorian claim to an aristocratic strain of feeling and conduct” (Neil: see above on c. 40, 4). Perhaps ‘good breeding.’
mh\ ta\ ei)ko/ta—a neg. is not seldom placed before the article or preposition (ou)k e)n o)li/gw|).
e)painou/menoi—viz. as models of a)ndragaqi/a.
ou)d'—‘no more than you.’
e)pignw=nai—after gnw/sesqe above, the e)pi- can scarcely have its usual force, ‘to decide further’: the sense is probably merely ‘to arrive at a decision.’
tou\s me\n pate/ras . . u(ma=s de/—‘if you, whose fathers . . ,’ the first clause being subord. to the second. Generally deino/n is followed by ei) in such cases.

to\n tri/poda—i.e. on the bronze pedestal of three intertwined serpents that supported the gold tripod set up at Delphi from the tithe of the Persian spoils dedicated to the Pythian god. It stood close to the altar before the temple. The pedestal was taken by Constantine to Byzantium, and still exists, with the names of the states inscribed on the lower part of the spiral. The tripod was appropriated by the Phocians. (Herod. IX. 81, with Stein's notes.)
panoikesi/a|—after po/lin and *pla/taian this means (as Steup points out) ‘with all its houses,’ not ‘household and all’ as in II. 16.
tou=to—referring to what precedes.
a)pwllu/meqa—Plataea was burnt by Xerxes. The rendering ‘we were all but destroyed’ is borne out by other passages; e.g. Andoc. de Myst. § 41.
e)n—as in kri/nesqai e/n
a)gw=nas—‘hazards.’
to/te—referring to the siege of Plataea, to/te being frequently used of a well-known occasion.
periew/smeqa ‘we are outcasts.’
ra/ntwn is probably masc.; cf. e)k panto\s tou= '*ellhnikou= above.
a)timw/rhtoi—‘unsuccoured.’
be/baioi—‘faithful.’
cummaxikw=n—i.e. the gods by whom the oath to be true to the alliance was taken.

th/n te dwrea\n . . pre/pei—‘and (we call on you) to ask in your turn the favour of them—that you do not kill men whom it disgraces you to kill.’ a)nt-apaith=?sai means, in answer to the favour they have asked of you—viz. ktei/nein h(ma=s. To this explanation rather than ‘in return for our services,’ ei)/ ti e)pei/sqhte and a)nti\ ai)sxra=s (xa/ritos) point, and this is the natural force of a)nti-, as in drw=n a)ntipa/sxw xrhsta/, and so on; cf. a)ntilabei=n presently. The subj. of a)ntapaith=sai is u(ma=s, and au)tou/s means the Thebans. The mh/ after ou(/s is because the rel. clause is subord. to an infin. In this series of four co-ordinate infin. clauses, the second and third have te, the fourth has kai/.
sw)frona—from us, in contrast with
ai)sxra=s from them.
kaki/an—‘ill-fame,’ character of kakoi/, as e.g. in Soph. Ant. 924 quoted on c. 82, 8
kat' a)na/gkhn—as explained in c. 55, 1.

w(/ste kai\ . . poiou=ntes . . kai\ pronoou=ntes—this is not clearly expressed, for the first participial clause states what follows from the previous sentence; but kai\ pronoou=ntes ktl. contains a new point (e(ko/ntas . . proisxome/nous), and should scarcely have been co-ordinated with a)/deian poiou=ntes.
poiou=ntes—supply h(mi=n: it is not clear whether h(mw=n is similarly to be supplied to pronoou=ntes.

no/mos the unwritten law; cf. cc. 66, 67. Prisoners who had not surrendered voluntarily were often killed. Appeals to the no/mos a)/grafos, pa/trios no/mos, no/mima pa/shs *)ella/dos are very frequent; and of course the Antigone is full of the a/grapta ka)sfalh= qew=n no/mima. In Xen. Mem. IV. 4, 19 Hippias defines the a)/grafoi no/moi as oi( e)n pa/sh| xw/ra| kata\ tau)ta\ nomizo/menoi.

e)sqh/masi—robes burned as offerings, probably, and not worn by the officials. The plur., joined with nomi/mois and a)parxa/s in this connexion, is surely mentioned as part of the e)nagi/smata. Plutarch in Aristides 21, giving an account of the ceremony as performed in his day, makes no mention of robes among the offerings; but the details may well have been modified by his time. On the contrary, he does say that the Provost wore a purple coat and carried a sword; but the present passage does not lead like a ref. to that. That clothes were burnt as offerings to the dead is well known, e.g. Eur. Hec. 573.
e)pife/rontes—specially used of offerings to the dead; II. 34.
cu/mmaxoi . . genome/nois—the object of the speaker is to emphasize the lasting effect of the old alliance and to say nothing of the alliance with Athens.
o(mai/xmois is an oldfashioned word, perhaps intended to recall the old times.
au)qe/ntais—as having sided with the Persians. Another old-fashioned word.

i(era/ te . . a)fairh/sesqe—there are three difficulties here:—(1) e)rhmou=te, present, among a series of futures. This can hardly be defended by passages in which a single pres, and fut. are combined, such as II. 44 ou)k o)lofu/romai ma=llon h)\ paramuqh/somai. StahI reads e)rhmou=ntes after Goller; Steup proposes to leave the word out If sound we must render ‘you are making desolate.’ (2) What is the constr. of tw=n . . ktisa/ntwn? The natural answer is that it depends on a)fairh/sesqe (‘you will take from’), not on qusi/as. The objection, that the Plataeans will ex hypothesi be dead, is hardly serious, for tw=n . . ktisa/ntwn includes the whole Plataean people of whom no small part was safe at Athens. Neither is there any need to render a)fairh/sesqe ‘you will deprive,’ a sense that a)fairou=mai no where has when the object is inanimate. (3) Is i(era/ or qusi/as the object of tw=n . . ktisa/ntwn? My reason for preferring qusi/as is that qusi/as ta\s patri/ous must refer to commemorative
sacrifices to the gods founded after the victory of Plataea: otherwise the Lac. could have no interest in them, and the speaker could not seek to influence them by such an argument. These sacrifices are to the gods, and they were offered on behalf of Greece—u(pe\r th=s *(ella/dos (Plut. Arist. 20, 21): hence the last sentence duly accords with h)leuqerw/qhsan oi( *(/ellhnes and e)kra/thsan (oi\ *))ellhnes). (The no/mima tw=n *(ellh/nwn are not in question here.)
e(ssame/nwn—this archaic form in place of e(same/nwn has by far the best MS. authority, and perhaps is meant to accord with o(mai/xmois and au)qe/ntais.
ta/de—the conduct deprecated in the last c., which conduct is now summarized in ou)/te . . ou)/te.
oi)/ktw| sw/froni labo/ntas—‘regarding (the case) with prudent compassion.’ The point of sw/froni is given in a)ll' . . cumpe/soi. The obj. of lamba/nein in this sense is omitted also in VI. 61.
w(s . . cumpe/soi—the subj. of cumpe/soi—to\ th=s c.—is anticipated.
pre/pon—sc. e)sti/.

o(mobwmi/ous; not found elsewhere; ‘having the same altars’ may mean either ‘worshipped at the same altar,’ of several gods worshipped together, or ‘having like altars’ throughout Greece; hardly ‘whose altars are common to all worshippers.’ The second suits the context best.
q'—this is a necessary addition, as the passage cannot make a fresh start at profero/menoi.

mh\ a)mnhmonei=n—Cobet pronounced these words spurious: the only constr. they can fairly bear is with profero/menoi o(/rkous, but, as h(mei=s is the subj. of the other infins., this is awkward. (w)/mosan would require fut. or aor. infin.: order and the addition of tw=n p. ta/fwn are against i(ke/tai gigno/meqa.) tw=n p. ta/fwn is rendcred ‘by . . tombs,’ but the gen. can hardly be so understood with i(ke/tai, on which it directly depends.
u(mw=n—emphatic.

toi=s e)xqi/stois—sc. to your dead (not to us). “The dead are implored to prevent the Pl., their best friends, being surrendered to the Theb., their worst enemies” (Widmann). h(=| . . e)n th=|de—e)n should not be made to apply to h(=|, as this kind of idiom (Aesch. Sept. 1032 mhtro\s talai/nhs ka)po\
dusth/nou patro/s) is confined to poetry (Wilamowitz on Eur. HF. 237).
pra/cantes . . kinduneu/omen—a compressed form of e)pra/camen, nu=n de/ ktl. For nu=n we might have expected the ei)=ta of inconsistency.
o(/per de/—the rel. clause qualifies pauo/menoi, for which we might have had poiou=ntes.
lo/gou teleuta=n—epexegetic of o(/per. The gen. with teleuta=n again in c. 104. If you ‘begin’ with a gen., you may naturally ‘end’ with one.
met' au)tou=—viz. tou= teleuta=n.
e)s ta\ au)ta\ katasth/santas—i.e. as we were before we capitulated.
to\n cuntuxo/nta—‘any that comes’; cf. o/ tuxw/n.
i(ke/tai o)/ntes—‘as suppliants.’ The likeness of this peroration to the poignant appeals in Euripides should be noticed.
kai\ au)toi/—‘they on their part’; I. 51, Xen. Hell. VII. 1, 7.
to\ e)rwthqe/n—cf. Xen. Mem. IV. 2, 23 to\ e)rwtw/menon a)pokri/nesqai.

ou)de\ h)|tiame/nwn—best taken as agreeing with au(tw=n, ‘and moreover when they have not even been accused.’ The alternative, neut. depending on a)pologi/an, ‘of conduct that was far from being made a charge against them,’ produces tautology with w(=n ou)dei\s e/me/myato. kai\ a(/ma adds something of special importance, often in Thuc.; Xen. Cyr. I. 4, 25 kai\ dia\ to\ filei=n au)to\n kai\ a)/ma e)lpi/das e)/xwn.
pro\s me\n ta/—cf. c. 82 e)pi( de\ tw=|. This is the ordinary order when a prep. occurs with o( me/n or o( de/, e.g. Isocr. II. 18 i(/na ta\s me\n feu/gwsi, pro\s de\ ta\s proqumo/teron e)/xwsin.
kaki/a referring to the kathgori/a, do/ca to the a)pologi/a kai\ e)/painos of the Plat.: not ironical, as the schol., but the use noticed above, c. 58, 1.
tou/twn is masc.; cf. h(mete/ra and ou(=toi below.
h(mw=n—the Boeotian migration from Thessaly.
cummei/ktous—Pelasgians, Thracians, Hyantians (Strabo).
h(gemoneu/esqai—i.e. to acknowledge the h(gemoni/a of Thebes in Boeotia.
proshnagka/zonto—an attempt to make them observe ta\ pa/tria. See c. 65, 2.
ou) belongs to mhdi/sai.
*)aqhnai/ous—attraction to case of au)tou/s.
i)de/a|—‘method.’
kai/toi . . ei)/dei—‘you must surely consider the conditions under which.’
e)tu/gxanen . . politeu/ousa—‘was in point of fact’: tugxa/nw, as often, not of a mere accident, but of the true state of things, as distinct from what might appear to be.
