i)so/nomon—where all the nobles are equal, and their rights are fixed by laws. But in a dunastei/a the few rulers are a law to themselves.

tw=| swfronesta/tw|—‘the best order,’ i.e. an aristocracy or moderate democracy. No doubt this is said with reference to the constitution of Thebes, as existing in 427 B.C., with its two Boeotarchs and four assemblies confined to toi=s kekthme/nois plh=qo/s ti xrhma)twn, as Theopompus or Cratippus says. (Several conjj. have been made on this unusual expression, e.g. tw=| sw/froni pa)ntwn Herw.: tw=| swfroneste/rw| Hude.)
tura/nnou—for turanni/dos: so dh=mos for dhmokrati/a.
ou(=toi . . sxh/sein—‘these in the hope of winning power for themselves in yet greater degree.’
kai\ . . e)/pracen—‘so the city as a whole could not control her actions when she acted so, and it is not fair to blame her, for any crrors she fell into when she had no constitution.’
gou=n—‘thus for example’; illustrative of the previous statement.

e)pio/ntwn th/n te a)/llhn *(ella/da kai\ . . peirwme/nwn—as te cannot mean ‘and’ here, but must be correlative to kai/, it is clear that e)pio/ntwn governs th\n . . *(ella/da, and that the introduction of peirwme/nwn changes the constr.; cf. cc. 67, 6, 94, 3 (so Steup).
e)xo/ntwn—after the battle of Oenophyta, 458 B.C. The battle of Coronea in 446 forced the A. to abandon Boeotia.
pa/shs—‘any,’ inclusive, a common use of pa=s and its derivative adverbs.
h(mete/ra|—objective; II. 42 th\n tw=n e)nanti/wn timwri/an.
ta\ pro\s h(ma=s—adverbial, i(/na h(ma=s timwroi=sqe.
u(pa/rxon—sc. mh\ cunepie/nai. ge gives a causal sense to a partic.
proba/llesqe—as a defence; cf. I. 37 to\ eu)prepe\s a)/spondon probe/blhntai.
ge—not a common use of ge, where it serves to connect, and at the same time throws feeling into the sentence: ‘Ah, yes.’
pare/xein—sc. u)mi=n.
de/ ge or de\ . . ge is used to cap a previous statement or, while accepting it, to bring in a consideration on the other side; it is common in retort (Neil).
kata-prodou=nai—‘utterly to betray’; so prob. in katadouloume/nous.
toi=s de/=e)kei/nois de/.

kai/toi . . a)podidome/nas—‘surely failure to return favours with like favours (cf. i)/shn above) is dishonourable; and not failure to return debts of gratitude that were justly incurred (cf. u)mei=s . . a)dikou/menoi) but of which the payment leads to injustice’ (cf. toi=s de\ a)dikou=sin). You should have waited till they were a)dikou/menoi to return the service they had rendered to you.

o(/ti . . ta)nanti/a—‘because the A. did not either, and we did, from your wish’ etc. h(mei=s is much better than u(mei=s, giving antithesis to *)aqhnai=oi, as in toi=s me\n . . toi=s de/: cf. c. 63, 3.
boulo/menoi applies to the Plat.
a)po\ tou/twn—emphatic resumption of the attracted rel.
cunagwni/zesqe—‘continue their allies,’ in mockery.
*ai)ginh/tas—Aegina was reduced in 457 B.C. to the status of a tributary ally.
a)/llous tina/s—thought to be the Euboeans, who had fought at Plataea, and against whom Pericles may have employed the Plat. in 445 B.C.
diekwlu/ete—sc. a)/llous katadoulou=sqai.
periteixi/zesqai—‘before the siege was begun.’
h(mw=n—‘on our side.’ This demand had been made by K. Archidamus, but the Theb. adopt it.
toi=s *(/ellhsi—the dat. of agent with other parts than perf. of pass. is not uncommon in Thuc.
a)ndragaqi/an—in remaining true to Athens.

ou) . . e)pedei/cate—‘you have now shown not to belong to your nature.’ Thuc. does not use e)pideiknu/nai in this sense elsewhere, but other authors, e.g. the orators, do. It is prob. unnecessary to read a)pedei/cate or u)pedei/cate. Steup renders ‘you showed afterwards.’
e)chle/gxqh e)s to\ a)lhqe/s—‘has been conclusively demonstrated.’
a)dikou=men—‘are guilty,’ as often.
koina/—‘common to.’ Plataea had remained outside the Boeotian league as reconstituted in 446 B.C., and of course had no representatives in the General Assembly of the league which met at Thebes.
katasth=sai—‘bring you into line with.’
plei/w paraballo/menoi—they were ou) tw=n a)dunatwta/twn (II. 3); cf. § 2. For the verb cf. c. 14, 1.

fili/ws, ou) polemi/ws komi/santes—cf. the au)toi/ and pole/mioi of § 2, and c. 66 ou) polemi/ws e)pra/ssomen which show that the adverbs cannot apply merely to the Plat. and mean ‘with friendly, and not hostile intent to their fellow-citizens’; but must refer to the Theb. For this reason, and because komi/santes lacks an obj., Steup reads fili/ous and polemi/ous. But ‘in a friendly manner’ implies here ‘us as friends of Plataea,’ and komi/zein is used like de/xesqai. It is not necessary to have an obj. expressed; cf. e)pekale/santo above. The rest of the sentence shows that there is an intentional vagueness in the terms chosen: it was ‘a friendly transaction.’

u(mw=n—partitive, in unusual position; cf. c. 22, 5. mhke/ti ma=llon gene/sqai—xei/rous and a)mei/nous have a political meaning here, and are scarcely felt as comparatives: hence ma=llon is natural; ‘should henceforth not get more so.’

swfronistai\ . . oi)keiou=ntes—adopting Weil's view that gnw/mhs and swma)twn must be under the same governance, and that there must he a real antithesis between a(llotriou=ntes and oi)keiou=ntes, tr. ‘seeking to regulate opinion and persons, not alienating their city (handing it over to strangers), but bringing it home to the union of their kinsmen’ (the Boeotian confederacy). It is usual to take tw=n swma)twn with th\n po/lin, ‘not depriving the city of your persons’: this is very strange for ta\ sw/mata th=s po/lews a)llotriou=ntes. swfronistai/ of the party opposed to extreme democracy; cf. c. 82, 8. (For the antithesis of sw=ma and gnw/mh, Andoc. de Red. 24.)

e)xqrou\s . . e)nspo/ndous—“sc. u(ma=s; not breaking your peaceful relations with any state, e.g. Athens, but putting you in them on a footing with every other state, i.e. Thebes. Plataea was still, as they sophistically say, to enjoy the spondai/, but not on conditions peculiar to herself. a(/pasi depends on o(moi/ws” (Prof. Lamberton).
proei/pome/n te—the account corresponds very closely with the narrative of the attempt on Plataca in II. 2 f.
plh/qous—often used of the majority.
mh/te . . e)celqei=n—explaining ta\ o(moi=a.

ou(\s me
 . . a)lgou=men—the sentence takes an unexpected turn: instead of tou\s me
 a)pektei/nate we get a comment on that action. The rel. in each case is causal, =o(/ti tou\s me/n: cf. I. 68 ti/ dei= makrhgorei=n, w(=n (=e)pei\ h(mw=n) tou\s me
 . . , IV. 26 a)qumi/an de\ plei/sthn o( xro/nos parei=xe, ou(\s (=o(/ti au)tou)s) w)/|onto e)kpoliorkh/sein.
parano/mws—see c. 58, 3.
ka)ntau=qa—this emendation of kai\ tau=ta seems necessary, since tau=ta trei=s a)diki/as for ‘these as three wrongs’ is unexanipled.
luqei=san—for the constr. see on c. 53, 3.
ktei/nein—the pres. depends on the subst.: but the verb (u(pisxnou=mai) always has the fut. au)tw=n—au)ta/ referring to what has been mentioned, as often.

h(mei=s de/—to supply ei)dw=men is grammatically necessary; ‘that we may know after your condemnation that we have yet more rightly taken vengeance on them.’ To e)/ti o(siw/teron we must surely supply u)mw=n: you will act justly: we shall have acted yet more equitably We are the parties chiefly aggrieved. But it is said (already by Bloomfield) that for ei)dw=men we need ‘feel’ or ‘appear,’ since the Theb. do not discover anything from their own speech: hence 1. fanh=te for ei)dh=te Rauchenstein; or 2. take ei)dh=te as a zeugma; or 3. read h)ma=s . . tetimwrhme/nous Kr. But notice (1) the speech would lead to condemnation by the judges; (2) the condemnation would show the Theb. that their action had been justified. The only alternative, I think, is to supply w)=men, and to assume an assimilation of finite verb to the previous partic. clause, as Hude, who compares Xen. Mem. II. 3, 17.
a)kou/ontes—‘by the account of.’ a)kou/wn, like klu/wn, is often used where we expect an aor. partic.
diplasi/as zhmi/as—the influence of the rel. does not extend to this clause.
ou)k e)k proshko/ntwn—i.e. contrary to what was to be expected of them.
w(=n—see on c. 2, 1 l. 3.

oi( de\ . . leleimme/noi—‘others left behind in old age and their homes desolate.’ The emendation kat: oi)ki/as or kai\ ai( oi)ki/ai, is necessary. The latter is better, because oi)ki/ai e)rh=moi should certainly be co-ordinate with oi\ de/, so as to correspond with th\n sfete)ran e)rhmi/an.
ta\ e)nanti/a—adverbial.
e)pi/xartoi—sc. a)/cioi/ ei/si.
di/kh kri/nantes together correspond to ui/sei.

ou)k a)ntapodo/ntes—i.e. they will not have done so, because the penalty will be e)/nnoma: whereas our suffering was a)/noma (§ 6; cf. pareno/mhsan); the aor. partic. alluding to fut. perf. time as if the main verb were fut., cf. e)kstrateusa)menoi c. 102. (Various changes have been proposed: (1) to alter a)ntapodo/ntes to fut., pres., or a)\n a/ntapodo/ntes, or to read a)ntapodo/ntes e)s nu=n: (2) or, keeping a)ntapodo/ntes, to start a new sentence at kai\ ou)k, placing e)/nnoma ga)r in parenthesis. It does not seem possible to separate the latter from pei/sontai. It is best to suppose a slight break after kri/nantes, as though the rest were an afterthought.)
kai\ h(mi=n—instead of a second obj. corresponding to kai\ tw=| no/mw|, a new verb follows: cf. c. 71, 1.
w(=n pro/qumoi g.—see § 3.
toi=s lo/gois—dat. of cause.
w(=n . . o)/ntwn depends on a)paggeli/a.
e)/pesi—‘fine phrases,’ =r(h/masi.
kefalaiw/santes—for the point see c. 52, 4.

pro\s tou\s cu/mpantas—‘with referenee to all,’ i.e. (as Classen) ‘as a warning to all.’ A summary question followed by a decision will serve to check rhetorical defences. (Weil conjectures pro\s to\ cu/mpan.)
poih/shsqe—attraction to u\mei=s, as in I. 82 o(/soi w(/sper kai\ h(mei=s e)pibouleuo/meqa.
ei) . . pepo/nqasi is the e)perw/thma.
to\n a)/llon xro/non—‘all along.’
dh=qen—always ironical, signifying that this is not the true reason.
meta\ to\n *mh=don—usually meta\ ta\ *mhdika/.
kai\ (
h)ci/oun)

o(/te . . ou)k e)de/canto—it is impossible to make grammar of the sentence with o(/te . . a(\ . . w(s in. Each word has been altered: the removal of a(\ seems most likely; ‘and particularly, when afterwards the offer that they made of remaining neutral according to that convention was refused.’
h(gou/menoi—this gives the reason for nomizontes . . e)de/canto.

th=| . . boulh/sei—‘by their own just intention,’ i.e. they had tried their best to conform to the spondai/: it was the fault of the Plat. that the Lac. have fair grounds for regarding the spondai/ at an end.

to\ au)to/—obj. of e)rwtw=ntes, so that paragago/ntes kai/ breaks the constr.; cf. Soph Antig. 1279 ta\ d' e)n do/mois | e)/oikas h)/kein kai\ ta/x' o)/yesqai kaka/, where ta\ d' e)n d. is governed by o(/yesqai.
h)ndrapo/disan—‘sold as slaves.’ From II. 78 we know that 110 women were among the besieged Plat. (all the others had found refuge at Athens) and that these were all slaves already.

*qhbai=oi—removed by Classen, who maintained that the true subj. of e)/dosan is the Lac.; but cf. c. 58, 5 ei/ . . xw/ran th\n *plataii/da *qhbai+/da poih/sete. ta\ sfe/tera certainly seems to refer to the Thebans (cf. II. 2). (Herbst and Busolt defend the MS. reading.)
kata\ sta/sin—the circumstances are unknown.
e)k tw=n qemeli/wn—take with w)|kodo/mhsan.

pro\s tw=| *(hrai/w|—the site of the Heraeum and remains of the new\s li/qinos have in all probability been discovered (Am. J. of Archacol. 1891). It is likely that the temple previously existing was pulled down and replaced by the new one mentioned here.
katagw/gion—for those who came to worship at the temple: otherwise they would have had no shelter after the destruction of the city.
pantaxh=| is put with diakosi/wn podw=n (200 ft. square) by some edd., but more prob. belongs to ku/klw|=‘all round,’ as in VII. 79.
oi)kh/mata—for sleeping: they were in two stories.
toi=s a)/llois—instrumental, with kataskeua/santes.
tei/xei—i.e. inside the city. The sacred precinct lay ‘before the city’ (Herod. IX. 61).
kai/—intensive.
a)/rti to/te kaqista/menon refers to the fall of Plat., not to the beginning of the siege. Cf. c. 3, 1.

tri/tw| kai\ e)nenhkostw=|—519-427 B.C. But Grote showed that 509 B C. was the probable year of the alliance; hence it has been suggested that e)nenhkostw=| is due to an early error in an uncial MS., and that Thuc. wrote the uncial signs for o)gdohkostw=|.
e)peidh/—cf. I. 6 ou) polla e)/th e)peidh\ pe/pautai.
to/te—see c. 33, 1.
e)k tw=n )*aqhnai/wn—the other places in Thuc. in which e)k ‘on the part of,’ practically =u)po/ are I. 20, II. 49, V. 104, VI. 36. The use is Ionic; not found in ordinary Attic prose.

spora/des—correl. with the preceding partic., as in c. 82, 1 ou)k a)\n e)xo/ntwn pro/fasin ou)d' e(toi/mwn parakalei=n, but Classen points out that a)p' au)th=s spora)des goes more closely with kathne/xqhsan, and regards kai/ before a)p' as spurious.
*kullh/nh|—the port of the Eleans.
cu/mboulon—because the nau/arxos had shown his incompetence.
peri\ *nau/pakton—see c. 7, 3.

pri\n . . profqa/swsi—the constr. is o(/pws de\ profqa/swsi (a second reason of the plan adopted), pri/n . . , but for the sake of the antithesis between dw/deka . . paro/ntwn and ple/on ti e)pi. the order is changed.
h)=lqon au)toi=s—see on c. 5.

e)k tw=n . . naumaxiw=n—there were two battles fought near the islands called Sybota. 250 of the principal Corcyreans were taken prisoners in the second battle, and were conveyed to Corinth, where they remained about five years.

o)ktakosi/wn—the ransom for not more than 250 men is very high, but the prisoners were very important. The price paid for a man varied very much, of course, as it does still. The lowest heard of is two minas (Herod. v. 77), the highest— in the case of an ambassador of Philip—nine talents. The sum here mentioned need not be thought so great as to rouse suspicion.
toi=s proce/nois—i.e. the Corinthian representatives of Corcyra had gone bail for them.

a)fikome/nhs . . a)gousw=n—edd. say a)gousw=n must be plur. because both ships had pre/sbeis on board. Yet we find pred. in sing. applying to several subjects; I. 42, 1, IV. 31, 2, VI. 31, 1, VII. 44, 6, 58, 4. For the attraction cf. e. 72, 2.
katasta/ntwn—sc. tw=n pre/sbewn.
cugkei/mena—it was a defensive alliance only.
pro/teron means before the convention with Athens, when Corcyra had been on good terms with the Pel., though not in alliance with any one.
h)=n ga\r . . u(pa/gousin—the reason stated in advance in parenthesis; cf. c. 107, 3.
e)qelopro/cenos—only mentioned here; it prob. means that P. had not been appointed by Athens; and hence he could be prosecuted for his Athenian sympathies.
proeisth/kei—unofficial leader.
xa/rakas—‘vine-poles,’ Corcyra having many vineyards. The sites of the teme/nh are unknown. Alcinous is the Homeric king.
stath/r—of silver, worth 2 1/2 Attic drachmas, the only form of stater coined in Corcyra.
taca/menoi a)podw=sin—‘pay by a mutual arrangement,’ prob. on the instalment system.
tw=| te no/mw| e)cei/rgonto—nothing is to be supplied; ‘the law forced them, allowed them no escape.’ Cf. Herod. IX. 111 u(po\ tou= no/mou e)cergo/menos.
tou\s au)tou\s . . nomi/zein—i.e. to substitute a cummaxi/a, offensive and defensive alliance, for the existing e)pimaxi/a.
th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs—sc. o)/ntes.

tau=ta . . doulwqei=en—for the position of the first kai/ see c. 67, 6. It is usual to supply from tau=ta (i.e. what they had done) a ou(/tws to h(/kist' a(\n d.: better, I think, without; ‘that it was not likely that they would be made slaves by the A.’
de/xesqai—the meaning of ei)=pon passes into that of keleu/w.
mia=| nhi/—cf. II. 7.
h(suxa/zontas applies to the Corcyreans.
w(s—‘as.’ They were to put matters in a good light.
a)nepith/deion—to Corcyra.

e)pistrofh/—lest ‘notice’ should be taken by Athens, resulting in some action against Corcyra. The pre/sbeis must have completely won over part of the refugee friends of Peithias to their side, since it was thought necessary to intern them in Aegina (B. Schmidt).
e)lqo/ntwn—sc. tw=n pre/sbewn.
o(/sous e)/peisan—sc. tw=n e)kei= katapefeugo/twn.
The accompanying map will explain the situation of the contending parties.

o)li/ga—adverbial ace. like braxe/a and mega/la in c. 40, i)/sa in c. 14. The constr. is widely diffused in Thuc. The appeal to the slaves is a most unusual feature, and shows the extreme bitterness of the strife.
plh=qos—of the ‘majority,’ as often.
h(me/ras—the day referred to in c. 73.
xwri/wn—this word is specially used of strategic positions.
kera/mw|—collective, as e.g. in II. 4. So ka/lamos II. 76; in Livy XXIII. 16 vallum ferre=vallos f.
dei/santes—ingressive, ‘becoming afraid.’
au)toboei/—said to be an archaie word.
newri/ou—in the Harbour of Alcinous.

cunoiki/as—situated between the Agora and the Acropolis. The gen. adjj. that follow refer to both oi)ki/as and cunoiki/as. No doubt some of the o)li/goi had invested money in the tenements, and let them out, like the plutocrat pork-butcher in the Knights of Aristophanes.
e)kindu/neuse . . diafqarh=nai—cf. c. 40, 5.
w(s e(ka/teroi—‘on either side,’ an idiomatic phrase, to be taken with h(suxa)santes, which is ingressive (A. G. Laird in Am. J. of Phil. 1906, p. 43).
*niko/stratos—he had command of the Athenian squadron at Naupactus, from which he could reach Corcyra in a day. The Messenians had been settled in Naupactus after the Messenian Wars.
e(/prasse—conative.
de/ka—oligarchs.

oi( tou= dh/mou prosta/tai—a bronze plate found on the site of the Corcyrean Agora and now in the Brit. Mus. contains a decree of the Corcyrean Assembly (a(li/a) appointing an Athenian ‘proxenus’ of Corcyra. Among the Corcyrean authorities mentioned in the decree, which is assigned to the 4th cent. B.C., oceurs prosta/tas *gna/qios. The prosta/tai therefore appear to have been a board of magistrates in Corcyra (Anc. Gr. Inscr. in the Brit. Mus. Pl. ii. p. 50).
cumpe/myein—sc. e)/fasan, by an idiom to which Thuc. is partial.
to\ *diosko/rwn i(ero/n—the site is unknown.

th=| tou= mh\ cumplei=n a)pisti/a|—‘by their distrust in sailing (i.e. in the proposal that they should sail) with them.’ The mh/ is added because the whole result is neg., as often; cf. II. 49 h) a)pori/a tou= mh\ h(suxa/zein, Plato, Apol. 38 D a)pori/a tou= mh\ e)qe/lein.
oi( a)/lloi—oligarchs, not confined to those who had refused to go on board the five ships.

to\ *(/hraion—see the map, with notes. The removal from the shrine of Castor and Pollux to the Heraeum is to be accounted for by (1) supposing that the latter was the principal shrine of the city, and (2) the necessity of getting 400 men into the te/menos. (Bloomfield's view that the Heraeum was superior in sanctity is fanciful.)
gi/gnontai—of the sum-total, as often.
th\n . . diakomidh/n—example of the liking Thuc. shows for a subst. derived from a verb.
*kullh/nhs—c. 69. For

e)f' o(/rmw| ou)=sai we say ‘which had lain at anchor’ (at Cyllene), ou)=sai being imperf. partic. (MT. § 140). The MSS. have e)/formoi for e)f: o(/rmw|, but there seems to be no authority for e)/formos as adj. e)pe/plei—e)piplei=n is used of the commanders: e)mplei=n below of the crcw.
pollw=| qoru/bw|—the democratic authorities in Corcyra had received no warning of the approach of Alcidas. No organization for getting information of the movement of fleets existed.
tw=n poioume/nwn—not very common. for tw=n gignome/nwn.
*salamini/a kai\ *pa/ralos—see c. 33, 2. They had been with Paches at Mytilene; but must have joined Nicostratus at Naupactus.
to\ kaq' au(tou/s—to/ is inserted in order to get a contrast between Corcyreans and Athenians. kaq' au(tou/s alone =‘by, or among, themselves.’
a(qro/ais—with tai=s . . t.: the Athenians shrink from attacking the enemy thirty-three strong in the centre.

mh\ o(/per e)n *naupa/ktw| ge/noito—in 429 B.C. when the Athenian admiral Phormio with twenty ships gained a great suceess over forty-seven Peloponnesian ships by similar tactics. Then, too, the enemy had adopted a similar circular formation.
o(/ti ma/lista with prokatafugei=n, ‘as much as possible.’ It might be taken equally well with e)bou/lonto, but the general sense of the passage favours the former.
e(autw=n—cf. c. 13, 7.
toiau/th—cf. c. 97, 3. (Heitland's idea that there is some irony in toiau/th is quite groundless: h)=n de\ ou)dei\s ko/smos in c. 77 refers to only one incident in the battle.)
tou\s e)k th=s nh/sou—see c. 75, 5.
kratou=ntes—concessive.
o)/ntas—see on ee. 2, 2; 80, 1.
*leuki/mmhn—at SE. of the island, still called Leokimo.
toi=s a)/llois—the other o)li/goi besides the i(ke/tai.
o(/mws—in spite of the eonfusion.
me/xri me/sou h(me/ras—Thuc. generally uses me/sos as an adj., but Xen. often has me/son as a noun.
a)pe/pleusan—to Sybota.

prosple/ousai a)po\ *leuka/dos—no doubt the fleet was not yet past Leucas when the signal was given. It appears presently (c. 81, 1) that Aleidas feared to sail round the island lest he should be seen by the Athenians. (It is not necessary to construe a)po\ *leuka)dos with e)fruktwrh/qhsan, as many do. Aleidas could not know how far on its way from Leucas the Athenian fleet had got; and his fear was not wholly groundless.) This is the first mention of Eurymedon, who afterwards served in Sicily and was killed during the siege of Syracuse.

punqano/menoi—‘on hearing of the strife and of the intention.’ Notice that the verb has a double constr. here. Commentators point out (1) that the Athenian fleet doubtless
consisted to a large extent of ships returned from Lesbos: (2) that the news of the sta/sis was carried to Athens by the ship mentioned in c. 70.
th=s nukto/s—‘that night.’
to\n *leukadi/wn i)sqmo/n—the isthmus connected Leucas with the mainland: there is now an artificial channel.

labo/ntes—if genuine, best considered pleonastic (with Stahl), as we say ‘took and brought.’ Some think it a gloss on ei)/ tina la/boien below. To supply th\n po/lin (with L. Herbst) is forced, and involves an artificial, and highly improbable, explanation of the meaning. See crit. note.
tou\s *messhni/ous—see c. 75, 1.
peripleu=sai—from the harbour of Alcinous. The oligarchs who had been induced to embark would now be separated from their comrades in the Heraeum and the agora.
e)plh/rwsan—c. 80, 1.
a)pexrw=nto—very rare in this sense; cf. diaxrh=sqai in c. 36.
ta\ gigno/mena—i.e. from the Heraeum on high ground they saw their comrades being led off to execution.
w(s e(/kastoi e)du/nanto—the sing. might be expected, as in pa/ntes e)/fugon o(/ph? e)du/nato e(/kastos (Xen.), but the distinction is not always kept up.
pare/meine—it seems from this that Nicostratus had left by now. Thuc. has neglected to give his movements after his Messenians had been taken into the city.
sfw=n au)tw=n—partitive.
e)fo/neuon—rare word outside Herod., tragedy, and late writers.

th\n me\n ai)ti/an . . katalu/ousin—‘bringing the charge on the subverters of the democracy,’ i e. openly it was the oligarchs who were the object of their attack (th/n does not need explanation in the context after di/khn u(posxei=n above. Only oligarchs—and they not in all cases—were put on their trial.)

a)pe/qanon de/—transition from partic. to finite constr., as often; II. 47 lego/menon me\n . . e)mnhmoneu/eto de/, VII. 13 tw=n nautw=n me\n a)pollume/nwn, oi( de\ qera/pontes . . au)tomolou=si, sc. ta\ xrh/mata. Frequent throughout Gk.

u(po\ tw=n labo/ntwn—‘by their debtors,’ with a)pe/qanon.
The Gk. justifies another way (Bohme), viz with o)feilome/nwn, ‘by those who caught them,’ but the point is not so good.
pa=sa) te i)de)a kate/sth qana/tou—Virgil's et plurima mortis imago (Aen. II. 369); cf. Tac. H. III. 28 varia pereuntium forma et omni imagine mortium.
kai\ e)/ti peraite/rw—sc. ou)deno\s o(/tou ou), i.e. panto/s, but the gen. is habitually omitted. Demosth. XLV. 73 has deino/n, w)= gh= kai\ qeoi/, kai\ pe/ra deinou=.
h( sta/sis (Kruger) is very probable, as the ref. is to a sta/sis just described, but it is not absolutely necessary. 2
ma=llon—sc. w)mh\ proxwrh=sai.
e)n toi=s prw/thn—see on c. 17, 1.
w(s ei)pei=n—qualifying a sweeping statement (never apologizing for a metaphor): ‘I might almost say,’ ‘almost.’
to\ *(ellhniko/n—c. 57, 2.
e)pa/gesqai—“sense” constr., diaforw=n ou)sw=n implying ‘attempting.’

kai\ e)n me\n ei)rh/nh| . . e)pori/zonto—the transition from me/n+partic. to de/+finite verb here is considered perhaps the most extraordinary anacoluthon in Thuc. It is quite different from cases like c. 81, 4, since there is here no finite verb for the me/n-clause. To put a comma only at *lakedaimoni/ous instead of the usual full stop helps to some degree. e)to/lmwn for e(toi(mwn (Vollgraff and Classen) is a conjecture worth notice.
ou)k a)\n e)xo/ntwn—sc. au)tw=n, the leaders of both parties in any given state.
e(toi/mwn—sc. o)/ntwn, an unusual ellipse except when the adj.+omitted partic. is supplementary to a verb, as in tetu/xhke to\ e)pith/deuma a)/logon, sc. o)/n, I. 23.
au)tou/s—Athenians or Lac., as the ease might be.
polemoume/nwn—mase. from polemo/w, of the Ath. and Lac. (to refer this to the two political parties is very strained).

kai\ cummaxi/as a(/ma . . ai( e)pagwgai/—i.e. kai\ ai( e)pagwgai\ a(/ma cummaxi/as. The point of kai\ a/ma is that parties no longer carried on their rivalry amongst themselves at home, but readily called in the help of allies too. e)pagwgai/ is ‘opportunities for calling in.’ e(kate/rois is ambiguous: it may be (1) by the Ath. and Lac., agent to e)pori/zonto, or (2) to either party in a state <*> then toi=s . . boulome/nois will be in limiting apposition to it. In either case toi=s . . boulome/nois is probably not dat. of agent.

th=| . . prospoih/sei—the two ideas are parts of one whole, so that one art. suffices. The dat is that of motive, esp. common in Thuc., mostly with single words such as fili/a|, e)/xqei, eu)noi/a| Thompson, At Syn. p. 150. sfi/sin au)toi=s is governed by prospoih/sei, ib. p. 155. The whole sentence has the appearance of a series of notes that have not been put into their final form.
gigno/mena refers to time absolutely present, not contemporary with the main verb. MT'. § 141.

ma=llon . . dihllagme/na—i.e. varying in intensity and in form: ma=llon de\ kai\ h(suxai/tera form the first idea, adv. and adj. being combined, as either is possible separately with gi/gnetai. ma=llon kai\ h(suxai/tera gi/gnetai might also mean ‘it rises and falls in intensity’ on any given occasion, but the emphatic position of gigno/mena shows that it corresponds in sense to the emphatic e)/sti, not to the mere copula e)sti/.
w(s a)/n—‘according as.’
e)fistw=ntai—‘impose themselves,’ like a doom: kh=res e)festa=sin Il. XII. 326, Soph. OT. 776, Eur. Hipp. 819.
tou= kaq' h(me/ran—some think that bi/ou has fallen out before biai/ou, and certainly to\ kaq' h(me/ran is odd; but cf. to\ paro/n and ta\ paro/nta.
o)rga/s—‘dispositions.’
e)stasi/aze/ te—this passage down to the end of c. 83 is severely criticized by Dionysius Hal. de Thuc. iud. cc 29 f. for its artificial and far-fetched expressions

ta\ e)fusteri/zonta/ pou—‘the later cases,’ the cities that followed the example of discord set by others; a strange expression, as Dionysius says, but occasioned by ta\ tw=n po/lewn. Notice that pou=e)/n tini po/lei.
polu\ e)pe/fere—‘brought on much,’ i.e. carried much further.
dianoi/as—‘plans.’
tw=n . . a)topi/a|—lit. ‘through extreme ingenuity in their enterprises and strangeness in their revenges.’
a)ci/wsin belongs to e)s ta\ e)/rga, ‘in relation to facts,’ as well as to o)noma/twn. It is not necessary to repeat the art. before e)s because a)ci/wsis has another qualifying word.
th=| dikaiw/sei—by the arbitrary construction they put on them.
to\ d' e)mplh/ktws o)cu/—‘impulsive rashness’: cf. Plutarch, Eum. 3 e)/mplhkton kai\ fora=s mesto\n o)cei/as.
a)ndro\s moi/ra| prosete/qh—‘was ascribed, or set down, to the part of a man.’

a)sfalei/a| de\ . . eu)/logos—this appears to have been obscure already to Dionysius, who, while commenting on what precedes and what follows, discreetly leaves this alone. The usual explanation is as follows: (1) a)sfalei/a| is dat. of manner, in contrast with e)mplh/ktws; (2) to\ e)pibouleu/sasqai= ‘reconsideration,’ or ‘further reflexion’; (3) the verb to be supplied is e)nomi/sqh. Each of these suppositions is surprising a)potroph/=‘evasion.’ It has been proposed to supply prosete/qh (with Herbst and Fr. Müller) and to take a)potroph=s p. eu)/logos as apposition to to\ e)pibouleu/sasqai. We should then transl. ‘to form a hostile design was regarded as a measure of selfdefence, (being) the specious pretence of fending off enmity.’
o( me\n xalepai/nwn—viz. about the political situation.
e)pibouleu/sas . . tuxw/n—‘if one had succeeded in a plot.’
deino/teros—of ability.
au)tw=n—viz. tou= e)pibouleu/ein kai\ u(ponoei=n.
e)pikeleu/sas—sc. kako/n ti dra=n. e)pikeleu/w ‘to encourage,’ of an authority, has dat; here keleu/w sets the constr. and e)pi/ is intensive.
kai\ mh/n introduces a new and important point (it never means ‘and yet’).
tou= e(tairikou=—‘the tie of party.’ To this e(toimo/teron refers.
w)feli/a|—‘to render help’ cf. the principle suggnw/mh a)delfw=| bohqei=n. This seems more likely than the usual explanation ‘for the public advantage.’

cu/nodoi—of political meetings, a word of sinister meaning in the political life of Gk. states, suggesting intrigue and treason. The verb is e)ge/nonto and had Thuc. written w)feli/as e(/neka and pleoneci/as above, all would have been clear.
e)s sfa=s au)tou/s=e)s a)llh/lous, a common use.

tw=| qei/w| no/mw|—i.e. it was not the oaths witnessed by the gods—qew=n o(/rkoi—that bound them when they exchanged pledges. Cf., for example, Eur. Med. 21 boa=| me\n o(/rkous, a)nakalei= de\ decia/s, | pi/stin megi/sthn, kai\ qeou\s martu/retai, and the celebrated passage in the same play, 439 be/bake d' o(/rkwn
xa/ris, ou)d' e)/t' ai)dw\s *(ella/di ta=| mega/la| me/nei, with Verrall's notes.

ta/ te a)po\ tw=n e)nanti/wn—the sense (says Prof. Lamberton) is, ‘when fair proposals were made by the adversary, the other party, when they had the advantage of superiority, would receive them not in a spirit of generosity, but only with practical precautions’ Thus oi( e)ndexo/menoi, not oi( e)nanti/oi, is the subject of prou/xoien. This is surely correct, though the passage is usually taken as if oi( e)nanti/oi denoted the stronger party, and the subject of e)nede/xonto were ‘the weaker.’ The right version is given by Herbst, who says “How can it be supposed that from the party that had the upper hand at the moment proposals should emanate that were generous to the weaker side, and how can any one conceive that generosity (gennaio/ths) should lead the weaker side to accept them?” For e)/rgwn fulakh=| cf c. 46, 4.
o(/rkoi . . cunallagh=s—‘oaths to confirm a reconciliation’; cf. Andocides, de Myst. 103 dihlla/ghte kai\ o(/rkous w)mo/sate.
pro\s to\ a)/poron e(. dido/menoi—‘as they were administered to either side only to meet an emergency.’ It is surely unnecessary to regard e(kate/rw| as dat of agent, as is usually done.

ou)k e)xo/ntwn applies to those who took the oaths tendered—i.e. it applies by sense to e(kate/rw|—and explains pro\s to\ a)/poron. o(/rkon di/dwmi generally means ‘I administer an oath,’ but in Eur. Hipp. 735 ‘I take an oath.’ The ordinary meaning gives an equallv good sense here.
e)n de\ tw=| paratuxo/nti—‘when a chance occurred.’

o( fqa/sas qarsh=sai—see MT. 903. 8, where grave doubts are raised as to the possibility of the infin. with fqa/nw in place of the ordinary partic. As fqa/sas qarsh/sas is intolerable, it is best to give the text as it stands, leaving the point undecided. The paraphrase of Dionysius is worth notice: ei) de/ pou paratu/xoi tini\ kairo\s kai\ ma/qoi to
 e)xqro
 a)fu/lakton, h(/dion e)timwrei=to o(/ti pisteu/santi ma=llon e)pe/qeto h)\ fulattome/nw|. dia\ th
 pi/stin applies to the enemy, as having confidence in the oath.
h)\ a)po\ tou= profanou=s=‘than when he attacked openly,’ giving the other side a fair chance.

r(a=|on d' oi( polloi\ . . a)gaqoi/—‘most men are more readily called elever if they are knaves than good if they are ignorant’ Another way of taking this is: ‘most men prefer to be called clever knaves rather than honest fools.’ The Gk favours the first. the connexion with the previous sentence the second. To make the latter way easier Steup brackets o)/ntes.
pa/ntwn d' au)tw=n ai)/tion—‘the cause of all that was office (i.e. the desire of office), resting on covetousness and ambition.’
e)k d' au)tw=n—viz. pleoneci/as kai\ filotimi/as.
kaqistame/nwn—masc., ‘when men were settling down to.’ The kai/ belongs, not merely to e)s to\ filonikei=n, but to the whole phrase to pro/qumon.
plh/qous . . sw/fronos—these are the fine names that were used for dhmokrati/a and o)ligarxi/a. i)sonomi/a was a catchword with democrats, swfrosu/nh with aristocrats.

a)=qla—this suggests several of the words that follow— a)gwnizo/menoi, perigene/sqai, e)pech=|san (the last unusual with object)—the general idea being that of a desperate struggle between enemies. (Very like is Xen Cyr. II. 2, 18-19.)
e)/ti mei/zous—as compared with the tolmh/mata.
prostiqe/ntes—from Dionysins, in place of protiqe/ntes of the MSS., for ‘to threaten’ hardly suits with what precedes.
yh/fou a)di/kou—best taken as subjective gen. depending on katagnw/sews.
xeiri/—the contrast is between force and the forms of law.
e)no/mizon—with dat., as xrh=sqai.

eu)prepei/a| de\ lo/gou—since eu)se/beia and lo/gou eu)pre/peia are not a proper contrast, many suppose that the contrast to the former is to be found in e)pifqo/nws ti, and consequently attach eu)prepei/a| de\ lo/gou to the rel. sentence, ‘those who managed to hide some malicious act under fair words.’ But the me\n . . de/ contrast is not between single words, but between the two sentences as a whole: eu)se/beia is ‘a name for piety,’ as e.g. in Soph. Ant. 924 th\n dusse/beian (‘reputation of being dussebh/s’) eu)sebou=s' e)kthsa/mhn, ‘on this pretence, covering an odious act, earned a better reputation.’ Thuc not seldom puts two similar words (eu)se/beia—eu)pre/peia) in contrast that do not really form an antithesis.
ta\ de\ me/sa tw=n politw=n—for the moderate element and the preference given to it by so many thinking men cf. Eur. Suppl. 244 triw=n de\ moirw=n h( 'n me/sw| sw/|zei po/leis.
to\ eu)/hqes—in the earliest, good sense of the word, according to its etymology (Plato, Rep. 400 E).

plei=ston mete/xei—‘in which nobility of character is
the chief element.’ Or, less probably, ‘which is a very important element of a noble mind.’ Cf. I. 84, 3.
e)pi\ polu\ dih/negken—‘gained the upper hand.’ e)pi( polu/ of space, ‘far and near.’

o( dialu/swn—‘there was nothing to . . neither.’ The fut. partic. as in Aesch. PV. 27 o) lwfh/swn ga\r ou) pe/fuke/ pw. (Steup is mistaken in supposing that h)=n must be the copula in our sentenee, if o( dialu/swn is taken as above.)

krei/ssous . . bebai/ou—the best way of taking this is as follows: (1) all men when they had the upper hand, by reflecting on the hopelessness of security took precaution rather against attack than were capable of trust in others.’ Thus logismw=| . . bebai/ou is to be taken together and refers to proesko/poun. But two other versions must be noticed: (2) ‘finding more strength in calculation against the unexpected than in pledges.’ Then tou= bebai/ou=h)\ tw=| bebai/w|. (3) ‘Being more inclined in their calculations to despair of security’ (or ‘than to security’). The last seems an impossible version of krei/ssous o)/ntes. The passage prob. repeats the thought of c. 82, 7.
gnw/mhn—‘understanding.’
e)k tou= polutro/pou—‘in consequence of their’—resemblance to Odysseus.
fqa/nwsi proepibouleuo/menoi—Gildersleeve is surely right in reading fqa/nwsi here, in accordance with the law that fqa/nw poiw=n and e)/fqasa poih/sas are the correct forms.
katafronou=ntes—causal. For the constr. cf. Xen. Hell. IV. 5, 12 katefronou=n mhde/na a)\n e)pixeirh=sai.

[The external grounds for regarding this chap. as spurious are these. (1) In cod. F it is obelized; (2) a scholium says that none of the commentators thought it genuine: all found it obscure in style and strange in thought; (3) Dionysius (time of Augustus), who says a great deal about cc. 81-82, and transcribes to the end of c. 83, does not mention this c.: the inference may be that he did not find it in his MS.; (4) there are very few scholia on the chapter. On the other hand it is certain that Dio Cassius, who wrote late in the 2nd cent. A.D., knew it. The citations from Josephus (fl. 70 A.D.) are not sufficient to prove that he knew the passage. If, then, this is an imitation, it must have been written before the end of the 2nd cent., and perhaps not before the reign of Augustus. The internal evidence is hardly decisive. If this is the work of an imitator, it is a remarkably skilful production; but I think
that any attentive reader of Dionysius, Josephus and Dio Cassius—not to mention Procopius—would hesitate to say that a scholar of the 1st or 2nd cent. A.D. could not have produced it. The most suspicious part is, I think, from ou) ga\r a)/n (§ 2) onwards. In the earlier part u(po\ tw=n th\n timwri/an parasxo/ntwn, dia\ pa/qous . . e)/xein, and kai\ para\ tou\s no/mous a)dikei=n are strange. The first sentence as regards constr. is, perhaps, merely a little corrupt. The weight of opinion among modern critics is against the c.; but the question cannot be decided.]
au)tw=n—vaguely referring to the ill deeds previously described. proutolmh/qh—pro- denotes before the rest of Greece.
kai\ o(po/sa—the kai/ is probably answered by oi)/ te mh/ ktl. below. The first clause requires a)/n, which has perhaps fallen out either after o(po/sa or dra/seian.

u(po\ tw=n . . parasxo/ntwn with a)rxo/menoi. Hitherto they have been ruled oppressively by those who now give opportunity for revenge. Instead of parasxo/ntwn something like h)/dh parexo/ntwn seems required. The oligarchs are meant.

dia\ pa/qous . . e)/xein—there has been much discussion of these words. tines and ma/lista d' seem to show that dia\ pa/qous must be intended as a contrast to peni/as . . a)pallacei/ontes, passion versus sheer poverty. But pa/qos=‘emotion’ or ‘passion’ occurs nowhere else before Aristotle: in Thuc. it=‘a disaster.’ (To take ta\ tw=n pe/las as equivalent to tou\s pe/las, and dia\ pa/qous e)/xein like di' o)rgh=s e)/xein does not get over the difficulty, and does not yield a proper contrast.)
e)pi\ pleoneci/a|—i.e prompted by oppression, poverty or downright passion
a)po\ i)/sou—‘on equal terms’ with their adversaries already. Only here in Thuc. in place of a)po\ tou= i)/sou.
e)pe/lqoien—sc. a)/n from the previous sentences. The omission is rather awkward and unusual in so long a sentence.
w)mw=s and
a)paraith/tws only here in Thuc.
e)s to\n kairo\n tou=ton—‘at this crisis,’ like e)s mi/an h(me/ran in VI. 16, Aristoph. Pax 366 ei)s ti/n' h(me/ran;

kai\ para\ tou\s no/mous a)dikei=n—cf. c. 82, 6 para\ tou\s kaqestw=tas (no/mous). As Stahl says, we expect krath/sasa after tou\s no/mous, ‘even when the laws are generally respected.’ Steup suggests the loss of pri/n after kai/ but Dio Cass. knew the passage as it stands.
e)dh/lwsen . . ou)=sa—obj. of dhlw= replaced by the partic., as often; cf. I 21 o( po/lemos dhlw/sei mei/zwn gegenhme/nos.
tou= prou/xontos—neut.
e)n w(=|—lit. ‘in a case in which,’ amounting to ei). Cf. II. 35 xalepo\n to\ metri/ws ei)pei=n e)n w(=| mo/lis kai\ h( do/khsis th=s a)lhqei/as bebaiou=tai.

a)ciou=si/ te—the sense is clearly given by Arnold thus: Men in their violence set the example of doing away with those common laws of humanity which all parties alike might have appealed to in their adversity, and by their own previous conduct put themselves out of the pale of those laws, when they themselves might have occasion to solicit their protection. By the koinoi\ no/moi the koino\s no/mos o( kata\ fu/sin, as Aristotle (Rhet. I. 13) calls it, is of course meant. See n. on c. 58, 3. Plato in the Laws (p. 793) says these observances are the desmoi\ pa/shs politei/as.
u(polei/pesqai—middle.
tai=s prw/tais foreshadows the further disturbances, described in book IV., which occurred when Eurymedon returned.
diesw/qhsan—aor. as plup., a common idiom in parenthesis.
tei/xh—built by Corcyra to protect its territory on the mainland against the neighbouring tribes, Chaones and Thesprotians.
e)lh/zonto—viz. the fertile central part of the island, e)ceirgasme/nh pagka/lws kai\ pefuteume/nh xw/ra, as Xenophon calls it (Hell. VI 2, 6).
u(/steron xro/nw|—always of a considerable interval. It is most probable that the crossing occurred in the spring of 426 B.C.

th\n *)istw/nhn—in IV. 46 we have e)n tw=| o)/rei th=s *)istw/nhs. It has been made highly probable (by B. Schmidt) that Istone is the whole mountain-range in the NE. of Corcyra. It is possible that the name belonged also to a particular height in the range.

e)s *sikeli/an—this is the first intervention of Athens in Sicily. Under Pericles (who had died in the autumn of 429 B.C.), Athens had concluded alliances with Leontini and Rhegium in 433 B.C, perhaps also—though we have no direct evidence—with Naxos and Catana. But the
idea of conquest in Sicily (§ 4) was entirely outside the policy of Pericles. See Introd. p. xxiii.

*la/xhta—the first mention of this well-known man. See c. 115. He was a supporter of Nicias in arranging the peace of 421. Plato's Laches is named after him. He is the dog Labes in Aristoph. Wasps. He was attacked by Cleon. He was killed at the battle of Mantinea, 418 B.C.
kaqe/stasan—when the war had broken out is not known.

plh\n *kamarinai/wn—Camarina, founded circa 600 B.C. from Syracuse, was dependent on the mother-city, revolted in 553 B.C. and was destroyed. In 492 B.C. it was restored by Hippocrates, tyrant of Gela, but shortly afterwards was again involved in war with Syracuse, and was again destroyed. Its third building occurred circa 460 B.C.
to\ prw=ton emphasizes a)rxome/nou.
*xalkidikai/—Naxos, Catana, Himera. They are so called because their origin was Chalcis in Euboea.

*)itali/as in the confined sense that it bears in Greek authors, the modern Calabria, the peninsula reaching to the Laus on W. and to Metapontum on E.: a)po\ a)/kras *)iapugi/as me/xm porqmou= *sikelikou= is the definition of Dionysius.
kata\ to\ cuggene/s—Rhegium, too, was Chalcidian.
pe/myantes—this is the famous embassy that was headed by Gorgias of Leontini. The reticence of Thuc. on the matter is characteristic.

palaia\n cummaxi/an—the only alliance we know of is that of 433 B.C., but six years seems too short a time to be denoted by palaio/s. Hence it is assumed that an earlier alliance existed. But some have thought that Thuc. wished to obscure the fact that Pericles was responsible for the alliance with Leontini, in order to make it appear that Pericles was in no sense responsible for the intervention in Sicily.
boulo/menoi de\ mh/te . . pro/peira/n te poiou/menoi— to make the sentence quite symmetrical, poiei=sqai should have been written in place of poiou/menoi.
dunata\ ei)/h—personal constr.
katasta/ntes—i.e. they chose Rhegium as their base.
e)klipou=sa me\n . . e)ge/neto de/—c. 81, 4.
to\ panta/pasin—this curious phrase, occurring only here, is to be compared with to\ para/pan.
ma=llon e)ka/kwse—no doubt this passage was written before the disastrous Sicilian Expedition of 415 B.C.

e)k tw=n ta/cewn—i.e. e)k katalo/gou, from those liable to serve as hoplites, those of the three higher (Solonian) elasses who wcre on the lists. Men were liable to ordinary service between the ages of 20 and 50. The fourth class—qh=tes— served only in the fleet; these with me/toikoi and dou=loi are included in o( a)/llos o)/xlos. The number of the hoplites on the lists at the beginning of the war was about 15,500. The cavalry numbered 1000.
oi(—as being well-known.
*boiwti/w|—the other was in Arcadia.
strateu/ousin e)pi\ ta\s *ai)o/lou nh/sous—as this affair is one of the lo/gou ma/lista a)/cia (c. 90, 1) we can see how insignificant were the incidents left unrecorded.
kaloume/nas—second attribute, hence the order; c. 54, 5.
ne/montai—the word is used of enjoyment of profits derived, which may or may not be combined with occupation.

e)n th=| *(iera=|—still called Vulcano The coins of Lipara show Hephaestus seated, with a hammer. The group of islands, seven in all, is still called Liparian or Aeolian. The full name seems to have been *(iera\ *(hfai/stou—Vulcani nomine sacra it is called in the Aetna.
*stroggu/lh now Stromboli, is there described as cui nomen facies dedit ipsa Rotunda.
w(s—very unusual constr. with nomi/zw.
*)atala/nthn—Talantonisi: it had been fortified by the Athenians in order that they might prevent the injury caused to Euboea by piratical craft sailing out of Opus and the neighbourhood.

*)axelw=|on—frontier between Aetolia and Acarnania. The route:— Through the territory of Stratus, the greatest city in Acarnania, westwards to the territory of Phytia (Phoitia); thence northwards through Eastern Medionia, which brought Eurylochus to the Ambraciau gulf; thence eastwards across the district of Limnaea, avoiding the town (of doubtful name) at the SE. corner of the gulf; and so across the low hills called Thyamus, and through the friendly territory of the Agraei; hence down into the territory of Argos, between that city and Crenae, to Olpae.

au)=qis—‘then,’ or ‘afterwards.’ It is usual to make *medew=nos depend on par' e)/sxata; but Herbst seems right in taking *medew=nos with dia/, and making par' e)/sxata modify the namc of both districts; i.e. they went along the border of Phytia and also of Medionia.
*)agrai+ko/n for a)groi=kon of the MSS., which is not used of districts, is a certain emendation.
kaqi/zousin—sc. to\n strato/n, but practically intrans.

*)aqhnai/wn—doubtless a small force stationed at Naupactus. Demosthenes used the ships referred to in c. 102, 4. Oberhummer thinks that from Limnaea he went by land, following the line of Eurylochus, that he joined the Acarnanian division at Crenae, and accompanied it to Argos. This seems most probable.
to\n lo/fon if genuine, is in apposition to ta\s *)/olpas, but the description does not seem likely or necessary after c. 105, 1.
*)amfilo/xwn—i.e. those of Amphilochia generally; for the reason why the majority were restrained from taking part in the fighting see c. 114, 3.
meta/—Demosthenes was to be Commander-in-chief.
xara/dra . . mega/lh—this has been recognized in a brook, the banks of which are overshadowed with plane-trees; cf. the o\do\s koi/lh kai\ loxmw/dhs.
kata\ to\ u(pere/xon—where the enemy's line (the left wing, c. 108, 1) outflanked them.
o)li/gwn—a strange way of referring to the sixty Athenian archers: we should expect simply meta\ tw=n *)aq. Possibly o)li/gwn is an addition to the text.
e)pei=xon governs to\ de\ a)/llo. The Acarnanians were in separate contingents, each under its own commander.
a)nami/c—on the right wing the Ambraciots evidently were the principal troops; cf. e. 108, 2.
e)s a)lkh\n u(pomei=nai—‘stand their ground to the point of resistance.’ For a)lkh/ see on c. 30, 2.
to\ kat' *eu)ru/loxon—‘that part where Eu. was.’

to\ polu\ tou= e)/rgou e)pech=lqon—both e/c- and e/pec- can have the accus.: the latter is the normal constr., and it is not certain that there is any parallel for the former in Thuc. In I. 70 the MSS. vary in the same way as here. § 2 l. 15.

maximw/tatoi—this refers to oi( *)amprakiw=tai only, not to oi( . . ke(ras, who are the few Peloponnesians on the right wing. This restricted reference is so awkward that it is not unlikely that kai/ after *)amprakiw=tai ought to be removed, so as to render ‘the A. on the right wing.’

w(s . . nenikhme/non—this is what they found on returning from the pursuit of the enemy's left. The inference is clearly that to\ ple(on also retreated to Olpae; cf. e)s fugh\n . . katasth=sai above. With a colon instead of the usual comma after *)/olpas, the difficulty that has been found in making au)tw=n presently refer—as it must do—to the whole army, disappears.
au)tw=n—‘of the armv.’ It cannot mean ‘of the right wing’ only, since the Mantineans were posted almost on the left wing.
prospi/ptontes—‘while rushing to the fortress of Olpae.’
au)to/s—‘single-handed.’
poliorkh/setai—‘to stand a siege.’ § 2 l. 13.
a)poqano/ntas=nekrou/s.
*)akarna/nwn depends on custrath/gwn, possessive gen.

spe/ndontai—for the plur. verb, rare with a sing. subj.
followed by meta/, see Thompson2 § 7. boulo/menos following makes the conjecture spe/ndetai probable.

to\n misqofo/ron o)/xlon—i.c. the Peloponnesian forces, exclusive of the Mantineans, the a)/rxontes and a)ciologw/tatoi. The Peloponnesian troops were mercenaries, it would seem. to\n ceniko/n is prob. a mere gloss on misqofo/ron.
diabalei=n e)s—‘to damage them with.’

*(/ellhnas—Steup places the comma at xrh/|zwn so as to make *(/ellhnas object of kataprodo/ntes, i.e. the Ambraciots and the o)/xlos misqofo/ros. This is better than e)s tou\s e)kei/nh| . . *(/ellhnas together, i.e. the Ambraciots only, because (1) the Amphilochians too would be naturally included under the tou/s, and they were not *)/ellhnes, (2) the mercenaries should certainly be included in the object of kataprodo/ntes.
w(/sper u(ph=rxe—‘as well as circumstances allowed.’
oi(=s e)de/doto—sc. e)kei=noi.
po/lews—c. 105, 4. The force from Ambracia had to march to Idomene (c. 112), then through the hills into the plain of Argos.
proloxiou=ntas—referring to the collective me/ros.
ta\ kartera/—strong positions in the hills.
oi(=s e)/speisto—see c. 109, 2.

pro/fasin—the so-called accus. in apposition to a sentence, best regarded as a free use of the internal or adverbial accus. The actions described are the pro/fasis (Bayfield on Soph. El. 130, Hardie, Latin Prose, p. 7).
oi( a)/lloi—i.e. the Peloponnesians who were not included in the secret agreement.

o(/soi . . cunecelqo/ntes—‘as many, that is, who had chanced to go out (from Olpac) in a body fortuitously with the others.’ This is the best interpretation of a passage that has been very much discussed. Notice (1) me/n. with no corresponding de/, implies a contrast: part remained behind in Olpae; (2) ou(/tws=w(s ei)=xon, ‘just by chance’; (3) the aorist partic. with e)tu/gxanon is unusual, the rule being e)tu/gxanon+ pres. or perf. partic. e)/tuxon+aor. partic.; (4) cunelqo/ntes, the other reading, would mean, ‘to have met together in Olpae.’ A great number of emendations have been proposed, but the reading of the MSS. gives a satisfactory sense. If (3) is a fatal objection, then (a) a comma must be placed at ou(/tws, and the latter must be considered to point forward to cunecelqo/ntes—
then e)tu/gxanon ou(/tws without a partic. is strange; or (b) me/n must be altered to memonwme/noi or me/nontes; or (c) a comma must be placed at a(qro/oi, so that e)tu/gxanon ou)/tws a(qro/oi sc. o)/ntes=‘happened by chanee to be together.’ Such an omission of a partic. with tugxa/nw is not impossible where an adj. is added.
oi( de\ *)akarna=nes—only their leaders knew of the secret compact.
tis—often explained as collective for tines: this is doubtful, because of the sing. nomi/sas following. § 4 l. 22.
e)s th\n *)agrai/da—the Agraei were independent and friendly to the Pcloponnesians. Woodhouse thinks that they were not Aetolians.
*)idomenh/n—twin heights in the hills, the exact site uncertain.
e)pi\ th=s e)sbolh=s—to the pass that led to Ambracia.
dia\ tw=n *)amfiloxikw=n o)rw=n—i.e. inland, among the hills, in order to stop up the roads.

a(/ma o)/rqrw|—the time between first cock-crow and the dawn: o)/rqros e)sti\n h( w(/ra th=s nukto\s kaq' h)\n a)lektruo/nes a)/|dousin. a)/rxetai de\ e(na/ths w(/ras (circa 2 A.M.) kai\ teleuta=| ei)s diagelw=san h(me)ran (Phrynichus).
*dwri/da te glw=ssan—it was only thirty years since the Naupactian Messenians had left the Peloponnese. The Ambraciots spoke Doric.
th=| o)/yei—‘with the eyes,’ pointing the contrast with what they heard. Here as in other passages (e.g. VII. 75, 2) it is disputed whether the phrase means this or ‘by their appearance.’
tw=n de\ . . a)nepisthmo/nwn—for the gen. abs. though it refers to the subj. of the verb see c. 13, 7, 55. 1.
parapleou/sas . . cuntuxi/a|—‘sailing along the coast from Olpae) just at the time when the action (the fighting) occurred.’
skuleu/santes—the Athenians themselves were not above this on occasions
kai\ au)toi=s.—the incident as related inevitably reminds us of a Greek tragedy—e.g. the Persae.
tw=n nekrw=n ou(\s a)pe/kteinan—cf. II. 52 nekroi\ e(p' a)llh/lois a)poqnh/|skontes.
cunech=|san—‘tried to depart with them.’
to\ pa/qos—‘the catastrophe’ of Idomene.
tw=n meta\ sfw=n—i.e. that they had belonged to those who had fought with his own comrades—i.e. with the body that escaped over the border.
qauma/zoi . . teqna=sin—the change of mood from opt. to indic. has nothing to do with the sense: it is purely styhstic Cf. c. 22, 8.
au)=—‘for his part.’

tw=n e)n *)idomenai=s—edd. compare II. 34 tou\s e)n *maraqw=ni where, however, e)n should prob. be omitted (see Neil on Aristoph. Eq. 785). In most cases a partic. is expressed; but ‘those of Idomenae’ is, of course, sufficient.

ta\ o(/pla tauti/—the omission of the nnmber—diakosi/wn—here appears to be impossible: ‘these are not the arms, then,’ would be natural, were it not for the contrast following. The schol. already did not find diakosi/wn in the text.
maxome/nwn—imperf.; cf. c. 62, 5.

ei)/per ge—‘yes if,’ taking up tw=n . . e)sti/n, exactly as in dramatic dialogue the retort is apt to catch up the question. (I have put a note of interrogation at e)sti/n in place of the usual full stop, because the remark seems to be a query as well as a denial: ‘then they are not . . ?’)
a)ll' h(mei=s ge—‘nay, but we.’
kai\ me\n dh\ . . ge—‘why I assure you it was with these’; for the particles cf. Plato, Symp. 197 *a kai\ me\n dh\ th/n ge tw=n zw|wn poi/hsin.
pa/qos—‘this disaster was the worst that . . ’ The number of days is three. The qualifications are very precise, and suggest that Thuc. is conscious that other events might be suggested.

kata\ to\n to/lemon to/nde—many think that only the Ten Years' (Archidamian) war is meant. It is impossible to attain certainty on the question. If Thuc. wrote this soon after the event, the expression is quite natural.
a)/piston—pred. not to gene/sqai, but to le/getai gene/sqai together, i.e. ‘the total that it is said to have amounted to is incredible.’
ple/onta e(a/lw—when or how is not explained.
e)ch|re/qhsan—the number is prob. influenced by the apposition panopli/ai.

kate/pleuse—to Athens. He was once more elected Strategus at the following elections (in spring of 425 B.C.) for the year 425-424. A statue of Nikē was set up on the acropolis as a memorial of this victory: an inscription relating to its repair is still extant. The Messenians and Naupactians set up a Nikē at Delphi: a fragment of the inscription upon it is extant.

a)naxw/rhsin . . e)c *oi)niadw=n—i.e. by sea, the ships obtained from Oeniadae, which was friendly. These Ambraciots had prob. got to Oeniadae from Agraeis by crossing the Achelous and marching right across Aetolia. They could hardly have got safely home to Ambracia by sea without leave from the Acarnanians. (oi)=per for oi(/per and *salunqi/ou for *salu/nqion are certain corrections.)
e)pi\ toi=sde—no attempt is made to modify the cummaxi/ai of Acarnania with Athens, or of Ambracia with Sparta.
bohqei=n of defensive, strateu/ein of offensive, operations.

e)pi\ *)anakto/rion—the Corinthians had added fresh colonists to this important place in 433 B.C. A year after this agreement (autumn 425 B.C.) the Acarnanians, supported by the Athenians at Naupactus, took Anactorium. § 4 l. 27.
die/lusan to\n po/lemon—Ambracia never recovered from its effects.

a)/nwqen—from the interior, where the Sicels dwelt: ta\ me/sa kai\ ta\ pro\s borra=n th=s nh/sou e)/xousi (VI. 2). *sikelw=n tw=n for *sikeliwtw=n is fairly certain: the Siceliots were being hard pressed by Syracuse.
ta\ e)/sxata—Freeman says that the extreme eastern part of the Himeraean land must be meant.

e)pi\ ta\s nau=s dia/doxon—it is hardly necessary to supply a partic.: dia/doxon in itself implies taxqe/nta. It appears that Laches, on retorning to Athens, was prosecuted for embezzlement of public money.
cu/mmaxoi—the Siceliots.
e)/peisan—plup. in sense.
w(s ou) perioyo/menoi—with pareskeua/zonto.
kataluqh/sesqai—by establishing themselves in Sicily.

mele/thn . . poiei=sqai—it has been pointed out that this is prob. intentional irony on the part of Thuc., who repeats the statements of the war-party of the day. There was an unlimited field for Athenian naval activity round the coasts of Peloponnese without sending fleets to Sicily.
*puqo/dwron—the three commanders are mocked at by Aristoph. Acharn. 598.
frou/rion—see c. 99.
tw=n *katanai/wn—Catania, now the second city in Sicily, has survived many terrible disasters, due partly to its wars, and partly to its proximity to the mountain.

penthkostw=| e)/tei—if the number is exact, the previous eruption would be in 475 or 474 B.C. There is a magnificent description of an eruption of Etna in Pindar's first Pythian (474 B.C.), and in Aeschylus, Prometheus Vinctus (circa 468 B.C.). An eruption is recorded as occurring at the time of the battle of Plataea, 479 B.C.
le/getai shows that Thuc. was not quite sure as to the exact date.
tri\s gegenh=sqai—the ‘first’ eruption is legendary. A fourth is recorded in 396 B.C.
